m703ZaOTKOmF2725dMXBWA.text: Great portions! It was only two of us and a fried rice plate could easily feed four people!   We went in for a late dinner. There was plenty of seating. Amber was our server. She was very kind and helpful. The service was a little lax, though. Given, it was a slow night.   I would definitely visit again. This is also a great spot for groups and families.

VlQIl0T_R39iPW5Wr7_0Vw.text: The chicken feet was really good. Everything else was good but not great. I wasn't wowed. Nice staff

WcjTlM9h12gj0FYltr8wqg.text: If you are looking for a great dim sum experience look no further! This place has been remodeled and makes the delivery of your dim sum more streamlined. The name itself is horrible - but the food is great! For the carts and the visual appetite is only during lunch hours, I found this out the hard way going in later in the evening. I think the carts and see what is available is an experience. You get all the smells and it encourages you to try something new. The best part is whatever you don't finish they box up for you. Some of my favorites are the har gow shrimp and the mung bean sesame balls. This little gem of a place is located in the Gold Coast Casino. It does not disappoint but get there early because the lines get long!

zEvBd11a8olipcP9nYkU3A.text: Before they moved I usually come here for the Dim Sum during the day, and I got to say they are one of the best!   The review I'm doing today will be the late night snack.  Food are all delicious for its price, portion is big, and service is ok.

5847SLo3A02JS9kyCeCJ_A.text: Our experience, three visits till date, have been spectacular  - both food flavour. Having said that I wonder why the Yelp reviewers have rated it so low, still wondering All three visits we ordered different dishes, mostly veggie, to experience the skill of the chefs there - Chinese cuisine and Veggie food are not common, right.  All times we were super impressed wanting more.  I would say this,, to the readers, don't just go by reviews on this spot, try it. It might be a real delicious experience

SVYVadLpv0RBG07471L0Hg.text: Very delicious and reasonable pricing! When family comes we usually stay at golf coast therefore we like to get dim sum here in the morning! It's very delicious! I wished chicken feet was served! That would complete my life, and would prob be the best dim sum in town! I hope they serve chicken feet soon lol

Np_UAjtCwjlSwlluiCGltw.text: It is legitimately good, authentic Chinese food near the Las Vegas strip within the Gold Coast Hotel & Casino. Most people go there for the dim sum. However, I went there for some late night eats after I landed in Las Vegas late at night. I ordered some spare ribs with black bean sauce [dim sum dish] and the salt and pepper fried pork chops. Both were very good and consistent with my expectations for what they should taste like from the same dishes in New York, specifically Chinatown. I definitely recommend Ping Pang Pong if you are craving Chinese food and do not want to venture out to Chinatown in Las Vegas.

2BSodX7zYp7BhAi-oA5c1Q.text: They're potstickers are really juicy and good if you enjoy the dough texture. They are not crispy, which is my preference, but over all flavorful. The orange chicken wasn't very crunchy but it had a lot of sauce and not super big pieces, nice enjoyable pieces. They're salt and pepper prawns where really flavorful and crispy. I don't know if I would return but don't completely regret giving it a try. Family style restaurant do they do serve a lot of food.

HNRXtlZMFMz55ceT1e1Sgg.text: These two hosts are so so bad with some serious attitude, lack of guest services training ! I and my wife went in for dim sum, the tall skinny one saw us walking in she never give us any eye contact nor say hi, never smile but got a face full with attitude expression, she just bend down grab a menu and start walking off to our table without saying anything to us. We didn't even sat down yet and she already took off. When we done with our meal and asked for a check, the other girl on the right of the picture delivered our check to the table without saying anything either and slam the check down on the table and then just walk off. This was only at 10:30am in the morning, the rush didn't even start yet. My blood pressure just shoot up to the ceiling, so I asked to the speak to the manager and explained how these two are so so poor in guest services and look so very much like how much they hate their job. On top of that they give bad name and reputation to the place and to the other people in that place that do such a wonderful job and also to the Chinese people around the world about bad manner that already been spreading for years ! What I want to know is how did these two get a job in there as a host in front of the house, or you guys just hire anyone of from the street without screening. The manager did handle and control the situation very well. To these two hosts .. If you hate your job so much, please do not come to work and give your other good team workers and the place such a bad name. We will not visit this place again because of the facts that these two are working there, just by looking at them really ruin my appetite. To Christy ( the general manager of Ping Pang Pong ) I hope you will handle these matter in a proper way. They serious need a drive and an attitude correction with serious guest services training !!!!!

vzBMd2cZon1MCPUY8DXtFw.text: A fun place with great food...also weekend dim sum is awesome

sDc7oRIcmG4o7LjNyZa4_g.text: Food was good, I was expecting not so good do to the ratings. The pan fried Chilean seabass is exceptional! Got a side of XO sauce that was not good at all. Ginger lobster was ok but service was good. I'd be back if I'm on that side of town.

v5MpBbbgqk7R_lU5VtCv0w.text: The food is poor, the service is bad... NEVER coming back!!!   First of all, we came to this place because of a recommendation of a friend. Didn't have too much expectation, however it was the worst experience I've ever had in my lifetime.   The food is, first of all not tasty at all (neither the Chinese nor the American at our table likes it).. the bun is definitely brought from the supermarket... and the seafood aren't even fresh which almost makes me throw out... and most importantly, the food is NOT freshly made!!!!! Half of the food that we ordered turns out to be half cool, that's when we realized that the food are made before(or even left over from other table, which I hope it's not).   The service is REALLY BAD!!! They missed some orders, and when we ask for it they just replied in a very bad manner saying that we didn't order it. We then later ask them why the food was cold, again, they replied in a very rude manner saying that they wouldn't precook any food and there's nothing they can do!? Then they recook the food with water... which make the food taste worse...   Then, they even charge a large amount of tip automatically...   Too many other bad experience that we had that I don't want to even mention. Ruined our family day, please avoid coming here!   ,,,,... !!!

y3HP6B9Pi5TIpnS7F_GQFg.text: Maybe because of the all the hype but I expected more. I was told this is the best place in vegas for dim sum and if it's True then dim sum in vegas is seriously lacking...

cfVX1x-IsNcNkvWF4ejdJw.text: Been coming to Ping Pang Pong for over a year now. This is one of my favorite Dim Sum spot to go. The only downside might be the long lines and it's a little pricey. But overall great place to go to.

LolD9J28xCkO5cb5NuRORQ.text: I love the atmosphere, especially everybody that was pushing and serving the food was very nice. All the food was good ...  when it came to the Chinese broccoli I was hoping you guys had it with the oyster sauce, is very plain without it . The fried tofu didn't have much heat nor flavor and it's like eating a sponge burst of oil in your mouth. I just give it a try for the tow dish everything else was good ... the layout of the place has great decor, I would highly recommend bringing a party and people to this place for a great entertainment and food specially service!!! The place was a bit pricey

BNA3IgmWCIENSCB7zDx-lw.text: The food was good but the service needs work... we got there and it was empty but still had to wait... there was 8 people in our party and i had mentioned to the hosts that it was my mom's birthday... i didn't mention that so we could get anything for free but at least decent service... the host acknowledged that she heard me but nothing... we had to keep asking for water... after our order was taken the only time we saw some one was when they brought out our food... we had to go hunt for our check they took forever and we had to get our own takeout containers... being in a Las Vegas hotel and casino you should have at least decent service... plus the servers wasn't nice or friendly at all... by the way someone recommend this place... sad...

A7dSD5LSiYRuhvLMgEupHw.text: Was referred to this place by a friend because I really enjoy dim sum. I'm glad I tried this place, I liked it a lot. Service was good too. Free valet parking (just need to tip) and not too far away from hotel doors, making it easy to navigate to. Would definitely be back again.

BLJ914bXQ6jpwgRGo-lHwA.text: I used to check in this place for dim sum whenever I'm in town. After the recent visit I feel that I'm not a fan anymore.   My favorite dish, BBQ pork pastry, has become so bad recently. The pastry became so thick and lost the nice crispy texture. We also tried fried rice roll, which was supposed to be "very savory" - Meh. Very bland. Other items, such as fried shrimp ball and chicken feet, were still nice to have.  I wonder if they are taking any cost-reduction measures, because I feel there are fewer carts going around. Some items, especially fried dishes, no longer come in carts - they simply have some ladies carrying them around by hand.  Even if the place is not as good as it was, it still worths 3 stars. But given so many good dim sum places popped up in Vegas recently, I decide not to waste my time here.

BhbifWiugoNhNJ0NhoZbeA.text: This is by far The best local chinese food you can ask for in Las Vegas.  from A to Z was the best. Thank you all specially the chef.

ACO25gsI9YtDSVIXDRX75A.text: I thought the food was delicious. The dim sums were some of the best I've ever had. But make sure to go on the days they have the carts. You get more options that way. I think the carts are on the weekends. Make sure you try the roasted crispy chicken in the scallion soy sauce. So simple, and so good.  Now that we moved to the west coast & I've had the chance to try dimsum in many more restaurants, I now realize they have one of the best dimsum I've tried. Everything I have tried here has great texture & all flavorful. The exterior of all the dimsum I have tried here are all delicate & thin as I prefer. Soft & chewy in the inside too. Other dimsum I have tried has been tough & chewy. And really missing the flavor ping pang & another favorite I have in Vegas has. Las Vegas really knows how to do dimsum.   As for service, they can get busy sometimes. But we usually have great service.

XzXUIdNVHG6bL8UtumVDIA.text: This has been my favorite place for Hong-Kong style Chinese food for years! They also have the best dim sum in the city!

vF3AJQDTiaO_uVB3cO6YHw.text: "Sundays are for Dim Sum. While the rest of America goes to church, Sunday School, or NFL games, you can find Chinese people eating Cantonese food."  Eddie Huang  So our friend wanted to grab some dim sum at a place he was profusely gushing about.  I was pretty unimpressed as a Cantonese person and after the meal, he echoed my sentiments.  What's the big deal?  I suppose it's the best dim sum in Las Vegas but places in Arizona have impressed me more.  I can't believe we drove all the way to Gold Coast to try this place!  It may be because we were here for dim sum on a Thursday but the food was pretty cold despite being in steam carts.  We tried a wide variety of dishes and the salt water dumpling, egg tarts, and the chicken feet were the only ones that were particularly good.  Salt water dumpling is always good because they're fried, the egg tart is generous with custard filling, and the chicken feet had a good sauce on them.  Plus, they were really plump!  I did find the roe on the siu mai and other various dumplings to be interesting.  They didn't add much the dish themselves but it was okay.  Service is that of all dim sum places: basic.  They do treat Cantonese and Mandarin speakers a lot better than the English speaking customers. 3.5 stars!

SJoqSQVe9NGi-_CrVpt8-A.text: My mother's friends highly recommended this place, so I took my family and best friend to give it a try.  It took the dim sum cart a really long time to get to our table. The dim sum served on the grill/fried/pastry cart all came out cold... like the eggplant, eggtarts, and this fried dough with minced pork. Very disappointing, especially it was the first time I took my foreign best friend out to try dim sum... bet he didn't have the best impression.  Besides the cold food, the taste of everything else was average to below average... prices are slightly higher than local spots out of the casino.   I will not be returning.

6xtNwzk8YNptF4qINu8OQA.text: Free parking! Don't miss the roasted duck! Black pepper beef is food as well. Again don't miss the roasted duck!

ko6VyTfJ_-I5O1-OVyVTuA.text: This place is a top dim sum place at LV. The food is good. You can't go wrong with most of the stuff here. However, the wait was 1 hours for two people. We came during Holiday season at noon. Come as early as possible don't waste time in line. Service is ok. The place definitely should enlarge the space. Overall, it's a good place to eat but you cannot enjoy the atmosphere and relax.  ,,,

FeDrqpDivBEPRzK8iqvlpw.text: I was looking for a good dim sum joint in Vegas. When I travel, I like to try the dim sum from other places. This place did not disappoint. It's located at The Gold Coast Hotel, all the way in the back. I have to give this place props for the nostalgic Chinese feel to it. Everything from the  tables to the uniforms scream Chinese. It seems so out of place at this hotel. It's as if it's in it's own little bubble.  We got there about 10:30am and there was no wait. The place opens at 10:00am. When we left an hour later, the place was packed. When we first got there, I heard the workers speaking in Cantonese, a good sign. The hostess sat us at a table and gave us one of those stamp cards. Every time we took something from the cart that they pushed by us, they would stamp the card. That's how they total the bill at the end. This is the only dim sum place that I've been to that charged for tea. With that being said, the dim sum here is a good deal compared to Hawaii, where I'm from. All the items were about a dollar cheaper.   We had the black bean spare ribs, chicken feet, shrimp dumplings, stuffed eggplant, and the hot tofu dessert. These are pretty much my staples. I tend to order the same items at dim sum. I have to say the food is excellent. Everything that we ordered was on point. The shrimp in the dumplings was fresh and the wrapper translucent. The chicken feet was plump and huge. The eggplant was stuffed with shrimp paste. My favorite was the hot tofu dessert. It was silky smooth and so yummy with the ginger syrup. It was as good or better than most dim sum places in Hawaii.  As with most dim sum places, you get better service if you speak Cantonese. After the hostess sat us, no carts came around for a while. As soon as I asked for shrimp dumplings in Cantonese, the hostess waved all the carts over. Within 10 seconds, I had all four carts in front of me. My husband was laughing because he knew the drill. This happens at a majority of dim sum places that we go to.

XAyGWNZewhumhcCpI2Yu1Q.text: This is one of the best dim sum spots in Vegas. The food is always good, and has average prices. However, there are several drawbacks to Ping Pang Pong.   The first, is that unless you get there right when it opens, you will have to wait in line. The line can sometimes take 10 minutes, but more often it will take much longer. This can be infuriating at times, because they have two sides to the restaurant and often keep people in line when half the restaurant is still empty. I understand that they don't want half the restaurant unattended by employees, but this place is so small that really shouldn't be a problem.   Second, service is hit or miss. At times, they are attentive and you don't have to wait long to get your food. But at others, you can wait a long time before you get any food, or your drinks refilled. When it's busy, you need to leave your table with your food ticket and basically attack the food servers, since dim sum is brought out on carts. If you don't then you might not get food for a while.   Third, while most things are great here, especially the char siu bao (bbq pork bun) and dessert buns, there are also things which are sub-par. The most disappointing is the lo mai gai (stuffed sticky rice). While it works in a pinch, I don't recommend getting it here.  All in all, this is a good place to come for dim sum, just make sure you arrive early and are ready to attack the servers for food.

i3Vc_nDAvSOHZnTD2dnltA.text: The restaurant looks very nice, except that the service is horrible. Front service has NO SMILE. We ordered to go, and they have no condiments for take out food. Very reluctant to attend their customers. In China, service is much better. What us wrong with the Chinese in the US? We will never ever come back here

5VbsOmzgA13kfktVzsvzpQ.text: The best dim sum spot in Las Vegas. Food tastes fresh, lots of different items and its a good size place which can get crowded.

-gZrvg9DcSnG8O6y6M7Nmg.text: Purposely made a trip here because of all the reviews and "best Chinese food" title this place has.  Be aware that this restaurant is located within the Gold Coast hotel. The place doesn't have walls blocking the smoke coming from the casino and I didn't appreciate inhaling smoke while eating. I asked if I can be moved to a more inner location in my desperate attempt to get away from the smoke but the lady said there isn't anywhere she could move me even though I clearly saw many empty tables. Food was subpar but perhaps that's because I was hyped up by previous reviews. But this place gets two stars for fast service and the price.

pJqPrYFpEdAAml-4khE7Ag.text: The food is good, but the services is bad . we asked have another glass of water with lemon, but they give us tap water taste horrible. After we eat were still talking with our friends but we feel we wants us to leave right Away. Pls improve your services.

HfPPrR2e2I4Uou_nh0cDUg.text: Hands down the worst shit hole in Las Vegas for Chinese food.. I waited over an hour and 20 minutes for a takeout order they said would take 20 minutes ..Wong Tong soup and combination fried rice.. worst service and people in Vegas

4xr7pS6LCD5LXtmlhU9Weg.text: I have come to realize that getting amazing food in Vegas is like seeing a unicorn. It just doesn't exist. LV just seems to enjoy buffet style food and fast food joints. Places with casinos just seem to operate under that model.  However, this place comes pretty close as close can get with being authentic Chinese food. Their dim sum dishes are pretty close to the same ones served in NYC. The selection of food on the non-dim sum menu is made fresh in the kitchen and very tasty - packed with flavor. If one is having a craving for real good Chinese food - check this place out. Hopefully, one comes on a good day when there isn't a long line. I got the sauteed pork chops and their house special lo mein. Sooooo yummy!  On a side note, the woman sitting in the table next to me with 3 kids was a cowgirl redneck and thought this placed served 4 piece chicken wings and pork friend rice. She left super fast after the waitress served her bread and water and she realized dishes on the menu was not food she was accustomed to. Some people can be so uncultured and classless!

k4ARn2nCRuqpnRrgE87UeA.text: So good and worth the wait! If you're in Vegas looking for some dim sum this is the place to go!

s9n4DwNY6KXi5x519N_1oA.text: Stopped in for a late dinner after a day of poker at the Rio. Easy walk across the street. Was quickly sat, drink ordered and after a quick review of their extensive menu, I opted for dishes I am familiar with:  war wonton soup and Singapore Rice noodles. I was not feeling adventurous to try frog legs or the live eel dish and was a little put off that they offer shark fin soup. Service was far and friendly, my ice tea never ran dry. Place was clean, well lit and not too noisy. But then it was 11:20pm.   Soup was delicious with plenty of shrimp, chicken white meat, BBQ pork and pork filled wontons. Throw in some greens, scallions, mushrooms and it is a shareable portion. He second dish was Singapore Rice noodles. Again, plenty of meat and it arrived steaming hot. I added some red chilli paste as I found the curry spicing a little lighter than my preference. It too was delicious.   Overall, 4 stars and a definite recommend to my friends, family and fellow Yelpers. Also, I found it to be a good value considering it is in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. War won ton soup was delicious and not too salty. Plenty of meats, wontons, veggies.
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Singapore Rice Noodles were slamming. Curry was light so I suggest adding red chili paste to spice it up

XKadyA2QbdbWA2XN9LQUkg.text: Everything I've eaten there has been absolutely wonderful! When my family comes to visit we made sure to try to hit this place up every single time. The food will not disappoint you but the service though they are attentive they can be quite rude and I mean quite rude!

i0k-NC3MjPLEcM_ilNpidw.text: My friend made a to-go order for me to pick up on the way home one late night. We got a couple different things. I got some boba milk tea and pork buns, he got some soups and orange chicken. He place the order to be ready at 12:20 or so. I left work and went to go pick it up. I walked up to the stand and told them I had a pick up order. They asked me for an order number, which I thought was odd. I told them I didn't have the number but it was his phone number/this name. They said they needed the order number or they couldn't give me the order. I tried to call my friend for 5 minutes but he was asleep and didn't answer. They saw me struggling and asked what I ordered. I told them and they picked up the order right behind them and verified the phone number I originally gave them... It would have been nice for them to take that originally. I wanted out with my order. By the time I got home the ice in the boba was melted but everything we ordered was really good. It wasn't their fault I didn't have the order number but they could have just checked the phone number that was on the receipt. Anyways, pork buns were bomb and the orange chicken was delicious!! I'll remember to get the order number for next time.

6W2NH8BYdB2Pmx8Cag-ohw.text: Have been very unimpressed with both the food quality as well as the rapdily declining service at Ping Pang Pong over the past 6 months or so. New floor management is certainly to blame, yet the front line staff is also to blame. The areas where service is falling short: Failure to greet customers in a timely fashion 2. Lack of a genuine greeting  3. Rushed order-taking. 4. Failure to touch the table more than once per dining experiece (cover). Management (on the floor) has not properly addressed these issues & is failing to ensuring any reasonable level of service. I recently noticed 2 or 3 other guests laughing in the restaurant while dining alone. After speaking with a couple of them, I later learned through our conversation that they were loyal customers for many years, but that the service levels are now "laughable". This, I am not alone in this review....I am also not hesitant to make it. Ping Pang Pong will be given one final chance to remedy this poor situation. Two stars will become 1 star if the next experience mirrors this one. There are too many other options out there.....

ku-tU7ubXEoTY8jLblvlsw.text: Quick run through review...  Dim sum in Vegas?  Okay!!! :D   This restaurant is off the strip at the Gold Coast Casino.  The restaurant itself is on the actual casino floor with kind of limited seating so expect to wait unless you're lucky.    Overall the dim sum is pretty standard when it comes to dim sum, couldn't complain in the taste or MSG overdose afterwards.  I just don't remember if they had my favorite chili paste Sambal Oelek there or not, they may might have had the regular chili oil, which IMO is not the freaking same!  (So if any Asian restaurant owners/managers are reading this please read carefully....Sambal Oelek chili paste can not be substituted with chili oil or any other brand!  Damnamit.)    Although....one thing that I did enjoy over here specifically was their jellyfish during dim sum hours.  Idk, either the places I go to don't offer jellyfish at dim sum or I just barely missed the very last portion to some lucky sonofabitch.  :/  Other than the jellyfish, their name 'Ping Pang Pong' and that its in Vegas... nothing really stands out to me as I can have the same at any one of the numerous dim sum restaurants in Cali.  Nice place to check out nonetheless if you suddenly have a craving attack for dim sum and the 'Asian' foods at the buffets aren't satiating that craving.

tlOT9U71SRQTUipS8qMqjw.text: Stay away from this place.  Ordered the Chinese broccoli and there was two caterpillars in the veggie.  Told the manager/owner about it and he asked me, " What do you want me to do about it? Sometimes veggies have caterpillars and it's normal. " I was stunned that he can even say that.  How about wash your veggies properly.  I asked for his name and the staff will not say.  We paid and left.  Called Gold Coast to file a complaint and they can't do anything about it because they are independently owned.  If I could... I would rate Ping Pang Pong a negative 10 stars.

h7-dwp-axZv33labA1sBIA.text: I wondered about a casino Dimsum, but look no further.  Gold Coast is an older hotel, but clean and plenty of parking.   I hate the name but this place is one of the top DimSum in Vegas.   Inexpensive and quick service.

E1gccHyVqyYM3Ka5ncuYfA.text: This restaurant is located in The Gold Coast Hotel Casino and turned out to be our favorite.  With the sad (but finally improving) state of Chinese food in SW Florida we needed to get our fill and ate here three times.  Things got off to a shaky start.  Four of us ordered; Seafood Crispy Noodles ($10.95), Tea Duck, (half $12.95) Beef Lo Mein ($9.95) and Ma Po Tofu ($7.95).  It was a Saturday night and the place was busy but our order was taken promptly.  Interestingly after a reasonable wait we inquired about our food and it miraculously started to arrive, albeit one dish at a time making it seem like the order was never entered.    The duck was cooked to a crispy goodness but was served without any dipping sauces - Hoisin was brought on request.   The two noodle dishes were large portions with the seafood noodle including ample pieces of fish, Scallops, Squid.  The fourth dish Tofu was a complete no-show with a different server offering to get it but advising the "kitchen is slammed", we declined and the check was adjusted accordingly.  Lunch here is Dim Sum served from a parade of steaming carts.  We tried some old favorites and few new things.  All was fresh and presented with care.  We tried a favorite of many Asians; Chicken Feet and now realize this is an acquired taste, however the fried rice served with it was the absolute best we ever had.  So that's how fried rice should taste!  We ate our fill and had many items with the bill for two at just $30.00.  If you've never had a traditional Dim Sum meal this is definitely the place.  One more dinner visit included our all time favorite Beef Rice Flat Noodles ($9.95) also known as Chow Fun served "wet".  The beef was tender and the noodles just delicious coated in the light flavorful gravy.  This dish included a few large pieces of perfectly cooked Gai Lan.  With this we had Orange Beef ($9.95) cooked just slightly crisp with an outstanding flavor.  We stuffed ourselves to help prolong the memory.  They claim to be Las Vegas' "best" Chinese restaurant and the fact that on each visit we were just about the only non-Asians there would seem to prove them right.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

jR6os_cgngeJP2_uFr0cRQ.text: Two friends and I dined at Ping Pang Pong this week for dinner, and our expectations could not have been higher. I lived in China briefly and one of my accompanying friends is from the Philippines and her mother makes incredible Asian cuisine. So, when we heard that PPP was one of the most authentic and well-received Chinese restaurants in America, we couldn't wait to try it.  Immediately, I was pleased with our server, who noticed we were ordering things without meat and asked if we were vegetarians. We said yes, and she informed us that many of the items were cooked with chicken broth, but said she'd ensure it wasn't used in our dishes. Unfortunately, we concluded that the chicken broth must be Ping Pang Pong's top secret ingredient, because we were rather disappointed in our food! It pains me to say I've had better tasting meals at Panda Express.  Here's what we ordered and my thoughts on it: -Wrinkled Green Beans: Bland, but nothing a little extra hot sauce couldn't fix.  -Ma Po Tofu: Good seasoning but we would have preferred a firmer tofu over the squishy one. -Sauteed Lotus Root: The fact it was described as "pungent" on the menu should have been a red flag. It was too crunchy and the taste of vinegar was over-whelming. -Shanghai Noodles: We got it without the pork, and it was basically oily ramen. Big portions a plus, though. -Rice: Dried out and hard!   -Iced Chrysanthemum tea: It was akin to drinking potted plant water. -Fresh Coconut Juice: It was on the menu, but apparently not available. I hate it when that happens.  Ultimately, I was disappointed with Ping Pang Pong and don't plan on returning. Another patron might have better luck ordering Dim Sum or a meat dish, as apparently both have been praised. However, I'll stick to other establishments/fly to China the next time I want authentic noodles/have my friend's mom cook for me! :D

CJePxKVy8rBx4xfONZ_q0Q.text: Hidden gem inside the casino - dim sum is soooo good!

Vr5OH_8vL_yWCvfPbhPROw.text: I have discovered P3 since 2013.  I visit evey 4th of July week up to 2016.  Still it is the best dimsum place!    I had dim sum very much every where. By far this place was the best.  Although don't expect the best service.  It seems like most Chinese restaurant service is not that great.  I would visit again but I will only tip them based on service!

LugFF7KqqNNYAbB1wdWekQ.text: Best Dim Sum around period. I'm heading back tomorrow for my second visit on a weeklong vacation. The bbq pork dumplings are awesome here as is most everything. Go hungry and be prepared to eat a lot. The carts of wonderful Chinese food just keep coming.

hZ9gcxZhSGNgn6GXFNdnBw.text: My family doesn't really like to go out to Chinese restaurants very often since my dad was once a Chinese chef and knows how to cook dishes very well himself. When we do go out or get take-out however, it's always from 'Ping Pang Pong' (still don't understand the logic of this name choice..). He always raves how this is a really good Chinese restaurant and they cook their dishes with all the right ingredients and proportions. The pricing is very suitable too. You would assume being inside a casino, they would charge more than the actual dish is worth, but the price range is about $6-8 for a good portion of food per dish.   My dad would be the one to know all the technical stuff with what is a good quality Chinese dish and bad quality. The reason why I know this restaurant really lives up to the 'Best Chinese Restaurant' awards plastered around the entrance is because the traffic that I have seen come in and out of this restaurant, and the number of to-go orders that are bunched up on their large counter space everytime I am here. It's ridiculous! We've had to wait a good 45 minutes for our to-go order (3 dishes) to come out, so my advice is if you're looking for some take-out.. make sure you order way ahead of time of when you expect to actually eat.  Had dimsum the other day and they don't have a wide variety of options but for what they do have, it's superb quality in my opinion! Really loved their turnip cake. Best I've ever had!   4 instead of 5 stars is just because I wish their floor space was a little larger and had more selection of dimsum items, but as for their quality of food.. 5 stars for sure.

2rxTo0njI6qs1HHlYmcDzQ.text: We came here a few times. Their food is not bad. But service is always bad. We sat in our table for 20 minutes and waited for the waitress to come order. No one eve come. I had to go to cashier and ordered there. Nothing but bad service.

Gj3d5991k16gHwjaxkNSxg.text: First time here and I'm so impressed! Not only is it open late but the food is actually amazing. The honey walnut prawn and fried rice was the best. Our server was a bit negligent but the busser named Juan saved the day. He was very consistent and polite. He was the reason i didnt walk out and settle eating TGIFridays. Thank you juan!!!!! Give that man a god damn raise!!!!!

_rFkIhYv9jDjxbFEeLu7Ug.text: Cantonese food tends to be salty. This one is not so much. Good Chinese food, even for the Chinese. Pretty quick service. They serve different style of food, even though most severs seem to be fromSouthern China. I did not like the smell of cigarettes.

iUzGQhdTbfF7K0ypXQVmAQ.text: I love their dim sum! So far it's my favorite place in town for it. I'm a shrimp fan and they have so many options for me. The coconut buns and sesame balls are delicious. This is a place that any dim sum fan should try at least once.  I haven't tried their regular menu items, but I've heard great things. I intend on checking this place out for dinner so I can see for myself.

2iuSvWPGgFgb9ldvcBiDiA.text: They've got some very tasty dim sum on their menu and a few that isn't anything special.  Pork buns and pork shui Mai is delicious!  I've got to say that the only thing that left a bad taste in my mouth was the HORRIBLE service!  Doesn't matter, over the phone or in person, they are rude.  I'll definitely try out other dim sum places before I come back and spend my money at this restaurant.

CDbtbaNIc3oVaEzede6pmg.text: The best Chinese food in Las Vegas enough said!

upWqBxC1a1ld4hAam3ccEQ.text: PLEASE PROCEED WITH CAUTION!! The staff here are crazy RUDE and they even lied about what they were still serving. They told us they were out of dishes but then served the same dishes to another table behind us. We had to fight for our food and called the manager since everyone was ignoring us. Manager there is great btw! Only reason this place had 2 stars. Once we called him, we finally had better service. Food here gets a C- as far as quality of Dim Sum. Dumpling and bun exterior a little hard and didn't taste fresh. Listen, bottom line is in Vegas there are a lot better places to spend your money than Ping.

qyZCjiTsyiixhJcIsblrcA.text: We were there for lunch on 10-31-13 and tried some dim sum and some dishes off the menu.   Dim sum - don't remember everything but the shrimp balls and the shrimp donut with noodle were great as was the pot stickers and coconut buns.  Menu - salt and pepper pork chops, salt and pepper shrimp, beef rice noodles and Kung pow chicken were are excellent. Our favorite were the pork chops.  This was our first attempt at ordering dim sum so we were a bit lost however they tried their best to explain.

BbzNjbwcCvZVpzN5uKMDkg.text: We just landed and we don't know where to get some Chinese food. So we found this dim sum place inside Gold Coast Casino. The dim sum was not good at all, but of course you can't expect much from a dim sum restaurant inside a casino. So we just order the normal plates of dim sum like har gow, siu mai, cheung fun, crab claws, calamari, etc. They were not good and they don't care, because people keep flocking in to eat them. The price was okay, but food sucks.

guplpAUFfmtmN4vIj4sA0A.text: The food was a bit Americanize to my liking, i had better authentic Chinese food at KJ's kitchen

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

YODdgpZBPXbCQvM_9rAwZQ.text: OKAY I admit it...for the longest time we'd make fun of the huge Ping Pang Pong sign on our way into the Rio. However one of our friends heard that the joint was actually decent so we decided to check it out.  I regret the fact that we went at 11...we waited what seemed like forever to get in, and by the time we sat down to order they were already starting to run out of stuff. (after all...i'm a gaijin...what's a yum cha trip without the char siu bao???)  The noodles may have been my favorite part of our meal. I was glad we were able to find some sesame balls on the mango pudding cart (after the nearly empty baked goods cart kept taunting us with each trip around the joint). Everything was pretty standard, no surprises here. Service was pretty decent, they were good about refilling our water and tea. After escaping with a $60/3 people tab, we left full and content.

UzuhAetfI739hcOsoabklw.text: Great authentic food, always comes fast and fresh. If you are only accustomed to americanised Asian food then this is not your place.  I love coming here.

YKLUyaroNtkopxcDDdLK9A.text: It's always been a habit of mine to compare Asian food in Sin City with the City of Angels.  There's little to say about the Asian restaurants in Vegas (compared to the San Gabriel Valley), but this place hit the spot, especially since I was bored of having French/Italian food.  I've visited this place for dim sum about 3 - 4 times now and the food has ALWAYS been consistent.  You get the typical har gow, siu mai, chicken feet, and steamed buns.  What you DON'T get is stuff like shark fin soup or the more "expensive" type dim sum.  The only item I did not enjoy very much is the shen zen bao (pan-friend pork buns)...no juicy orgasmic flavors there.  The bills usually averaged about $50 - $60 for 2-3 ppl consisting of approximately 12 - 14 dishes.  A little more expensive than the Cali dim sum places, but it is Vegas, ya know.  Sure, the name of the restaurant sounds racist, but if you owned a jam-packed restaurant like that, so what?  And...the fact this small joint is in a casino...even betta!!  Try out PPP and try it for yourself!

JupiFQpkFvHuM1q3OBxOig.text: Great prices, very generous portions, fresh and flavorful, what else is their to say

gMqG-I6zQt_9donIAoa2hQ.text: We had lunch here yesterday.  The service and food was great.  Very authentic Cantonese food.  I didn't expect a good dim sum restaurant inside a Las Vegas casino.  It is a gem despite its undignified name.  Apparently it is not a hidden gem either because there was a long line outside the restaurant before noon.  Don't empty your wallet while waiting in a field of slot machines, save some to pay for the lunch.  Its Chinese name is Jin Yuan Bao (lit. gold ingots) which is a much better name especially to those high rollers in Vegas.  It is actually much better than the dim sum restaurant in Las Vegas Chinatown on Spring Mountain Road.

l9SMsufUrpK0UFmYMpp8rw.text: Where: The Gold Coast Casino. What: Amazing Chinese food!!!  Yes, four stars given!!!   I've eaten at some really great Chinese restaurants in my time. All over the San Gabriel Valley, OC, Los Angeles, San Francisco, etc, etc.   This place amazed me! There is TRULY great Chinese food in Vegas, and Dim Sum as well!    Located in the Gold Coast, this place was filled with Asians devouring Dim Sum for breakfast.    Siu Mai. Har Gow. Bean Curd rolls. Fried Taro thing. Beef Meat Ball.  Other misc. Dim Sum.  Lop Chong Fried Rice.  Low Mein.   All frickin amazing. I'd put this place up against some of the places in the So. Cal/No. Cal area.    Definitely worth a try!!!

xIXIQa7s2vYTRXjXXJnuqw.text: dim sum yay!   Haven't had anything from the regular menu here but the dim sum lunch was just like back home in the bay area!  $30 for 2 people, and we were stuffed, the carts just kept on coming! **it gets a little crowded and it's in the middle of the casino, but if it's cheap and the food is good...I'm all for it and besides...it's Vegas baby!!

wpkOFJQVzP2K9IavpbDMHA.text: Outstanding Cantonese fare, whether dim sum or dinner. We live in the San Francisco area so were happy to find comparable quality to what we are used to here in the desert.  Probably the best roast duck I've had in years: not as fatty and more meaty than a True Peking Duck but delicious nevertheless.  Both HK and Macau style egg tarts for daan taat freaks.   Other dim sum very typical but well done.  A variety of noodle and rice dishes and wonderful claypots like the scallop and greens pot. BTW they also have a noodle house at this same Casino so you can try other dishes including Hot Pot.  Only small issue is the seating: too many large tables go partly occupied. In Asia, a large table would be seated with two or even three parties so you don't waste a ten seat table on just three people

tZ83nF0e7ZxKIzhE19wQTA.text: I've never been a fan of eating dim sum but I was quite impressed with the dim sum here.  If you need a dim sum fix in Vegas, this is the place to go.  My favorites are the white tripe dish and the fried chicken wings.  I also really liked the bbq pork fried rice and shrimp dumplings.  I will definitely be back the next time I'm in town.

xadQ7oNyxdtFlLrGc4bynw.text: Went on a weekday so that's most likely why i'm giving it 3 stars. On weekends when you get the crowds you're gonna wanna bring your A game week days are meh and the food was slightly above meh  Haven't tried anything here that made me think ZOMGBBQPWNAGE. Of all the things we ordered the only thing i can call an Epic Fail were the deep fried shrimp balls with crab claw it was very bland and tasteless even for a deep fried dish.  The steamed buns are fresh and very soft and hot but the filling was bland and tasteless if it wasn't for the color i wouldn't have known it was suppose to be Chinese bbq pork.  I will definitely come back on a weekend to see what their A team can offer but for now it's a step above the other place i said was epic garbage

emxAr2biQsDXs7fxfqXG9g.text: I enjoy the authentic food, but difficult understanding what anybody is saying. when the ladies  with the dim sum carts are rolling by i point at the dish that looks familiar and then they mark my sheet of paper. Its fun and I love it!

TGXsyTCOB-fEiT0D5Y-Bnw.text: Dim sum here is pretty good for a Vegas joint. However, I did not like the service! When my friend and I first got here (around 1130), we had to wait about 10-15 min before we could get some tea or even water to drink! It wasn't even that busy yet, and we were seated right away! Usually, at many dim sum places, it is automatic to get tea or water right away! Also, the carts did not come to our side very often, so we had to make sure to get plenty of things before we started really eating! (Especially the dessert cart! Geez! That one took forever to come by!).  The place is also pretty small. We can barely get into or out of our seats, since they were so close together (so I just stayed in mine the whole time without moving it heheh!).   The only thing that I tried here that was not as common as other dim sum places was their soft tofu dessert with sugar/ginger syrup. It tasted like a Filipino dessert called Ta-ho (except Ta-ho is sweeter and not ginger-tasting). That was pretty good. They also had a seaweed salad, (which looked very good but didn't come until we were waiting for our check), and we couldn't try it! Other than those two, just your typical dim sum place with a limited quantity of items!  I probably would not go back here, especially if I ever have to wait! Geez...wait for a table...and then WAIT for a drink...and then WAIT for the dim sum...and even WAIT for our check/to go boxes!   Unless you're with a big party, this place would probably be decent to have dim sum. Be ready to FLAG those cart people! Expect a wait on the weekends starting around 12 (We went on a Sunday).   Btw, the price for most of the dim sum is about $3 a piece, so it could add up if you want to try lots of things...(They also charge for tea!)

PrhkZ9SEFuRAoQr4akCVkA.text: The best dim sum ever in LV that we ever tasted.  If you stay at the strip like we did, you have to drive a bit.  It's close to the china town.   ANyway, a friend of mine said that this place is good.  So, we gave it a try.  We noticed their giant billboards all over the place.  Anyway, we got there. Although, it wasn't full house, they were quite busy.  We waited for a few minutes after we got our tables to be approached by the ladies with the dim sum carts.  We ordered quite a lot. As 2 giant piggies, we finished everything.  :) The conclusion is good food, price is not bad. The only thing that keeps me from giving 5 stars is the service.  There was totally none.  We'll probably come back here just to grab quick dim sum.

qwa3laRyMzBlP28yjkXJMA.text: One might think, with a wacky name and being located in a casino, that Ping Pang Pong isn't going to be any good.  However, it's definitely one of the better places in town (and my favorite) for dim sum.  The restaurant is little bit small, so expect a bit of a wait on crowded days.  If you don't see a dish that you want being carted around, you can ask and they will generally make it for you.  Prices are a little bit more expensive than the other places in town, but not that much (maybe 50 cents to a dollar more per dish).  Also, I saw Johnny Chan eating here once.  If Ping Pang Pong is good enough for Johnny Chan, it's good enough for me, and probably you, too!

ZegfO8tliFAXl-sklVHiIw.text: First time having dim sum in Vegas and it made me feel like the east coast a little.  Food was fast and fresh, service was great and the flavor was amazing.  Ten plates of food came out to a little over $30 and filled up two people.  Great Dim Sum!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Char Siu Bao, steamed not baked
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken feet :p
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Stuffed Crab Claw Recipe (Yeung Hai Kim)

qA5utK_Utkf8I9t08LjhqA.text: I recently tried Ping Pang Pong and I must say it's my least favorite dim sum place in Vegas.  It barely qualifies as dim sum since the dining area is tiny, the only view is of slot machines, there are so few clients since it's so small that the food selection is nearly nil!!  Some of the food is brought on trays since there's barely room for the carts.  I took my wife and in-laws who were born and raised in mainland China and they agree it's nothing special compared to Orchid Gardens although they did like the chicken feet and congee they ate.  I couldn't come up with enough dishes to even eat so we bailed out after a couple of dishes and ate at the buffet instead!!  My wife commented that even the hot sauce was the cheap kind.  None of my favorite "ribs" and no Chinese broccoli in sight.  Prices were nothing special and it had zero atmosphere.  All this in spite of the fact that we know one of the servers.  I hate to say it but the service was also marginal.  As an example of my dim sum credentials we checked out two dim sum spots in San Francisco the week before.  How about dim sum for four people including duck for all of $12.50?  This was at the Oriental Tea House in San Leandro.  Great place and not just because the food was cheap.  Go to Orchid Gardens for dim sum.  Real atmosphere, great food selection and even friendly service!

MNwgIvtB6AHLfpI3cByqBg.text: There is usually a long wait, so my boyfriend and I decided to go early.  There wasn't that much of a selection and it took about an hour after opening for food to really come out.  Once it did service was still slow.  Their lo mei gei was made with long grain rice, which I did not like.  Their food was fresh and good quality, but was lacking in taste.  Orchid Garden over Ping Pang Pong.

UiZ2-Zq1SqZAC5HnfNNZFA.text: Staying at the Gold Coast I tried this place the first day I arrived. The prices were reasonable and the good yelp reviews I researched turned me on to eating here. I ordered this white rice mixed in with pieces of of sausage and eggs. It was sweet, oily and a bit salty BUT delicious! I never have had a rice mix like this in my life.  I took my leftovers to go even though I had no refrigerator in my room. Whateva! I ate it cold after a night of partying in vegas and it was still soooo delich!

XYnat03KERjWQPjcwKmmDQ.text: i really hope i came here on a bad day. i was so excited to try their dim sum after reading these reviews but i was completely disappointed.   i came here around noon to eat. it wasn't busy but like Teri i was happy to see mostly asian families eating here.. a good sign right? immediately after being seated our drinks were ordered and our first cart came around. picked the usual shrimp dumplings and pork dumplings. we didnt have time to try it because all the other carts were on their way around. hmm.. potstickers.. beef with noodle.. fried shrimp ball  thing.. lol.. i tried the pork dumpling first. it was tasty but cold.. the shrimp dumpling was also cold and the outer rice layer was hard. definitely  old. the fried shrimp ball was oddly sweet. it tasted like they threw in cake batter into the batter. the potstickers were okay.. a little chewy.. the only thing that came out hot was the beef with noodle. which is my favorite. so i was pleased about that.   this was my bf's first time eating dim sum and i apologized because this was not the experience i wanted him to have. i know a lot of people don't like cathay house but this visit to ping pang pong left me wondering how this place could be better. maybe i came at the wrong time? i hope so..

RY49IGLYEJrRq-5wDdURlA.text: Like many others, we opted for PPP on a random late Vegas night.  The food was alright (went for the veggie noodles) and although better than some other places I've tried, it really didn't hit the spot for me.  Plus, we came on a kind of busy night...? It took quite a while to get seated even though it wasn't too busy looking and a bunch of empty tables available.  Rough night for them?  Maybe.  Food was enticing enough to maybe return for a 2nd round.. hopefully my experience is better next time.

Whub-0UZlzJrEjzTLfPaFg.text: Very good food. Nice waitress. Reasonable price.

-mnTfqz3lTvosF-SDf8aNw.text: Best dim sum place I've ever had....eat there every time were in Vegas...

ImKyeEJzBeN4wmVeXhANKQ.text: Best dim sum in town!!! Get there early, lines get long. Service remains awful :(

CH8_yGfHu-qUxUbnpRtO9w.text: While the name is kind of unfortunate and makes the place seem more tourist-y than it actually is, the restaurant was great.  We ate here because we had come to Gold Coast to eat at the Noodle Exchange and they were about to close so we felt bad going in to eat.   I had a curried noodle dish, and my girlfriend had kung pao chicken.  Both dishes were fantastic.  The service was really good and portions were large.  My only complaint is that if you don't like seafood/fish/shrimp, your menu choices are fairly limited.

WeUL9JkuR-dTSmzN6ZCcbw.text: The dim sum is mediocre but the prices were moderate.. We were seated right away but after that there was no customer service whatsoever.. We had to ask multiple times for someone to bring us water and tea, something that is usually done right away without being requested.. The ladies that walk around with push carts kept asking if we wanted anything but how are we supposed to eat when the basics haven't been covered yet? I have never received such lack luster service from a dim sum restaurant.. I would probably return again if they improved their waitstaff but the likelihood of that is not likely.. Sorry but you'll just have to try again, because for now you fail..

fzZGgAO3REOTWoW-5TjE-g.text: Although the place is small, the dim sum is pretty good to me. They have a good selection for dessert. Not much of the regular dishes, but the taste was pretty good.

LtCtUdlulkucqcPdEnVQ8w.text: While in vegas, our family friend who lives there recommended Ping Pang Pong in the Gold Coast Hotel and Casino since we were craving dimsum.  It was solid and pretty consistent for Dimsum. Fresh, the restaurant staff spoke Cantonese (which is the kind of Chinese that dimsum comes from). I give it a 4 because the dimsum is what I would expect out of a decent dimsum, but not AMAZING. For being in a hotel/casino, it's pretty good as well. Dimsum is usually either good or really bad. LOL It's tough to make it bad, but it happens quite a bit.  Whatever chinatown you go to, usually the crowded dimsum places are the best and having to wait in a line in vegas for dimsum meant Ping Pang Pong was decent and it was.  I would say it's a little bit above average.    Also...I'd have to say...dimsum and blackjack is quite a kool combination ya? lol. Not to mention the sports betting section being right around the corner =P The hilarious chinese restaurant name is funny too =D

OgPDzAZSnYoQpKDdkVKSxA.text: I just went to Ping Pang Pong with my family and we sat down for eight minutes before they even asked if we wanted a drink when we got the drinks we waited another five minutes before we were got anything to eat we only got one thing and it was cold it didn't even taste good at all all of the stem carts would go to all of the other tables but miss our table what kind of service is that???  I have eaten dim sum in California, Hawaii, and in here in Vegas that were cheaper and way better

MD3JUes6qHhtXI24C2NDOg.text: Definitely good but not great.  If your looking for a safe bet at the Gold Coast this is definitely a good choice.

P3-T8vMpfinYJaoPjX2llw.text: Pros:  Best Dim Sum in Vegas! Hands-down. Their traditional Chinese entrees are very authentic too.  Cons: Waiting time. Price

RnjTZFlNw9opaMvzJZxvbQ.text: Inconveniently located about as far away from the parking at Goldcoast as you can get - this restaurant is great if you want to go to a dodgy casino and overpay for just-alright Chinese food. The bill came to $90 for 4 people and no one was all that impressed.  Don't believe their signs that this is the best Chinese food in Las Vegas.  It isn't.  Make sure to check out the menu on Goldcoast's website that they haven't updated since 2006 so your guests can be disappointed that they no longer have Oxtail soup.

kAAMaLN4qVkuZFnj_CTdzw.text: Good chinese food in the middle of the dessert. Didn't see the dim sum.

gPLj5D7IY9fdyulr1NfNqg.text: had an opportunity to have lunch at ping pang pong and i was blown away. the dim sum was so good, the dumplings were fresh and so flavorful. the chicken feet, the pork and shrimp dumplings. highly recommended to everyone.

azE0-lsesVqyBLxWP7U53g.text: The BBQ pork buns were decent. The Thousand Year Old Egg and shredded pork porridge wasn't bad. Everything else we tried was a miss.  Food-wise, this place is no better or no worse than say, Chang, Orchid Garden, Cathay House...etc. (Actually, Cathay House can be much better on the right day with the right server but that is another review for another day.)  Limited Dim-sum selection and the actual square-footage is quite small.  Not too shabby for a Casino Dim-sum restaurant.

xqJaggRDU3xZswhL_Oa4zg.text: I was worried about having to make a long time after reading other reviews, but luckily for us, we only had to wait about 20 minutes before getting seated.  It does help to only have a party of 2!    They had every one of my favorite dim sum dishes (turnip cake, tripe, bbq pork rice noodles, lobster claws) and even some new dishes too.  The quality of the dim sum was pretty good, not the best but better than a lot of places in Orange county.    The prices were decent too, i think it ranged from $2-6 a dish.  We stuffed ourselves for $30.

1e4POaKnGHd-CMBou-6EuQ.text: Disappointed that they do not have Xiao Long Bao... though it was mentioned on yelp that they do.

Jq87oIaE4FTe_bAfVd6zlw.text: I think this is the most authentic Cantonese Dim Sum restaurant inside a Las Vegas Casino and Hotel.  Dim Sum 10am to 3pm  Price:  Fair Food:  Overall is good *Shrimp Ball - Good *Chicken Feet - Below Average because it is not well done enough *Chicken with mushroom over rice in a bamboo container - Not good (There were very little chicken on top of the bamboo container and it tasted frozen and stalled.  The rice is too dry.)  Don't order this dish. *Lau Sa Bau (Sweet bun with yellow filling) - Bad.  The bun part is fine but the filling is awful.  The filling should be in bright yellow color and a light sweet taste to it.  When I bit into it, it appeared in this orange color and the taste is funny.  So, don't order this either. *Steamed Spare Ribs - Ok and very oily and fatty. Service:  Excellent Environment:  Comfortable  I will check my parents into this hotel next time for it's Asian themed and catering services.  My parents will love the convenient of this hotel and restaurant.

3TxfA_tN0AxPzQq-FiKc1g.text: SOOOO DELISH! I know, I am white so I am obviously not a Dim Sum afficianado however, my aunt (who is Chinese) is and this is where she takes us for dim sum in Vegas. Thank goodness because sometimes it is hard to understand the servers and vice versa. It has to be good if Chinese people eat there in my humble opinion! And there is almost always a line. The food is AMAZING, very fresh and plenty of it, in fact, you will probably overeat. My favorite are the Cha Siu Baos (there are 2 similar versions, one in a sweet white bun and the other in a darker, flakier, triangle shaped bun with sesame seeds) Both are outta this world! Highly reccomend!

OzPalLqtKo0w-7MxnUUqnw.text: Restaurant is located at the Gold Coast Casino.  Ate here for the 1st time last year for my birthday dinner before heading out to the clubs (not a good idea btw esp when you have lots of alcohol to drink after eating this type of food if you catch my drift. lol!). The closest I've eaten authentic chinese food since I been in Vegas.  I still have yet to try the ones at chinatown unfortunately.  Chinese food is actually one of my favorite ethnic foods & this was ok. Again, I still have yet to try other chinese food places.  Just as long it's not like a Panda's (which I have no problem with.  Just too americanized for me.) lol. Anyways, we had a few dishes during my birthday dinner but I don't remember all the names.  The walnut prawn is very good. A little on the creamy side but still good.  Huge prawns! Peking duck was as it should taste.  =) The ma po tofu was good.  A lil spicy but not too spicy.  The fried rice we had I believe was the pineapple seafood one.  Yum.... Ate here a second time this yr after a concert & tried the black pepper beef medallions.  Very good as well.  Service on both times i went here were a little slow.  Even when filling up on drinks.  At least it was clean! haha! =) I would go back again.  Next time I have to try the dim sum.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Walnut prawns, combination fried rice &amp; Mongolian beef

BxWmOIg7Lamyut_btS4NiA.text: Ping pang pong.  Well lets get some facts straight.  It's in Gold Coast.  No one expects a 5 star steak from a place like that,  It's chinese and it's better than panda express.  I had some Orange beef and man that stuff was good.  It was like a glaze rather than a sauce on it.  Made it pretty delicious.  Am i gonna go out of my way for it ? no. but if i go bowling there sometime then sure why not.

Li6Epshuj9JTX-K_QFrUDQ.text: There isn't really any place for dimsum right on Las Vegas Blvd, so if you're craving some dimsum, this place isn't too bad of a choice.  PPP goes oldschool with their dimsum carts, featuring congee or bean curd dishes.  I really enjoyed their char siu rice rolls, which had large pieces of bbq pork in them.  I thought their Siu Mai was just average, they were pretty small actually.  But overall, the dimsum was good.  We didn't receive great service here, the dimsum carts came but the rest of the employees ignored us when we needed some plum sauce or water.  But I wasn't too surprised, if you want the authentic Chinese restaurant experience, you have to expect the not-so stellar service.  I prefer to hit the Chinatown area for dimsum but if you are staying at a hotel on the strip, PPP isn't too far out the way to get yourself a dimsum fix with some authentic dishes.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

LSHOYoSkrtLN4yeAw3BZvw.text: Ended up here on a random night craving authentic Chinese food- not glorified Vegas fancy schmancy Asian- and it exceeded all expectations.    Had the roast crispy skin whole chicken and it was probably the best chicken I've ever had - juicy moist flavorful and crispy skin on the outside.  I could've had the entire chicken!  Also had the pea sprouts, deep fried sea bass and roast pork belly - all amazing.  I'm Chinese and I've had my share of Chinese food ;) and this is some of the best!    PS- this is a real Chinese restaurant so people who are expecting impeccable 5-star service are unrealistic - go to the aforementioned places I talked about instead.  Let's be real- You're never going to get that kind of service here. You will get efficient and courteous service and that's all you could really ask for, people!

Wwx0SE91aav0BgcbLKht1g.text: Good food, horrible service both both the hostesses and waitresses.

HWLtJSF-xzMdM1eu1ePxSA.text: Must try their CONGEE. when I visit Vegas again I will be there with 5 bowls of congee. ^___^

zSk3BJKU14P-wOcn3qywpQ.text: Very tasty dim sum dishes.  Favorites were the pai gwat fahn (spareribs over rice), nai wong baoh (custard filled bun), dan tat (egg custard dessert), and their gnow yook cheurng fun (beef long noodles).  We also ordered the typical sui mai (pork dumpling), har gaw (shrimp dumpling) and fung jao (chicken feet).  Overall, I really enjoyed the dim sum here and would definitely return the next time we are in the mood for dim sum when visiting the strip in Vegas.  This restaurant is located inside Gold Coast Casino.    And what's there not to love about the name?  It's definitely memorable.

WT1RUuwLuqr73XujvS0NPA.text: Feeling disappointed was looking so forward to eating here this morning, but found a strand of hair in my dim sum and service sucks so bad. They have poor customer service!

Logj1EYjpjQeOOTWwqHYOg.text: This place is pretty busy during lunch hours. We had to wait in line for like 20-30 mins. So many Chinese and Asians here. The only place you see Asians is at this restaurant haha.  Food: not that many variety. Looks the same as other dim sum places I've ate at. There was nothing special. The food didn't taste better quality or anything. Potstickers- didn't taste fresh. Dry. Glutinous rice wrapped with lotus leaf- steaming hot, fresh, soft, flavorful. fried shrimp stuffed crab claw- this was good Cheong fun with shrimp- this was soggy and drench in sauce, but still good.  Not really worth the wait. Price was ok. Bill was $20

Kh46j0VeXuJ1o7n9IQlWRg.text: Overpriced and miniocre. I don't think I'll come back again.  There's just way more dim sum restaurants id pick over this one.

g0xfoBecCwrXjQL2Z7wAUQ.text: One of the best place to take the family. Try the salt&pepper pork chops and orange chicken. So much to choose from. A popular spot here in Vegas. Service always great every time.

Gyr0aF7jiNcAl9iXs338xQ.text: Finally tried this place because my friends rave about it...and the results are Mehhhhhhhhhhhh... too greasy..I know dim sum can be greasy on its own but wow this stuff was really greasy.. we ordered the typical dishes - shumai, hargow, chicken feet, spareribs, shrimp, rice noodles, and many more but nothing really stood out as outstanding or spectacular.  rather than wait long for this place and prob spend more money - just drive down the street to Chinatown... it'll probably be better..but hey I can say I tried this place now...

qQTd2yrgmTN2BxDYvIHKAQ.text: This review is coming from someone who was born and raised in HK. We have different standard on Chinese food than people from other culture. If you happened to be from an area outside of Canton/HK this review will not help you.   This used to be my most favorite restaurant in Vegas for its high quality authentic cantonese cuisine...yet the most recent visit proved to a a disaster...this place had lost its authentic cantonese taste, the pan fried noodle was saturated with gravy, my pan fried shrimp was over filled with sweet and sour sauce (it was supposed to be dry), and the beef rib tasted just gross. Service is ok; but I would say that food had downgraded to American Chinese food style...I will not come back.

TNfg4kAaMK9n8mOh656lcg.text: Best dumplings(potstickers) in town!!  Must get the sauce with it which they dont have during dim sum.  Only dinner hours.  Salt and pepper pork chips also the best!

Zr530Xzu9zMzWo-QbaKUtg.text: Wow wow wow was s Not sure about going in to one of Vegas casinos for dim sum but we tried it we had eaten many time at harbor place for dim sum but there's no comparison Ping Pang Pong by far the best ever thing we got was steaming hot fresh absolutely the best yum I can't wait till next month to go there again I hope that the chef will keep up the good f Work and the wait staff was very good place is clean also this place had all Asian people eating there if you into real Authentic and I mean real Authentic Chinese cuisine Not American Chinese cuisine this is the place and don't believe the ons that write a bad review you be the judge try it

-x03naelnktsPiLXVpJ7MQ.text: The best dim sum in Las Vegas for a very reasonable price. Food is amazing, best bbq pork buns and shrimp noodles. Food comes fast and is very fresh. Five stars for the food alone. Need to know what the place is - be prepared for bad service, very long lines, and a lot of people.

1CpftrtwbctiqPmgF8G53Q.text: Ping Pang Pong.  We used to make so much fun of this place, because let's face facts... the name sounds very racist. Does anyone know what it means, because I'd like to know.  I had a comp room at Gold Coast, and my usual eateries there are the Buffet (which is alright) or TGI Fridays, or I walk across the street to the Rio Buffet. This trip I decided I had a hankering for Chinese food, but I wasn't brave enough to go down a few blocks to Spring Mountain for the real authentic stuff, so I decided to go to the place we all joked about, Ping Pang Pong.  I was pleasantly surprised.  The service was great! Everyone was smiling with quick, prompt service. They were knowledgeable about their food too. I had the Pineapple Seafood Fried Rice, which had shrimp, scallops, and calamari in it. It was so tasty, and I filled up quite quickly.  I'm not quite sure on the authenticity of the food, I am certainly not the judge on that. But the food was good. Price was a tad high but certainly the food delivered.

s8x0OQNXxIlhepz1m_ofjg.text: Not bad at all.  The standard dishes - chinese broccoli, xiu mai, ha cao, chicken feet, black bean pork ribs, steamed bbq pork bun, shrimp wrapped in thick rice noodle, chinese donut wrapped in rice noodle - were all a-ok.  The rice and chicken served in a vertical bamboo cup was tasty; flavors were similar to Vietnamese 'com ga', with ginger, light soy, and chicken.  The xiu mai had orange/yellow 'eggs' on it which tasted like crab innards/tomal/mustard; rich and super flavorful.  All the dumplings were packed with meat and/or seafood and not a lot of fillers (yay!).  The only downside is that the offerings are limited/uninspired; just the basics.  I'd come back if I were in LV and craving dim sum.  Other important info: small establishment, push cart servers, prices are higher than CA but definitely reasonable, located inside Gold Coast Hotel off the Strip next to RIo and across from the Palms.

0RBfskZ8-s8NcdbJ4Ofqdg.text: I have mixed feelings about this place.  The food was pretty good, but the overall experience was kind of blah.  The restaurant itself is inside the Orleans, off to the side, and gated in,  but not really closed off from the casino.  There are paintings of happy Asian babies on the walls, and the clinking, and beeping of slot machines in the air.  The machines are only about 15 feet away, so there's cigarette smoke wafting in too.    I very rarely drink soda, so when I do, I want it to be kind of special. There was nothing special about my watered down Pepsi.  :( I told the server that the soda tasted off, and that the syrup needed to be changed.  He nodded, took my glass, ran off, and came back with the exact same crap, which kind of pissed me off.  Whatever.  We didn't come for the Pepsi.  Pot stickers:  These were really good. The wrappers were thicker than any pot stickers I've tried before.  They reminded me more of Russian pilmeni (I love those, so it worked out).  Hot and sour soup:  My boyfriend had a serious issue with this soup. He looked borderline pissed off after trying it.  It wasn't really spicy, or sour.  In fact, we were pretty sure it wasn't hot and sour soup, but the server assured us that it was.  I thought it tasted fine, but it wasn't what either of us expected, or craved. Lame.  Kung Pao chicken:  I thought this dish was great.  The chicken was juicy, all white meat, and perfectly sauced.    Shanghai noodles:  The noodles were cooked well, and the vegetable ratio was nice.  The mushrooms in it were really tasty, but the pork was barely there.  It came in tiny half-inch slivers, thinner than the noodles themselves.  It was delicious, but it should have had more meat in it.  Overall, it was okay, but I doubt we'd come back.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kung pao chicken
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shanghai noodles; lots of veggies, almost no meat.
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shanghai noodles

ros2ZPJPJ__UWJAfLhtySQ.text: One of the most authentic Cantonese restaurant I have ever been too !!! The princess chicken tastes exactly the same as the one I had in Canton. !! Excellent !

yS8WRIhpVTNKln1R7k71jw.text: I was a little hesitant to try this place out due to the mixed reviews. I was starving and this place is located inside the Gold Coast Hotel and Casino. Parking was not a problem, but that might be because I'm here on a Monday! I was pleasantly surprised by the food and service so I'm glad we ended up giving it a chance. We were seated right away and the carts came by pretty often. The food was hot and fresh. I actually thought the dim sum was decent and they had a great selection to choose from. Our water was refilled frequently and a food server made her round to ask every table if everything was okay. Although I've been spoiled with dim sum in LA county and OC, it certainly satisfied the dim sum craving. The best thing about it next to service is the pricing!

ZeuqYDtGQAHx3QyplVTCNQ.text: my go-to place for dim sum.....off the top of my head, fish balls, chix feet, chef's special tripe, and all the pastries just outstanding!...And don't forget to get the wor wonton soup!!!!!!

thQ8-Frohc-GqRuNsdk7Fg.text: Decent dim sum. I don't know of any other options in Las Vegas. When Vegas locals dine in, its probably a good bet Ping Pang Pong is considered one of the better places for dim sum.   Make sure you get there early as there is a line during the rush hour. The dim sum is good the service is ok. We went in during the Sunday brunch crowd, a group of 10 and they sat us on two tables as my buddy (who is a Vegas local), was able to make a reservation for us.   I loved their dim sum. You name it, Har Gow, Siu Mai, noodles, spare ribs, baos, etc...it was all pretty good. What sucked was the popular items such as the Har Gow (shrimp balls) and Siu Mai (steaming dumplings) always ran out. Every cart that rolled through all said "later".   Yummy for Vegas standards....

Qu2vtPZ1xw6cHf86rsbQEw.text: A hidden gem in Vegas. We had 12 in our party and had a round table with a Lazy Susan. Perfect for family style. The Duck, Lamb, MongolianBeef and Orange Chicken were awesome. The place has elegance and sophistication yet is very affordable. As far as service goes no news is good news. Servers always had our food and drinks coming but never noticed they were there. Great place for an event or occasion. Ours was a graduation dinner.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Great graduation dinner at this Vegas gem.

cE1fmnLum86RoGQGJowi8A.text: My favorite Chinese restaurant in Las Vegas. I stop by every time I come to vegas. Very authentic Cantonese food. Reminds me of home. Last visit I was pleasantly surprised that they renovated the restaurant but there was still a wait. And it's worth it. Their dim sum is really good. Have tried lots on their menu and doesn't disappoint.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dim sum - meatballs, chicken feet, shumai, beef tripe, BBQ pork bun.

ald_483SVjbxUAlxmFNN9g.text: The best restaurant I've been to , had the best authentic Chinese food in town. I loved their crispy roasted chicken , spicy is the best one. Must try it if you're in town !!! The service is very friendly .

68ueP3VlVrv36kUqLhjk4Q.text: I love dim sum and this place has the best dim sum in Vegas. Prices were reasonable, especially compared to any other casino restaurant out there, and service was quick and accommodating.

omirhOMjnC42fbc4xzUGMw.text: Love it here!!! The food is a big portion and it's delicious. I love their shrimp rolls and their pork spare ribs on the dim sum cart.

npeWcjwNJvJU-8nfYocPZQ.text: Food is always freshly made and also very delicious. Very clean and staff is efficient. Very good selection on the menu.

RWnO5H-iUJIEb74K2Qidbw.text: We came here for dim sum and there was a bit of a wait. They do push the carts around, but it was basically the same people again and again. Some of the workers can be a bit rude.  I thought the food was okay, but very oily.

9bw4j9SIOIWXNpqjEzfwvg.text: Came here twice on consecutive days for dim sum, which says something about the food. It's super good. Everything you'd expect for dim sum, plus some. Also, you can order off the menu. This place is very reasonably priced.  However, be prepared for a long wait if you come between the hours of 11am to 1pm. We got there a little before 11, and didn't sit down until 12:15. The line moves pretty slowly. The cutoff time is 3pm, and that's the exact time they stop coming around with carts. On the second day, we got there around 2:30 thinking we had some time, but they stopped serving soon after. The waitress was nice enough to give us a small plate on the house.  The service is not the best. The busboys who take your order for drinks take forever to refill ice water, as well as hot water for tea. When we asked about refills as he was passing, he seemed really pissed. Sour attitude throughout the meal. However, the ladies who come around with the dim sum carts are pretty friendly, and although it may not be their job, if you ask them about refills or missing utensils, they will make sure you get it right away.  It's a little far of a walk from the Strip, but we walked the 1 mile with no problems. The weird pedestrian walkway bridge makes it seem longer. You can take the free shuttle from Paris, Bally, or Harrahs to and from Rio, the casino next door.

z4y22-Wr3xYPiX97fIjyag.text: Seriously is the best dimsum place in town. I'm not a big dimsum fan, but when I tried Ping Pang Pong, it legit changed my view on dimsum. It really is the only place I'd go to have dimsum. And it's affordable as well. Love love love

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

XLSqej7xxRP9kMlvx0mp3w.text: We came at about 10:15 am (they open at 10am Saturday). The place was almost full, and we waited in line with about 3 parties ahead of us. We were seated within 10 minutes. They have your typical dim sum eats (shu mai, Har gao, sesame balls, baos, etc.) and the food alone was a solid 4 stars. But service was incredibly horrible, and staff incredibly rude so minus 2 stars.   They seated us in a section away from the main dining tables, so the carts were rarely seen in our section. The 5 main carts being pushed around only passed us maybe 2x in the hour and a half we were there.   Bottom line, if you don't have the luxury of time or blessed with the ability to be patient when you're starving, don't come. If you do come, try to show up early, and try to be seated in the main dining area where the carts like to pass you 10x more than the other area that is blocked off by a wall.   Food was expensive, for dim sum. The 3 of us ordered maybe 13 cart items, with tea, and our total was $75 and some change. Sorry, but I'm from LA, and the cost of dim sum there is about 1/2 with even better food, and just as bad service lol. But I guess for Vegas quality dim sum, this is one of the "better" options.   The shu mai was really good, and the red bean sesame ball was epically good. Not worth coming back though. We tipped them under 3% for the jack ass waiter who pitched a tone at my mom when she was complaining to him about lack of cart service. That was us being nice, since the service received was worthy of a 0% tip.

jX0UIIBgHRfHxqNMGjof9Q.text: Services is sadly provided, the line up for sitting down was a joke. Hostess is cutting lines to bring ppl into restaurant, enough to cause fight to break out. There was even "excuse me" when hostess walking in front of you with ppl bumping shoulders.   Food carts was a joke. Even their own dim sum lady were  raiding each other's cart. Trying to order something from a cart, other guest come up and demented services to other side, whom was ready to take over the cart to other side himself...   Disputes of bill at front cashier was a show to say the least..   I understand food is good, the services was pathetic to say the least. If you ask me if this place recommendable? The answer is zero, no, hell no to this place.

3r64OAGnjuP4B7Vp_UGWpw.text: This place is great. Come for lunch and the dim sum. You can order off the menu all night and you will never be disappointed. Maybe the best Chinese in Las Vegas.

r-iqKLVhIqwzi2Yprc77mw.text: I recently came here and wow it's like brand new lol they remodeled the place it's much bigger and nicer. We sat and waited for our dim sum to come around seems like they didn't have much to offer. I asked for a few things and they said soon it's coming which it never did lol. Overall service is bad and food never came only had a few choices ate what we can grab and we left
