Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pot of green tea

fPoQ-_5_LBOLrtdLgKJQxQ.text: Great authentic Chinese food, nice ambiance, very accommodating for large parties even on the weekends, and excellent service. You really can't go wrong with this place or anything you order. We were a party of 10 and we got a lot of food and they all came promptly and at the same time. There was the fried flounder, salt and pepper pork chop, spicy tofu with ground beef, deep fried chicken, and some kind of lamb with green onions. Everything on the table was amazing and had really great flavors; highly recommend the salt and pepper pork chop and spicy tofu. And we also go the house special deep fried noodles which was so good we had to order another one in the middle of the meal. It is a bit pricey compared to other places (bill ~200) but it was definitely worth it and it was a great experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu

8J7VQwTWYDBVvkmtKp4Y2Q.text: Ok Dim Sum, nothing special. We came for lunch. The Dim Sum carts were quick.   Fung Chao, Shiu Mai, spareribs were good. Everything was mediocre. Porridge was bland, super thicken. We don't speak Chinese so a lot of sign languages.   Our server was never around. When we wanted to order something on the menu! I had to ask for him 4 times over.   I wouldn't come back to this part of the strip, if it wasn't for us to meet a friend there on my bachelorette trip.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

YNT2cZrxiT4kYbv41INOtQ.text: So, the front desk guy at our hotel recommended Ping Pang Pong as the best dim sum in Vegas. He was Chinese and said his family ate there a lot. I had also heard that Gold Coast casino was a good local casino. So a quick Uber ride brought us here for a quick dim sum lunch. It was mid day on Monday and there was no wait. The carts were rolling around and there was also a lunch menu.  The pan fried shrimp, pork and chives dumpling was soooo flavorful. It was piping hot since we got a fresh batch. We also had a few other dishes that were all delicious. Since this was a quick snack for us, we didn't order anything off the lunch menu. We did inquire about their whole lobster with noodle but the price tag of $116 was a bit much for a snack.  Dropped off one star because service was terrible.  Servers were scarce. The bus guys were great, the cart service was good but the main server was probably hiding.  It took 3 requests to finally get water.  Hoping this was not a regular occurrence.

02yLJBZvaOycgG3D1caU5Q.text: My boss has been raving about this place since she knew we were staying at Gold Coast she recommended this place to us. I'm glad we went because their food is SOOO GOOD! As soon as they open, they'll have a long ass line wrapping the entrance. Luckily we were able to go before we left Vegas.   the first dish I ordered was their shu-mai or as you may know it as... pork hash! It was simply delectable. My husband is basic AF so he told me to get a fried rice. I had to get chicken fried rice since it sounded simple yet bomb at the same time. It came out good and the portion size was friendly. Last dish was their honey walnut prawns. It's soooooo good !!!!  Service was OK. Waitresses were obviously flustered from how busy it was so didn't really come by to check up on us. At least our waters were filled. This place is kind of pricey but it's like high end dim sum. Worth a try!

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Honey Walnut Prawns
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken Fried Rice
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Su-mai (porkhash)

HPl7TTY3IDiu2obNirjhAw.text: All these years living in Vegas and I finally make it to Ping Pang Pong for some midweek Dim Sum lunch for a lunch meeting...  PPP Service & Ambiance:  Attractive contemporary Asian decor right out of a fight scene in a John Wick movie (I dig the giant abacus decor) with tall ceilings to make the dining area appear more spacious.  There is plenty of room to accommodate 100+ diners.  The dim sum service was good, it wasn't hard to locate the cart with the dishes you wanted.  Multiple times we notified the nearest cart attendant what we were looking for and that cart would be sent over quickly.  Well done.  PPP Dim Sum dishes:  Everything I sampled was tasty and fresh.  They had all the 'mainstream' Dim Sum dishes along with some plates I've never come across before.  i.e.  The shrimp balls, covered in almonds and to be dipped in the sweet mayo sauce was was fantastic.  Additionally, some of the carts had some dinner plates so it was like a pseudo fusion of dim sum and dinner entrees.  Ping Pang Pong definitely has a diverse selection of dishes to try.  The prices are slightly higher than dim sum restaurants in the Vegas Valley which I expected considering their casino location and the upscale decor.  However, it's not unreasonable for the extra variety of dishes to choose from and the great quality.  I'l be back to try more dishes when I don't have the time constraints of a business lunch.  Enjoy!

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

zqjpJA-Y5V1Nm6DiqQtbPQ.text: Love the restaurant...  But quite disgusted to see that they allow dogs at the tables inside the restaurant.   Shameful that the customers would bring a dog into an indoor eating establishment and equally shameful that the restaurant allows it. Obviously not a service animal either...just some people who didn't want to leave their dog in the car.   Disrespectful. Heath hazard. Big thumbs down to the team at Ping Pang Pong for not addressing.   -From a dog owner

r256QPzUF6-GQ_x_wT589g.text: We're new to the area and are establishing our new "Go To" list of places to regularly visit. Due to the interesting name we decided that this restaurant needed further investigation.   We parked in the ramp and made the long walk to the restaurant. As we get there we can see a line forming outside - usually a good omen. Luckily we were quickly escorted in (about 20 minutes) to our table.   We explained to our "waitress" that this was our first time here. She said she'd be back with our drinks and that we'd get an explanation then. We got our drinks (from someone else) but never saw her again. Instead we had people walking by serving from their carts (okay, I get it. Been to similar places). Each person walking by would ask if we wanted anything from their cart. The unfortunate part is that we were not able to hear any of them as the place was way too loud and English not primary languages for them.   The portions for each plate were too big for an individual, so you'd have to grab a plate with the idea of it needing to be shared. My wife and I have very different tastes when eating at a place such as this. I am by far more adventuresome, and will try most anything. She???? ahhh NO! When you have no clue what is being offered this make things very difficult at best.  We had some rice, noodles, a couple dimsum (total guess what was going to be in them until after I had bite into it), and my wife had some chicken soup. The bill came to over $80.00! The soup was $14.00 alone!  As we were getting ready to leave, we notice that there were some menus that were being handed out to select customers. We are not sure why some were getting menus and others not but these would definitely have helped.  Other than enjoying saying the name of this restaurant, there is nothing worth coming back for. We can say the name anytime we wish to have it roll off our tongues.

zhx1x51e4_Vqn9sd4mijUQ.text: late night, incredible value for your money! delicious traditional meals served by friendly staff! management presence, to ensure customers are satisfied. two can dine for under $50! shareable portions, and enough to take home.   Upon arrival, after midnight we recieved are seats in less than 5 minutes! were eating in less than half hour! definitely return to this place!

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. vegetable egg roll, delicious dipping sauce!

6G7mdnXaUas5JwFsLSlCog.text: The comical name of the restaurant may arouse your curiosity, but the  consistently solid authentic Cantonese food they serve up is what should really lure you into Ping Pang Pong.  Located inside the Gold Coast Casino, it's just a quick few minutes off the Strip, and caters heavily to an Asian clientele.    Whether you're interested in an elaborate fare, or simple chow mein, you'll easily find something here for you.  The menu selection is vast.    My all-time favorite item here is their whole steamed fish.  It's always super fresh.  I prefer the simple, yet flavorful presentation with just ginger, onion and cilantro, which they do very well.  The one downside to this preparation here, though, is that it always seems to be brought to the table with obvious cuts in various parts of the fish, to test for doneness.  It doesn't detract in any way from the taste, but does take away greatly from the aesthetic presentation.    There's also a whole deep fried fish option on the menu, which I've yet had the opportunity to try.  However, I've seen them all over neighboring tables, which is clearly indicative to me that this is a favorite staple here.  On several occasions, I've even seen solo diners here with just one plate of the massive whole fried fish in front of them!  Another outstanding dish was their Shrimp Lai Fen with XO Sauce.  The noodles (lai fen) were deftly hand rolled, and boiled to al dente perfection.  The noodles really made the dish, and their house XO sauce was amazingly good.  I'd easily return solely for this entree!  I've also had Pan Fried Noodles with their XO sauce on a previous visit, which was also very well done.  If you're up for jook (rice porridge), there's plenty of traditional Cantonese versions, like the jook with pork and 1000 year old eggs. It was homey and plentiful in serving size, but the rice was significantly over boiled for my preference.    I've been here on weekends for their dim sum, but was dissuaded by the 2 hour plus wait time.  The good news is that weekday wait times are much more palatable, and dim sum items are available for order until 3pm.  Their dim sum offerings lack in uniqueness, but are solid in authenticity.    For late night owls, or rather late night gambling owls, Ping Pang Pong is open until 3am.  There's nothing like closing out an evening in Las Vegas with something hearty and homey for "sieu yeh" (a late night snack).

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Outside
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Inside
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu

LK-bCyL_9UOI-fo2ZqLaFw.text: The Food When eating your way across Las Vegas, one cannot forget the importance of dim sum. The place our friend recommended was Ping Pang Pong The Chinese Kitchen. We ordered quite a bit of dishes, some including... - Cha Siu Bao - Shrimp Rice Roll - Spare Ribs - Chinese Broccoli - Meatball - Beef Stew Claypot - Claypot Rice - Custard Pineapple Bun All the dishes were very good, and my friends and I enjoy them. Some we even got seconds like the Custard Pineapple Bun because everyone wanted more. The restaurant also had a dinner menu, which I would also like to try if I ever return.  The Miscellaneous The restaurant is very spacious, but people will line up before it opens. It gets crowded quite quick so it's recommended to get a reservation. The interior is very typical of an upscale Chinese Restaurant. The service was pretty face and the staff were professional. They had a wide selection on dim sum on carts, and some unique dishes that most dim sum places doesn't have. In the end, the prices were not super expensive per person, and everyone enjoy the experience. Would recommend to those looking for a good dim sum place to try in Las Vegas.

Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Custard Pineapple Bun
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spare Ribs

xuB2ilCbgs2LdLU79f1mjg.text: I think if you are totally desperate for "Chinese" food, then this place is fine.  If you can hold out a couple of minutes and drive a few blocks over to Spring Mountain... then do it!  This is not a destination place for Chinese food.  For what we paid, I thought it quite mediocre... Horrible even.  The standard dim sum was okay, but the certain things were just awful.  The fried calamari was just terrible.  It was super greasy as if the fry oil was extremely old and dirty.  There was also very little squid... mostly just puffy batter.  I was also excited to see a few pastry-type items that I have never seen before.  There was some kind of pineapple twist, and a red-bean filled bun.  Both were on the dry or old side, and marginal at best.  Service was ok, except for the boiling-hot water that was splashed on my back by one of the waiters.  Granted it was only a little, but seriously... really?  And without so much as stopping to apologize...  For two people we paid nearly $50.  Not really sure if the bill was even correct given that the classes of plates are not really advertised anywhere.  But its pretty much the most I've paid for dim sum.

bk9B6a0roL5sYcSsVLO0gw.text: Update: they moved the restaurant within the casino.  Today when we went for lunch there was no line!  There's usually a long line.  The food quality has diminished a bit from 4 stars to 3 stars.    When we were ordering the clams in black bean sauce the servers kind of didn't know what we were talking about.  Then after a few minutes they finally figured it out and then we found out that they didn't have any Manila clams but they had the razor ones.   We had 7 adults and 2 small children for dim sum and spent $200!  Wow, that was a little insane since it doesn't even seem like we ordered much.  Their prices per dish is a little higher than most places.  A lot of the dishes we got was also at the higher mark.  My mom said that we would have done better going to an AYCE sushi place for the same amount and had more variety.    Original review: My family loves coming here for their dim sum!  They renovated recently and the place just looks gorgeous!  Everything is nice and clean, fresh and inviting.  They did an excellent job!  Ladies man the carts but you can also try and order with a server as well.  The carts come around quite a bit so just be a little patient if you don't see what you wanted in the first round of ladies going by.    Some things we usually order: Steamed and baked pork buns Small spare ribs Beef tendon Honeycomb tripe Congee Shumai Beef balls Har gow crystal shrimp dumpling Calms in black bean sauce Egg tarts Turnip cakes  Shrimp in rice noodle with lots of sauce Fried taro balls Tofu pudding   Oh man, I'm getting hungry thinking of all that food!  It's all so

ifEDI7hTvnJ8N6_qGrhtJA.text: Came here today for the first time to try their dim sum. I typically don't eat a whole lot of dim sum because it's quite heavy on the oil. And even when I do have dim sum, I typically go to KJ Kitchen. However, some friends invited my husband and I to a Sunday brunch! I definitely took this chance to try it!   I got there at around 10:15 AM or 10:20 AM and there was no line. We snagged a table first while waiting for our friends to arrive. The service was quick, at first, to grab us water or tea, and plenty of people came to ask if we wanted to get something to eat. Surprisingly, they do push dim sum carts around. I was told by a friend previously that PPP was made to order ... I guess not? I was a little disappointed in this.   We got orders of shumai (pork dumpling), ha gow (shrimp dumpling), beef meat balls, beef wrapped in rice noodles, taro something, sticky rice, bbq pork buns, egg tarts, and Portuguese tarts.  The shumai were not good. They were tougher than any other shumai I had. Our friend said that they were probably previously frozen. Gross. The ha gow was honestly the only thing decent and worth having at PPP. The beef wrapped in rice noodles were average. The taro cake wasn't that great. They used dried shrimp in it and the flavor of the dried shrimp over took everything. That was all I tasted. The sticky rice only came with one and most dim sum places, they typically give you two. They also put a whole quail egg in? The bbq pork buns did not have enough meat in it according to my husband. The egg tarts were decent but they were full sized and I prefer the mini ones.   Overall, I would honestly rather go back to KJ Kitchen for dim sum. Don't get me wrong, PPP isn't bad. It just isn't all that special to me and definitely not the best of the batch. I also prefer to have good shumai over good ha gow. The hubby doesn't eat shrimp. Haha.   Also, there was a line by the time we left at 11:40 AMish. If you do want to try the dim sum here, try to get here early.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

7l37kcm2t_s1wl4bakpZLA.text: I've passed by Ping Pang Pong sign many many times but never thought about try them. I'm not sure why but maybe because of the strange name. I'm more used to dim sum names with dragon, garden, gold etc. A friend told us that this dim sum place is pretty good so we decided to try it. It is located inside the Golden Coast Hotel and Casino. The restaurant is located close to the parking structure so it's easy to find. Parking is free. The decor of this restaurant is beautiful. If you're wondering about the beads on the wall, they are abacus or Chinese calculator for you young ones out there.  Anyhow, they have a variety of dim sum from steamed dumplings to baked pastries. It was pretty busy when I visited but the staff were very nice and helpful.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Abacus
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

hHr7FgRYax4ELxrUOEnBWg.text: The Chinese Dim Sum during lunch is understandably busy. If you are into trying different things and different cuisine, this is a must stop for locals and visitors alike. If you are there for the food, it's great. If you are there to be wowed by Bellagio style service, you're obviously at the wrong place but it will work, no complaints from me.  I will definitely return to more during the week to escape the holiday rush. By far the most authentic and tasty place in Las Vegas. The price is on par with those other Dim Sum joints in town but much more tastier and popular. If you're down for a quick lunch, swing right in during non holiday hours! Clean, delicious, and fast: trifecta for great Chinese food!

ySEHOCscUfeynIDiDjWIwQ.text: Excellent food but if you're looking for excellent service, this is not the place.  We went in for late lunch and we were pretty much hurried out because they were preparing for dinner.  The waitress gave me the check and came back within minutes to see if I've signed it.

Xenr6BFbFg3a9cCs01YuhQ.text: Love this place great dim sum in town which is hard to find in vegas if your a local. Downside it gets packed very fast and the wait can sometimes be too long. But I would keep coming here.

lDBB3v9uUYTM29alqu2sjA.text: Ping Pang Pong. Ping Pang Pong. Ping Pang Pong. What a fun sounding name to say over & over. Wow! Can't believe it's almost a year since the first time I found out about this place through a friend. This time around, we made sure this was the first stop we made in LV to satisfy our huge appetite. Warning: get here early to avoid the long lines of people trying to get some shrimp balls.  As soon as the host directs you to your seat, be prepared to be asked if you're interested with plate after plate of dim sum & other Chinese concoctions. Items are not priced the same, obviously, so it's a guessing game how much they will charge you at the end of your meal (although they do stamp your order summary with some item/menu codes like in other dim sum places) but it really doesn't matter because the food is good any time of the day. Try the almond coated shrimp & shrimp balls on green bell pepper with black bean sauce with any of their special fried rice. The flavor lingers in your mouth like white on rice. Lol, rice coz I'm Asian. Lots of yummy things here & there; yummy things are everywhere! Order a glass of Thai iced tea or some hot tea to wash out the after taste. Sesame balls are always good to close out a filling meal. Got my full meal, & I was one satisfied customer.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

a1zuBuH5WW2R2GOGXAIKlw.text: Went Friday at 1130am to find it closed....wtf. You're supposed to be open at 10am or so goes yelp and your website. How can you have the most reviews of any dim sum place and close on a non holiday week day? Lost a local customer. Call ahead before you go I guess even though it says their open.

9z2-fIlPXIwm_MB3oG-frw.text: My family and I went here today for dim sum in the morning and were very unsatisfied. The restaurant is inside of the Gold Coast casino and there are no walls just wooden bars to desperate the restaurant which made it even louder, louder than average dim sum. The hostess was very nice and kept us updated on our table and we were sat shortly. The service was very lazy and doesn't really listen to what you're trying to order, and my grandma is Chinese and fluently speaks Cantonese and Mandarin so the servers had no communication barrier. We ordered something off the menu not the carts and it took almost 25 minutes to come out even though it was just a small noodle dish. The food was average, many dishes were below average compared to other authentic Chinese restaurants. I would not come here again.

p_f5-6L7CQwZvQXKNgI7qQ.text: They have a nice variety of dim sum however in my opinion it's not the best place for dim sum in Vegas.  The prices seem a little more reasonable than some of the restaurants on the strip that serve dim sum. The service was good and the carts are constantly circulating so there's no shortage of food when you're ready to order more. I will try the dinner menu next time I'm at the Gold Coast but I will go elsewhere for dim sum.

EZcAHRUc5LONaknUCNcSRg.text: I love to eat dim sum so we decided to try Ping Pang Pong inside the Gold Coast Hotel & Casino. Everything we ate was delicious! My sister and brother in law who drove from Flagstaff, really enjoyed the steamed and baked char sui bau. Ladies come around with their carts full of "small plates". When asking what the items were, I personally had difficulty understanding what they were saying. Just pointing at the dish seemed to work. Egg tarts and sesame seed covered "donuts" were the perfect end to this great meal.

BaavjgPbRd6bOWROGOukiA.text: I had heard about this place on Thrill List,, getting mentioned in both dim sum & chinese food for being one of the best in the country.  Boy, were they right.  We came here for dinner, in the mood for dim sum & were not disappointed.  Being dinner, the dim sum menu is limited, but still worth it.  The sesame shrimp rolls are crispy & coated with sesame seeds, filled with suculent shrimp.  The golden sand buns (steamed egg custard buns) are wonderful with a fresh bun & smooth sweet egg custard filling.  We also ordered some appetizers.  The pot stickers are crispy golden filled with a perfectly seasoned ground pork, cabbage, & ginger filling; perfect with a little rice vinigre drizzled over the top.  The vvegetarian egg rolls are crispy with a perfect vegetable filling; perfect with the well balanced sweet & sour sauce.  The pan fried seered shrimp & chive dumplings are wonderful with wonderful wrapper that is not doughy & perfectly pan fried bottom; the suculent & savery filling is excellent.  The hand made fried shrimp balls are wonderful with a crispy exterior & well seawsoned suculent interior.  For other desserts, not on the dim sum menu at nigyht, the sesame balls are sublime with a crispy sesame seed coated exterior & smooth red bean paste filling.  The service is friendly & attentive.  I can hardly wait to come back & try other items.  Round it off with a Ching Dao & you will not be disappointed.  Keep up the good work guys.

7DyHKmuMHY3CMsyl-fARMQ.text: They serve the very best dimsum in all of Vegas. Everything is fresh and tastes as if made in-house unlike other dimsum places around town. Other places sell previously frozen dimsum and the giveaway is the texture of the shrimp. The food is pushed around in carts and piping hot.   My favorites are the shuimai, hargow, rice rolls (packed with lots of shrimp), chicken feet and egg tarts. They have some unusual fare too like escargot in wine sauce. Good selection and prices are comparable to California dimsum. Do not go anywhere else for dimsum in Vegas!   The service is not the best but it is Hong Kong style service but the food quality is worth the visit!

dmJvsaukTqJDr4No4xh4kA.text: I just loveLoveLOVE this place. I like everything I ordered in the menu so far. Make sure you're not hungry if you wanna eat here because you have to stand in line

d5NvIoQd_D_OFyApcT5zTQ.text: Ok, this is my second visit and I was so disappointed with the organization of the wait line. We had a party of 7 and there were three large tables of 8 that were unseated the entire time we were in line. We asked about it after 10 minutes but the hosted told us we had to wait like everyone else. So all those who were a party of 1-4, ahead of us, were waiting for smaller tables that were all filled. So we waited patiently in the smoke filled casino. As we approached the front, there were two couples ahead of us and the host asked how many in your party? The both answered two and when she asked us we said, "Seven." And she immediately waived us ahead of the two couples...After waiting 40 minutes they line jumped us? What? SMH!!! This is absurd! Such disorganization. Not returning here anytime soon.

Q5WhJ3brbGLyZ42foWa0gQ.text: Nothing in Vegas is cheap anymore.  But for good dim sum this is the place.  It is clean and service is decent.

0GOTouA5ErPEkcMQKj3hZA.text: I'm only giving this place such a high rating is because of the food, which was good, but the service absolutely sucked. Waited in line for about 10 mins before anyone acknowledged we were in line. Another 10 mins before our order was taken. When it did come, it came incomplete and the last dish came out over 10 mins after our first dish came out. The manageress then tried to bullshit me by saying that the particular item takes longer to cook because they needed to fry it first. She shut up when I called her out on it as I have owned a Chinese restaurant before and knew what goes into making sweet and sour pork. I would've rather she just say I'm sorry we fucked up, it's coming right up. Never try and make lame excuses to the customer.  I guess she feels what happens in Ping Pang Pong, stays in Ping Pang Pong.

QWfjOM7ms8u2DZcsnLmcNA.text: I freaking love this place! This restaurant is located inside the Gold Coast Casino..   My auntie and I would always come here for lunch time. They have a descent lunch menu. All entrees for around 6-7$ and it includes the soup and rice and the entree itself.   We usually order:   the black bean chicken. Which is to die for. Really good seasoning and sauce  Chinese broccoli, really crunchy and steamed to perfecftion  salt and pepper pork chops, so damn good!  PIang Pang Pong also offers Dim Sum we tried a couple entrees it was ok they had some stuff that werent on your typical dim sum menu i guess they added a few things since there are so many Chinese customers they had to be competitive.  I would highly recommend coming during lunch time the menu is cheap and you get your money's worth and it is pretty good overall.  Just expect it to be crowded and packed with a bunch of Asians.  If you are expecting to have a business meeting i would not recommend it this place is LOUD and I literally was screaming at my aunt in all our conversations.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

hD3aM7CsJtwUiGWhYoc4Qw.text: How can you not love the name of this restaurant.  "Ping Pang Pong"?  Come ON.  Just saying it makes one all smiley.  Ping Pang Pong Ping Pang Pong Ping Pang Pong Ping Pang Pong Ping Pang Pong...  See?  Don't even front.  You're grinning right now-- or at least cracking a smile too.  :P  So I just had to check it out.  Chicken Congee.  They make special!  (For you?)  Yes, for me.  Usually I don't care for runny, Cantonese style rice gruel.  Plain, thick, bright white porridge is what makes my palate happiest.  Chicken bits, soup colour and mystery stuff that I myself did not place in the cooked down rice, just weirds me out... sorry.  Blame it on my boring Taiwanese-Japanese influenced upbringing.  However.  What's the point of being in Vegas, if you don't take chances?  In this case, I gambled on trying it.  And it paid off.  In my tummy.  This congee item wasn't on the menu, but it was kind of them to cook it up.  The waitress suggested it.  Perhaps she took one look at my haggardness and thought I needed some.  It was quite good.  Wor Wonton Soup was also basic and tasty.  Will have to try the dim sum this place is known for, next time.  The soups here were a good way to wind down a full day of travel and eating on the run.  Thank you Ping Pang Pong!

h-ZG4y3GlPYomYiVWzdLIQ.text: I'm a fan of Dim Sum, and usually try to make it a point to try them when I come across one.  To this day, I have yet to find a place that blew my mind.  Din Tai Fung was probably the closest (is that even considered dim sum?), but in the more typical joints where they come around with the trays, I've never been super impressed.  We decided to try Ping Pang Pong since it was in a casino, and we figured it would provide the necessary cleanliness that I find to be generally lacking in dim sum spots.    We got there 15 minutes before they opened on Sunday, and there was a line of 3-4 parties waiting in front  of us.  By the time they opened, there were another 5-6 parties behind us.  Shortly after we began dining, the place was full.  Good sign.  The wait staff was surprisingly Chinese - I say that because this is inside the Gold Coast and I would have thought the wait staff would be more diverse - and resulted in a service very typical to other dim sum restaurants.  They spoke little English, and often called out the dish in Chinese even after realizing we were not Chinese.  The decor was clean and typically nice for a casino restaurant, so this part we enjoyed quite a bit - dim sum in a clean environment.  The food was actually quite good.  It was quite distinctly lacking of the dumplings and shumai that we were looking for, they just kept telling us it would come later and they would come in trickles.  But what did eventually come - shrimp shumai and shrimp & pork shumai - were very good.  But alas, no har gow, no rice noodle rolls with shrimp (they had one with beef...), and just not enough choices of these little pieces.  What they did have though, were interesting and not common.  Congee porridge is common, and theirs is good.  They have a large bowl for the table and a smaller bowl for one.  They had cooked congee in spice broth which were excellent, and clams in similar sauce that were great also.  Their souffle-type dessert (they only make 10 per day) was delicious, as well as the custard flavor rolls.  One big issue I had with them were that the dessert dishes started coming out first, and just kept coming around.  Why do they do that?  Bring out the porridge and dumplings first!  We kept having to tell them "later, after we eat!" as the dessert trays passed by probably at least half dozen times.  They've got to fix this.  But all-in-all a good meal, and our meal for 4 came to $49 plus tips.  That's not a bad deal, and perhaps I can overlook some of their glaring shortcomings.  3.5 stars is more appropriate, but I'll bump up a half based on the quality of what we actually did get to eat.  Table-for-1 Factor:  May be for regular lunch & dinner, but for the dim sum brunch it's probably not a great option.

yM_OJx32ivrs8rowcIIMHg.text: By far the best dim sum in all of Vegas. Grades above most SoCal dim sum restaurants. Go early it's packed. Everything is tasty especially Hom Soi Gok Fried glutinous ground pork ball.  The sticky rice is excellent but unfortunately they didn't have the siu Mai or bbq rolls.  When the chicken feet is as fresh as this, the feet do the walking into my mouth.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried Chinese donut wrapped in rice noodle.

mmumYJNMy8zrgHk3T8m_CQ.text: I have been harboring some nasty suspicions for some time, and last night, I think my worst fears were confirmed. I am just a regular, non-ethnic white girl. I cannot eat the food that they actually eat in Japan and China. When I am served chicken at a restaurant that is cold (on purpose), yellow, still has the skin on, and has chopped up bones in it, I don't even want to take a bite.Fried pieces of pork that still have the fat on them do not appeal to me. A soup that is served with a huge bone in it with tiny scraps of meat and fat clinging to it does not look appetizing. In the spirit of adventure, I ate a few bites of everything, and it wasn't disgusting or anything, just meh.  In fairness, Ping Pang Pong also has some of the traditional American-y dishes you can get at your local Chinese takeout, but we were looking to branch out and try some new things. I'm not upset with the restaurant - I'm sure this is excellent preparation of Princess Chicken or Salt & Pepper Porkchops - they just aren't for me.  We also tried the singapore noodles, which were kinda like your standard Lo Mein, and some fried rice, which I thought was really good. Our final order was the wrinkled green beans, and they were also good. Overall, we mostly stuck to the noodles and the rice.   Our 6 dishes and 2 drinks ran about $80, so it's higher than your average takeout place, but still reasonable. We had enough food to easily feed 4 people.  The atmosphere inside is nice - kind of like any casino restaurant between casual and fine dining. The drawback there is that it's open to the extremely smoky Gold Coast casino floor.

aOeoulfucNMuBQfFU2LPVg.text: The wait in was long. Saw a bunch of kids running around. We probably would have left but we were here with family. There was an elite yelper there and they got to cut in line mother the less we had to deal with crazy customers walking in and sitting at our table. The manager had to help us. She was sweet and very polite.  Loved the food, tried some new things. It was a little crazy but nice at the same time. They seemed busy working. Food come out in rounds, that was kinda nice since we had a spinning table. Was fun

HydqfqNS40wKmF89jwo_UQ.text: Heard nothing but good comments so I decided to try it. Went it got some dim sum Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce on the side which cost me $9.99  has no taste or flavor nor was warm. I felt like I've been robbed. WILL NEVER EVER go back.

C7GCLH6NbAE4PrYCV648sw.text: The new location is pretty and upgraded to double space of the previous one. The best place to try authentic Chinese food plus dim sum, good place for group dining as well. The portions here are very big and fresh. Must try lamb chop and Cantonese roast duck; they have perfect seasoning. Walnut shrimp is my favorite; it's juicy and not too salty and the shrimp were super big with creamy sauce and crispy walnut.

dWco2CVdivzCghL2pmcD_Q.text: Great Chinese food! Wait times can get long but worth the wait. I love the eggplant dish, salt and pepper pork chops and salty fish chickens fried rice. Glad they expanded and remodeled the restaurant - much nicer than before.

Z6UQHmU_-mcPv8p3VthGRg.text: We come here because their "jook" rice congee is on point. Usually a pretty long wait to get seated. The dim sum price points are a little high for the portion that's served. But we visit here once in a while. Food is hot, delicious, and carts come by consistently.

ano3ys_IwGgJOxGTFbS-_A.text: Beware of unexpected overcharge when they total the bill (charging for special item when it was a small item on the original bill)!  First visit to this restaurant yesterday, here is my takes:  Pros: 1. Nice decor. 2. Dishes are "on the average" slightly better. Individual dishes can be better or worse than an average dim sum place.  3. The soy paper roll was more tasty than the one I used to have. 4. They do fill your teapot regularly.  Cons: 1. Accounting for quantity, price of most dishes are 50% to 100% more expensive than the regular dim sum place I go to.  So unless money is no subject to you, it may not be worth it.  2. Some dishes are not hot. The stuffed pepper I had was lukewarm, which made for a much lesser dining experience. I passed on the pot sticker for that reason, knowing it has been sitting on the cart as long as the stuffed pepper. Some dishes really do not taste the same when they are not hot. At this price level, one certainly expect more.  3. The Har Gow is 50% more expensive and not bigger nor better. My 7 years old label it as yucky and stop eating it after she had one! Why? She said the skin is soggy. Har Gow has been her favorite dish at our regular dim sum place and she usually finish 4 in a single setting, not this time.  4. The baked bbq pork bun taste sticky, and is small, though only 20% more expensive.  5. The waiter made no attempt to write down or understand what we want when we first sat down (we asked for 4 bowls, a pot of water and a pot of tea, plastic spoons and forks for the kids, the last three items were omitted by him) and came back with half of the items we wanted. We were left waiting, not knowing if he is going to come back with the other items, he never did.  6.. Last but not the least, the check! They overcharged me when they totaled the bill by charging Small dim sum(labelled as A)  as special dim sum (labelled as D), a difference of $3 per dish plus tax.  I do not know how that can be an honest mistake, A and D are not next to each other.  Is it intentional? That is certainly fruit for thought. Most customers do not check their bill and would never know.   I go to other dim sum restaurants frequently (at least once a week, sometimes 3 times) and never had any billing error (I am one of the rare few who check my bills regularly). Ping Pong Pang is one for one in the department of inflating the charge at the cash register. When it was pointed out to them and  they came back with the correct bill, there was no "I am sorry for the error". It certainly left a bad taste in my mouth. To make a billing mistake and not apologize for it certainly leaves a lot to be desired.

L-tEPAyoWRrxQinT_R8dJA.text: Whoa, second day in a row that I picked a place with a huge crowd and a wait.  I think I could've legitimately done without the wait. They have a sign pointing to a waiting area just outside of the restaurant, but they didn't seem to have a dedicated host. I stood there for at least 5 minutes before they even so much as said hi to the party in front of us, and another 5 before they seated us. It was very busy, but at least I should've been welcomed, and I'm pretty sure there were at least a couple of open tables.  By the way, try to park at the side of Gold Coast farthest from the Rio if you want to have a shorter walk, which is healthier than it sounds due to less secondhand smoke exposure.  Anyway, as with any good dim sum place, we were able to dive right in since the carts made their rounds quickly. My friend started off the picks with a har gow (4 pieces), a shu mai (4), and a rather large and unfamiliar bowl of some sort of tripe with ginger and daikon. I later got us a plate of shrimp stuffed eggplant pieces (3), some deep fried shrimp balls with sugar cane (2) and some nice compact egg tarts (2). The last item was the chicken feet that my friend was pining for the whole time.  Everything was definitely on the high end of good. All the savory items had sufficient flavor and non-mushiness, and the egg tarts were very flaky and were still noticeably warm at the end of the meal even though I'd ordered them at the start. I didn't fall in love with any one dish, but the quality was solid overall. Prices are probably a bit more than you'd expect since it's a casino restaurant and there's not all that many dim sum shops here. It was most likely $5.88 each for the tripe bowl and chicken feet, per my friend, and we had one $2.18 order, four $2.88 items, and one $3.88 dish. Couldn't tell you which is which since I'm not that much of a dim sum connoisseur, sorry!   Overall, I wasn't blown away by any single item, but it was solid dim sum and I definitely prefer this to East Ocean, which has seemed a little lacking for me the past couple of trips for some reason. I also definitely appreciated that we got a tangerine and candy here instead of a fortune cookie (looking at you, East Ocean). I have not been to KJ yet, so stay tuned in case I decide to hit them up.

iBdDeZqh0XyAOc7fCFLpwg.text: Seating is limited and service is unhurried so expect a long wait at lunch time. Getting in is the hard part-- you stand in line with a crowd of people yelling in various Chinese dialects as they shove, cut, and complain-- all adding authenticity and closely matching my experiences in China.  Another reason for the long wait is, once inside, diners tend to linger. I don't blame them. The food is tasty, hot, and well-varied. All my favorite dim sum dishes were here.  Servers are friendly and I never felt ignored (as I have at other dim sum places).  For about $18 including tip I was able to stuff myself.    The 40 minute wait to get in was painful but I'm glad I stuck around.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Egg noodles with beef in a sweet, tangy sauce. Very nice.
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp balls and chow mein. Both tasty and hot.

f457PBYFBp8xAKdNyBpdyQ.text: Love!! Chinese is my favorite food and this place is a real treat. We made the trip from the strip to this restaurant and I'm so glad I did! The servers had some trouble understanding our English, but they were so sweet it didn't matter. The potstickers were a favorite - so juicy when I cut into them the splattered all over my shirt so consider yourself warned.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ambiance
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. A feast!

dg6PN_C-fSPxEUWV8qUz-w.text: I'll be honest, I only came for the dim sum! Me and a friend ordered one of everything on their $3 menu. And some of it, like the pork bun&shumai& shrimp ball, were good. Others, I have to say, were just delightfully adequate! That golden sand bun, I just had no taste for, but I have been here before for various chicken dishes which were really good! So I have to recommend!  However, the service we received was really slow. it must have taken nearly 30 minutes to get dessert and the check after being done with our dishes, but that would be the only setback for me not visiting again!

JSVa8r8BrE20dCZDZiTLJg.text: The service and level is so awful,the waitress and boss do wrong things to our order.the chef did not see our order,we waited TWO hours to get our dishes.We waited fried rice and stewed beef from 7:40pm until 9:30pm.we asked waitress several time to take our order. But the staff just said it will be done soon.we waited so long for our dishes.it is a nightmare! If this restraint continue doing like this,it will be closed soon!

Wx0vW-iCljOTmliYVVwqIw.text: Excellent restaurant - the service was great, quick, and polite. The food was delicious and very reasonably priced.. loved

RCFV54bKVV71EFJsmwr0eQ.text: A really nice place for late night Chinese food. But the dim sum is not on the menu. Ask them what they have.

QCjsRgUOVTkpbvTc0DAVzw.text: If you like M S G this is the spot for you! A lot  ! Please learn how to cook properly without it....

KbcCHSDH1TtuL5a9N6Fsrw.text: After a very long wait to be seated (expected), the service was so bad that I will not return. Food was good but not worth the hassle to get it.

XoYkeXtfFuWdQKfFTJWkpg.text: I am so glad to have found this place in Las Vegas!  It is located in the Gold Coast hotel, which at first was a journey to get to the restaurant. We had to travel through the casino but if you want to play the slots in the meantime might as well!  The food was delicious, the cook is really good. It is one of the best Chinese foods I've had. The orange chicken was bomb as well as the roasted duck. We got a few platters of dim sum, and the shrimp dumplings were good as well. The shrimp was very flavorful and fresh. The restaurant also looks very presentable and clean. The only downside is that their dim sum menu only had 8 options on it :( Other than that, would recommend for some good Chinese food!

WK1gCC29e-EvsweLmzVVTw.text: Best kept secret in Las Vegas! I'm a total fan. Left completely satisfied.  At first, I didn't want to patronize this place because of the silly name! It's almost offensive! I mean, Ping Pang Pong? Come on, are you freakin serious?   But after reading other yelp reviews,  I had to give it a try and sure enough, my fellow yelpers did not lead me astray.   Thx! I'll definitely be back and this will be on my to do list in Vegas!  The food was surprisingly authentic. Don't expect the best service.  (Off the strip inside the Gold Coast Casino)

n-lmRt_b7KfZvZM6Oio53g.text: Good dim sum in Vegas that's open late. It's located inside a casino which was only 4 minutes from our condo. We came here around 11 in the afternoon and there was already a line forming.  The wait wasn't too bad if you have someone in your group wait while you go gamble lol and switch off whenever.  The dim sum was fresh, hot and delicious! The egg custard for dessert is really good and wasn't too overly sweet. The only downside was the ladies pushing the carts because it took them forever to come around the restaurant. Other than that everything was fine and service was friendly.

V0OCxADMwnKfQHUR1zjgRw.text: Worst customer service! Called in for pick up order. I was told it should be ready about 15-20mins for two dish I ordered. Okay no problem 22mins passed went inside and asked for my food hostess went to check. she came out 5mins after to tell me my order is not ready yet!!!! I asked how long more she said 5mins. Came back after 5mins still not ready so I left because first my order is still not ready after 30mins, 2nd didn't even bother to apologize, 3rd I'm not coming back here I wouldn't even recommend this place they need to get their shit together love the food but the service sucks.

IoMGFrEh-TtsE-icdw3Pvw.text: The food was delicious. Growing up in big apple where in Chinatown you have a variety of authentic food, I had a bar set. I was very happy with the flavors ? Of course warm and fuzzy is not what you go to this restaurant for....  kin du pork chops and walnut prawns with curry seafood rice were our choices.  Try the sesame shrimp roll...

u02q0Ecm3lSPDZHu7vWMdg.text: We've been waiting outside for almost an hour. Good looks good. Still waiting.  Got here 12:00pm, now It's 01:00 pm on a Tuesday afternoon So hungry!

ddRFaTb0dKmbfHk93UKrTw.text: The food is DELICIOUS and I come here quite often or order for take out. One thing that they do need to work on is the customer service.  I will be honest the customer service SUCKS!!!! The food is so good you barely pay attention to it, but when you are hungry or thirsty you shouldn't have to locate your server. On top of that the server never says for ex: "Hi I'm Ben" instead they just come and say are you ready to order or you have to say excuse me to whoever is walking by.  For that I give this place 3 stars because the service should match the beautiful restaurant.  Sometimes the staff is rude and barely acknowledge you, well most of the times. If the staff were more friendlier and more aware that different cultures are there to enhance their tastings with good Chinese Food, then I would give it 5-Stars.  I will admit the food is 5-Stars.  I recommend this place to anyone. It truly is a hidden gem with the ability to be 5-Stars.  I am headed there now to take out my girlfriend and mom for mother's day.

ruMinwG-j86n5KwdQPk-Pg.text: My husband said it was great, an absolute must try. Between his enthusiasm and the reviews, I was excited. I was sorely disappointed. Unsure if it was the time or the table location, but other than the steamed dumplings: shu mai, shrimp etc. everything we received was cold. Both the calamari and the fried pork dumplings were not only cold but also greasy.

yymi0Lzu82GH9hKf_0Sk1Q.text: My  Chinese wife and I ate here late one night and had a very delicious meal. We were trying to eat a light meal so we had a porridge , chicken and a green vegetable. It was quiet in the restaurant, the kitchen looked clean and so did the cooks. The service was helpful and friendly. We returned the next day and ate dim sum, it's obviously a locals favorite. We will return when we are in Vegas.

WSbUoD6CFkHp9SPjqAy3aw.text: Loved the dim sum here. Tasted very fresh. Not salty, not oily like other places. I highly recommended this place.   I should come back for dinner when i'm in the area again.

nrn6BHNb6F_-tgxKvyGa0w.text: The food here is GOOD. The service here is BAD.  We haven't been to this hidden gem a few times, and all though the food taste great.... their customer service makes me cringe. One time we had came in for dim sum, and the lady kept missing us. They didn't refill water and we felt completely ignored. It was hard to get anyone's attention. We kept having to raise our hands and ask one employee something and they said they would grab the right person and it was a vicious cycle.

ufEWbON4oYafAdFPQdRgig.text: Dim sum was actually pretty good. They had the dim sum in fresh carts. Dinner was also pretty decent for being inside this old run down casino. I would still dine here

hwYk1yR74da-7lz2GNyC6A.text: I come here all the time for the garlic frog legs cant find them anywhere else like it. The breading is light and the legs are always big.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. garlic breaded frog legs

2ql1Uv-UHase9yBz4Nrogg.text: I really  like this Chinese food restaurant , the food is awesome, nice portions , fresh, very tasty . Service is ok . Also I loved the coconut water

yAHpjlS9Pc1BEirCa1ildw.text: Do not go to this so call restaurant if you want to eat dim sum. The hong kong garden is far was much better.

owlInRva0lDpQOk-08onUQ.text: Last year I went to Ping Pang Pong with my boss and wasnt that impressed. I remember liking 1 dish and thinking the rest was just ok.  Went back a couple of days ago and had a much better  experience. All the dishes we tried were pretty tasty and service was quick. Standout dish was the BBQ pork. Mmmmm.

-zdYzspGmC9O4e834nZUnA.text: A brief background about myself. I am a veteran food and beverage manager for over 10+ years in the casino industry.       I have been here a few times and went there again today for some dim sum. Every single time we eat here there is always a long waiting line to just get seated. The food is average for a dim sum place. The only reason I go here is because I have comps to use up before they expire. After waiting about 15-30 minutes to be seated, we wait again for about 10 minutes before a waiter/waitress even shows up to take our drink order. Almost every time we sit at the table we are missing either silverware or tea cups. This place is always understaffed and could use more personnel to wait on the customers. The food is about average and once something runs out from the dim sum carts it takes over 30+ minutes to replenish that food item. This restaurant could definitely use a lot more improvements to service, training, and wait times.

yiBzlzMPiHIXI6JrxUHv2A.text: Maybe it's because I'm from California. Maybe it's because I'm used to Chinatown in San Francisco being a 15 minute bus ride away.  But when I'm handed a 16 dollar check for three small pork buns, two teas and two plates of small potstickers I gasp.  Because in Chinatown, heck, in any Dim Sum place I've been to in the last five years, that is outlandishly priced.  But hey, maybe all Dim Sum makers decided to up the price all at once and no one told me. Maybe it's just Nevada. No? Just triple P?  Good to know.  The service was good for cart Dim Sum, but again, we didn't revisit during our trip due to the price.  If we return we'll most likely skip it. I'd rather head to TGIF and get a huge place of food for less than that.

7-VeR3Fu8goxblPogX_Shg.text: Went here on a weekday around 6pm. For a Monday night they had a bit of a wait but not too long. We sat at a round  table, it appears they have some tables with Lazy Susan's which makes it easier for sharing. The reason I gave this establishment such a low rating was because the service was very bad and the food wasn't anything to rave about. We tried several dishes and none were impressive. The waitress kept trying to rush us out the door. It took them approximately 30 minutes to take out order. We received watered down Thai teas which had to be sent back, as well as one meal in a box without requesting so and the check was also presented halfway through the meal when we clearly weren't finished. The food was good but There are better Chinese restaurants in town. Sadly don't think I'll be back.

84RDC9ULx81NPhTlcgfYAg.text: Sooooo good here. This is my first time here for Dim Sum. But everytime i have dinner here i just love it. All the plates are authentic and very tasty. I'll come here anytime. Lunch or dinner. And it's even better when i have a comp too. Lol. Tell your friends to eat here. You won't be dissapointed.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. I love Dim Sum.

F3iggib9AXOSZp5kahWCjA.text: It's probably the best dim sum place in Vegas. The varieties and taste of the dim sum are satisfied.  Recommend to try if you have time.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

pDTkH_O6XKFyK3xlhHAW5g.text: The dim sum is delicious. Great quality. And the atmosphere is very clean.  We also had the roasted duck, which was perfect. The skin was crispy and it was very juicy, not dry at all.

A7odk_YuR9dAJ2evv4vN1A.text: Yay for DIM SUM after 3pm!!!  I came here a couple times, but the first time my cousin took me here. We were both craving dim sum at midnight, so what better place to be, since it closed at 3am?!  I honestly didn't know how legit the dim sum would be so I ordered Mongolian Beef and a cup of rice. I didn't think the portions would be that big, but when I got my beef and looked around the room, I noticed plenty of families eating together... hmm.. FAMILY SIZED PORTIONS! Even better!  I wanted to try a couple of the Dim Sum items, so I ordered the Baked Pork Bun, and HALLELUJAH! This right here, BAKED PORK BUN, is the BIDNIZZZ (business). If you want to try one thing, please let this be it!   A couple weeks later, I told my friend about my dim sum craving and recommended this place. This time we were actually here for the dim sum. We ordered every single thing off the dim sum menu. Don't worry, there were about 10 or less items all $3 each.  After getting to taste them all, MY TUMMY WAS HAPPY.   It was then time for dessert, but the server did not notice... We waited and waited, and stared into the sky, hoping they would acknowledge us. & they finally did! 30 minutes later... Thank goodness the egg custard dessert was BOMB.ORG, because it slightly made up for the time lost!  PING PANG PONG!  TRY THE BAKED PORK BUN!

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dim sum for $3!

1EpWQ9h55gItU7GkP7jzXg.text: This place has wonderful dim sum. The carts go around and you grab what you want. We must have been the only non Chinese customers and the place was packed for Tuesday lunch. The cart pushers recommended duck, jellyfish, and one other plate. We obliged. Little did we know that these plates were $10 each! Other small plates are only $3-$6. Hence we paid $50 for lunch that should have been at most $30.  This underhanded recommendation left a bad taste in my mouth. Buyer beware.  Good experience otherwise.

7sOXrIczWMf8DELGwQ-5Ag.text: The wait wasn't too bad on Christmas Day, the food was decent but the customer service was lacking. We requested a few items and the waiters said they will check on it and never came back with any of the dishes. My friend got fed up and we were all hungry that he had to individually chase down each cart to get what he wanted. We requested for a certain congee and the waiters like kitchens closed yet the other waiters around us were still taking kitchen orders. When we flagged down another waiter we were able to order without any problems. The first waiter told us they didn't have that congee and then we hear the workers who are about to eat lunch say to each other "oh there's blah blah congee do u want" my whole table turned around and was like wth? If you don't mind decent dimsum with hit or miss service by all means come here

SxOsz2bYLs5-4qaxIDpmnA.text: Every time we go to Vegas we go to Ping Pang Pong.  It is all new and bigger than ever.  the food is delicious and they did have a few items on their regular menu from their Dim Sum.  I wish they had Dim Sum all the time!

VRoTi8Bp1Cex-BE-t1KLtQ.text: Pretty good dim sum. Service is spotty though. Like many restaurants in Vegas, it's situated in a casino. I really dislike that as you have to make way thru all the smokers inside. Also, sitting near the outside of the restaurant is awkward because the ppl gambling and walking by just stare at your food. Other than that, it's a decent place for dim sum in Vegas.

0tZ4EE6pBrSgj0eQNoEgTQ.text: I wasn't expecting much from this restaurant after reading some of the reviews but I wanted to try this restaurant with the silly, ridiculous name anyway. My friends arrived before me so we didn't have to wait in line. There was a small line already. We arrived right when they opened at 10 a.m. The restaurant is the smallest one I've seen from the other dim sum places I've been to in this town.  The server took our drink orders right away. The dim sum ladies came by with their carts. We picked a few items. Some of the carts can be a little slow because a few times, we were waiting to eat more. The service is the least friendliest compared to the other dim sum places in town. Nothing too friendly or too abrasive...just your typical, nonchalant Asian service.   Moving on to the food...It was fresh, good, and hot. Shumai, shrimp har gow, fried shrimp ball with mayo dip, shrimp in rice noodle, shrimp in bean curd, egg custard tart, & the donut resembling a malasada with red bean were delicious!   The only thing that bugged me...We asked for hot sauce twice but never got our hot sauce. It's not a deal breaker but I like my foods with a little kick. Whatever, no biggie. I'll be back and I will make sure I get my damn hot sauce!

wkwJNIEyE3XeY2HU86OBiA.text: I  love dim sum. Every city I visit I want to find the best spots in that city to sample the local yum cha offerings. In Las Vegas I asked the sushi chef (no he wasn't Japanese) in the Fulton Street Food Hall in Harrahs if he knew where local Las Vegans went for dim sum. He explained that while he was new to the area having recently relocated from LA he recommended the spot over in the Gold Coast. That spot is Ping Pang Pong.  Sadly I got there a little late and yes there was a wait so the dim sum offerings were scant. I was told that they have dim sum all day, but by 3 there were only 5 items left. I was there with two dim sum neophytes. In the light of all of my enthusiasm they found the offerings underwhelming and ordered off of the regular menu. The spare ribs were some of the best I've ever had. In fact we got two orders. The sesame seed balls were different from the ones I've had on the East Coast but I liked them. In fact, the remaining two items I ordered were different but not bad. I'm giving this restaurant a 3 because I believe I wouldn't have been underwhelmed if I'd had more to choose from. The service was sub par though, we had to wait quite a while for refills on water and tea and the extra napkins we requested but the place was packed. That said, I really need to visit again to render a fair review. It's worth a 2nd visit for sure.

luroQNJAvJnAiS4PXwTFhQ.text: Horrible service and terribly cold dim sum! Management was very uncooperative. We left and went to a real Chinese restaurant. Bad bad bad!

_Ls5jdDAzFP4y1_VGjyrjw.text: This is definitely a hidden gem hidden in a corner of the Gold Coast casino. But once we were there, man was the line long! This must mean that the food is good. We waited about 45 minutes to be seated which is why I give it 4 stars.   The food was all really delicious! I love their chicken feet, they were surprisingly really huge and juicy. We ordered the classic hagow/shumai which was also fresh and delicious. I was waiting for their shrimp rolls, but unfortunately, it took awhile for that to come, and when I asked one of the lady's who was pushing the cart, she seemed very irritated and started yelling back at me, which caught me off guard. But other than that, the food is great, and the price is decent. I know where to go now to get my dim sum fix when I'm back in Vegas!

WDjoEe2RUZJJm9OO9NVAiQ.text: Good dim sum. Not typical but it's good enough in LAS. We came here at about 11:00am, not many people so we're quickly seated and served.  If you miss Chinese food, you may want to give it a try.

KVotlQno_aDCo_o0UJf-Rg.text: Dim sum here is very good. I was impressed. Lots of Chinese people here so you know its authentic.

BhZagybPVM3Y1uY_4WiuoA.text: Service is terrible. Food was good. Came here at the old location in the casino before and enjoyed it. Tried it today but the service was very poor. First, at the hostess desk, no one even looked up for about 45 seconds then just pointed and said wait. About 2 minutes later someone comes around the corner and says something like " let go" so I followed. She took me to a table. No menu. I waited for over 5 minutes before I even saw an attendant. She brought a menu and asked for my drink order. Didn't come back for more than 10 minutes and only wanted to deliver my water. I told her I was ready to order. She seemed annoyed but took my order. Kung Pao chicken and Night Fried Rice. A few minutes later another woman came to deliver good, that i did not order. I dont know if she didnt speak english, but, i told her no. Not mine. She said yes, yes and stared at me. Finally when i handed it back to her she got the idea. It was for tbe ladt next to me. Very unfriendly and almost rude staff. Food came quickly and it was hot and fresh. Never saw the waitress again. I was finally refilled on my water by a manager of some sort who was very nice. She brought my water back and I waited probably 10 more minutes before someone came back to get my credit card. They were busy but not full and really no excuse for service level.

YPoiOAMp9C8JODMw-BEC-Q.text: We did family style here with beef flat noodles, seafood chow fun, calamari, pork chop, shrimp balls, potstickers, and fried rice. These were really good. The thai ice tea was a little too sweet and the tapioca was a little too hard. But otherwise, the food was pretty good. I also  like that they have enough table room for at least 10 ppl too. Good for big groups

U-IYZGtNRIZhRrsD4EpvYQ.text: It's very decent.  I wanted to check out dim sum in Las Vegas.  We came on a Saturday morning, and at the stroke of 10, when they open, a number of tables were already filled.  They have the standard dishes, including two types of jook.  We left probably an hour or so later, and the same carts had rotated around several times.  There were a couple of dishes brought around on trays.  The variety isn't very large, but I liked it better than Five Star Seafood (fka New Capital) in Monterey Park.  It's a good dim sum fix when in Vegas.

0b-b2T_elZSjmARtjcvcHg.text: When the local restaurateurs tell you they only go to PPP for dim sum, you listen.  I have lived in many cities and travelled overseas and I can safely say this is easily the top 3 best dimsum I have ever had.  It is better than LA/SF, BC, NYC; in fact, it is better than the dim sum I had in Hong Kong.   1) They still use the authentic push carts. 2) It is easy to over season and over salt the food like so many restaurants.  But not at PPP.  It is so refreshing to be delicate and controlled in seasoning.  I don't remember the last time I ate such balanced and light dim sum.  Don't believe me?  try to cook a delicious dish with as little seasoning as possible.  It is difficult.  Somehow PPP managed to do just that.  All the ingredients shine through in an airy melody.    3) They also have dishes that normally don't show up in other dim sum restaurants. 4) I especially recommend their bbq pork buns and steamed honeycomb tripe.  Shut your eyes and enjoy the texture, subtle flavors and the balance of the whole dish.   5) try their mango dessert -- real mango pieces and clearly made with real mangos.  Well done, PPP.

nslGbWxfS4EDxeKrpU2i8A.text: Came here on a late Thursday night with my cousins b/c we were on a mission to find Dim Sum to bring back to the hotel and eat there...  Customer service was decent, but it took wayyyy over 30-40 minutes just to get our food...total cost of food cost us over $116 bux...we didn't care anymore...we were hungry. "$3.88 for 4 pieces of siu-mai? Aww damn, but fu*k it...we got a group to feed," says my bro lol...  While we waited, they served us ice water which was nice, and since we were drunk off the alky and were hella hungry, we ordered wor wonton soup...it was hella bomb haha  Eventually we got our food and ate it back at the hotel... -Fried Rice: 2 kinds I forget what...simple but good -Salt 'n' Pepper Pork Chop-a tad bit salty but it was good -Pork siu-mai-expensive but it was delish -Wor Wonton-the second time around, the broth was hella salty -Honey walnut shrimp--delish -HK style chow mein--I can't believe they ruined my fave dish...hella corn-starchy...and no flavor!! :/  Nonetheless though, we were satiated and sleepy by 3am haha

Sz22vxykcNS9GaqKu4svjw.text: Definitely come here for the dim sum and come early. As there can be quite a wait. Service wasn't spot on as it took a bit of time to get seated even when at this early time not all the tables were filled. Also took some time to get the attention of the service staff to get orders in. In the end the standout here is the dim sum. A large variety of various dim sum platters. Some you'll only find as specialty items in Asia and not found in the states. Large portions as well for a dimsum plate so you get value for your buck. Nicely flavored shrimp dumplings and chinese meatballs. They had a great tofu dessert. Served hot in a bowl with sugar syrup. Delicious shrimp and beef churn fun. Freshly baked egg tarts that were still hot and flakey. Their beef chow fun was also very good with lots of ingredients and can serve a large group. If in Vegas and hankering for some dim sum i would definitely come here. Would be 4 stars on food alone if not for the service.

C3tiqRkWeIfBGu-EZeBh_A.text: A yumcha gem inside the Gold Coast casino! the place itself is quite small which equals a long wait but the food more than makes up for It.   From the hagow to the shumai , everything was tasty and fresh, my only qualms is that the Lo-Mai-Kai only came with one! there's usually 2-3 :( Lo-Mai-Kai is the stuffed rice wrapped inside the leaf and my favorite thing to get!   other than that it was great, price is a little on the expensive side since it is in a hotel 2.88 for (A) and 3.88 for (B)  would come again

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

OYrG6soTuWFHAiZIFLAV2g.text: This restaurant was really awesome that I've never been!  It was really delicious and can enjoy many kinds of dim sum,

uYGj_zwESuGXjHiPkKmhJA.text: OK, I'm going to give up one of my favorite haunts in Vegas.  I was hesitant to tell people about this place.  LOVE their dim sum, it's all I've ever had there so I can not comment on their Chinese Food.  I can tell you though that 98% of their customers are Asian and so that is a huge indicator of the level of authenticity.  In the past we had trouble communicating with the staff because they usually speak in their own language, this last time though it seems they have hired more English speaking staff and it was considerably easier to order.  Everyone is smiley and happy, the worst part is getting seated.  There is ALWAYS  a wait, I don't care what time or day you go, but once you get seated being it's dim sum there is no wait for food and it just keeps rolling past you for your pleasure.  I love everything we have ever had there and they are reasonable with their cost.  The worst part of this place is that it is located in the Gold Coast and you have to wade through the heavily smoked environment to get to the restaurant, but even going through that is worth it for this place.

rbj60VVGDaBNPws_ySRCrw.text: my favorite chinese food in las vegas!the food is also freash and have a good service,the prices is good!

rU1K8JthKMU0uCdrf8u63g.text: My parents love this place for dim sum so we were all dragged here.  At first, we were dim sum in a casino?  Really?  You know what, they serve authentic chinese dim sum.  Actually, I was surprised that the dim sum was pretty good.  I agree with Ed C. some of the sauces seems a little watered down.    Highlights that I can remember: The BBQ buns (steamed and baked) were good! Steamed spareribs were good, a tab bit too spicy for me. Steamed rice wrapped in green leaves - YUM! Rice soup with shredded pork and preserved egg - YUM YUM! Almond tofu dessert - 1 Yum and a Yeah!

QURYB69gVZHB_JgjdryV3g.text: OMG disgusting orange chicken taste like rubber walnut shrimp gross. Cantonese sausage fried rice NO taste buried with soy sauce to eat Stay away

DOI270hLab7lPk4rkrIy2w.text: Well, having just recently having gone to the epic Din Tai Fung chain, I wasn't enamored with PPP. It was probably a little less expensive, but the flavors didn't pop quite as much, the quality shine the same way, and the service wasn't very attentive.   I had hot tea and they didn't have honey only sweet and low, kinda odd. We ordered some dim sum, a Shrimp noodle dish my guest picked out, and Chilean Sea Bass with some sort of fried glaze around it, which made an already oily fish very greasy. Don't get me wrong, the cuisine wasn't terrible, but I guess I'm just recently spoiled from DTF.   Sorry, didn't take pictures. It was a business dinner and I felt weird about snapping pics throughout the meal. I'm such a bad, bad, bad Yelper! Nothing noteworthy missed though.

Sd3mDiwahOFpk7-ZOo6tfA.text: Service here is shitty. Ruined my day. I asked the waiter to bring me some vinegar for three times. It probably takes an hour for them to bring me some vinegar. What should I say. and the food is not that good, and it's kinda pricy.

sPAe3f15QsrIIEIMXfCKDg.text: Yum Cha  Chinese breakfast aka Dim sum Quick service and good food Busy but clean I will definitely come back to this place

YPREbZeNmg-FDStEF0o5cQ.text: Went here after playing a couple of frames of bowling, it was past 12 and I am so glad that they are open late to get that midnight hunger taken cared of.   First off, I am very confused about what the other people is saying here about service since we have always been attended to normally. 2nd,  you come here for the delicious food and not the service. Ordered a couple of things, walnut prawns, some noodles, vegetables, and a couple of dimsum items. Everything came out fast as expected and everything tasted wonderful. As usual, at the end of the meal we are a group of happy stuffed people and will continue coming back here as often as possible.  Love the place, Love the food, Love the people! Carry on PPP!

so91WgilFnj6JQ0PHybCNA.text: You win some then you dim sum. One of my favorite Sunday morning meals. I have dim sum regularly and this is my favorite place in Las Vegas. They recently renovated making the restaurant a lot of fancy, classy, and larger (holds like triple what it use to) than before. The line for this restaurant can get long but it moves pretty fast. I don't remember the names of any of the dim sum dishes I got, but all the favorites are great here. I always end the meal with some egg tarts. Overall I'll continue to come here.

RUqDMYkP-502d6spO7hjfQ.text: I like the new remodel. This place is always consistent in the food quality. The service is hit and miss depending on who you get. It seems like it is always busy here. It is a real good Chinese food place on the classics. This was one of my spots for late night food after several cocktails ;)

w_z3kFQucIGrI-6p6NuOOg.text: We came here on a Friday morning with a party of 8 ppl and surprisingly we got seated right away.  We ordered a lot of dishes. I'm picky when it comes to dim sum. However, all the dishes I've tried here tasted fresh and not too oily surprisingly.   The only complaint is they don't have too many serving-carts while we were there. So we had to "order" several dishes that we wanted. So yes service was slow-or maybe we were really hungry. So don't come here with an empty stomach.  The porridge was really stand out to me. It has a very nice balance-not too bland. Portion-wise was decent as well.   Overall I would come back.
