0nViGUpKTbE7_8EwQiBu1w.text: Food was okay, but the noise level made it almost unbearable.......servers are not warning people about dim sum having seafood in it..................

N78cmLNLqA17ORw9zNunSQ.text: Being from the San Francisco Bay Area, the dim sum at this place rivals the best that San Francisco has to offer.  Hands Down, Shut the Door, forget about the fancy smancy pseudo way over priced dim sum the strip hotels offer.  Jump into a cab and go to this place located in the Gold Coast Casino.  Even with the cab fare, you still save big money and have world class dim sum.

HlXMTrQAbZ-zsZIzuTQapg.text: not bad at all as the dim sum was great and awesome.  We had a great time eating it which is great.  We enjoyed it a lot.  unfortunately they kept on forgetting our table which was bad that was the only bad part.  the food was not bad at all would actually come here again

LntT5jXpDdu02fxCSm8U9Q.text: My son is hooked.  He definitely wants to go back here and have their calamari.

3MHosdBC3r90WiABoSm-RQ.text: This is a great place for dim sum and dinner.  We had the usual shrimp dumpling, pork dumpling, chicken feet, etc.  The egg tarts were to die for.  They were steaming hot and the crust was so flaky but not greasy.  We also came for dinner which was just as good.  However, prepare to wait for we came at 11 A.M. and waited for an hour on a weekday.  However, the service could be improved.

HPsiWBHGIxy4r_Dy88FRmw.text: I have eaten in Chinese restaurants everywhere and this place has definitely surpassed my expectations. Though I was waiting to see a hostess for a couple minutes, as soon as we (I plus one) were seated they took our drink orders and checked up on us a couple times prior to ordering food. Food was amazing (gobo beef, roasted pork belly, and shrimp fried rice) and service was great! Aside from waiting 3 minutes to see a hostess. Definitely not your typical asian business with good food as bad service. It was great service and great food!

Ye1082z-_jE2jJ69O4q3uw.text: I had read the reviews for Ping Pang Pong and although the food was always rated highly, the service was considered poor.  The food is excellent; the service was as good as it gets, the employees were friendly and concerned of our satisfaction.  Great dinner.

i-zawfkSFzxHJdup5e4sLA.text: The only dim sum I've had in Vegas, but it's done well at Ping Pang Pong! Okay yes, the name is pretty ridiculous and stereotypical to Chinese people, but don't let that turn you off! This place is pretty legit.  A lot of reviewers mention that the wait is pretty crazy, but I've came here on weekdays only and never had to wait for a table, so maybe it's only crazy on weekends?  All the dishes we've had were good, but we've only came here for dim sum, so I'm not sure (but curious) how their other food is.  Service is decent, which I'm used to at Chinese restaurants, so it's good enough for me!  Kind of shocked that this place was noted as the 'Best Chinese Restaurant of 2011'. Is nothing good in Chinatown then? Haha.

bTwFJDA7OlKJDamBxzCxGA.text: The food here is really good. I have never had Dim Sum before and I must say i am impressed. I came in for the Dim Sum lunch special where they walk around and show you the food and if you want it you take it and they mark a small ticket. The food was delicious and the service was very freindly. I would definitely reccomend.

n2MoTracTgHefF4XxrD6yA.text: Have read so many mixed reviews about PPP from my fellow Yelpers in Las Vegas, and I finally went to try it with some schoolmates and guests.  The line wasn't too bad for us, and we were seated shortly, even though it was on a Sunday at ~11:30am.  The restaurant itself seems small, especially compared to the other dim sum options i Vegas.  The price overall is more expensive, and is to be expected for a restaurant located inside a casino (Gold Coast).  The per person charge for tea is only $0.50!  That is the lowest I have ever seen, even compared to off-strip dim sum joints.  But then they do make it up on everything else you can order.  The wait staff is friendly, but I think they are assigned way too many tables to watch over, especially the busperson, since our emptied plates rarely gets picked up after we finished whatever dim sum we had ordered, and the table looks like it is in a constant state of disarray. Not exactly adding to the mood of the meal. But our water glass was refilled on a regular basis, which is good. That applies to the tea pots as well.  Food-wise, I think it is just okay.  There were some highlights but also many that was not worth ever trying again.  The Panfried Shrimp and Chive Dumpling was excellent. The "fat noodles" stirred fried with XO Sauce (my pinyin sucks but I will try to type it... Stir Fried ChanFun with XO Sauce) is good and we ended up ordering two plates. HarGow (Steamed Shrimp Dumpling), was made with great fillings, but the skin was way too thick and you can tell that the cooks or prep cooks that make them lack the skills normally developed over many years of making dim sum.  But what do you expect from a casino restaurant that might have a really good chef, but the rest of the kitchen are cooks, prep cooks, etc that are just happy to still have a job in a state that has stupidly high unemployment rate.  Anyway, back to the food. They seem to have trouble keeping up with the demand for the essential dim sums (steamed shrimp and steamed pork dumplings), since we didn't see the Hargow until we were almost ready to get them to tally up our bill. And the Shuimai never made it to the area we were seated until we were collecting money from everyone at the table.  I did kind of enjoyed their Green Tea Mochi Cake, although the mochi was on the thick side. But I have never had this at any other dim sum restaurants in the US. The Mango Coconut Tapioca was good, according to my friend (I didn't try it).  And even though we have a party of 8, they did NOT automatically add in the "mandatory" service charge/tips.  I think that was cool, but we paid over the 15% anyways.  Overall, just a 3 stars dim sum experience for me, and I will likely not returned for just dim sum. But it is nice to eat at a dim sum place that at least have above average customer service.

v0KUeNqqYRYHMVYhFp8CFg.text: Omg  people don't ever eat here..  You will be disappointed.. If u want dim sum go to Rio hotel kj restaurant it's really good and cheap...  This ping pang pong I tried it  to compare  to other place I was sooo  disappointed...  It's soo  expensive and taste  nasty..the dim sum suppose to be hot..  But these food are really cold... I don't mind expensive but it's worst dim sum I ever ate...  They said best dim sum in the world..  They fool  you..  Don't believe me? Go try  just one item from here and one item  from kj restaurant u will know what talking about...  I still  have the nasty taste in my mouth...

PA_RVm7SeSVbIKhX70Y07A.text: Apparently this place has been rated Vegas' #1 Chinese restaurant a number of times and I know why! Despite being tucked away in the Gold Coast casino this place was packed with Chinese & English speakers alike.  My boyfriend and I got the pot stickers which were incredible. The filling was way more flavorful and, well, filling, than other pot stickers I've had. Every bite had a nice amount of it. We then shared the Night Market Fried Rice. Holy macaroni! A substantial plate of rice with a good amount of beef in it for $10?! The ingredients were fresh, providing a taste that was less heavy-laden than most fried rice. The beef was fresh as well - beef can sometime make my stomach go topsy-turvy, but it didn't this time - indicating quality beef cooked properly.  I wish this place was in my hometown. I'd like to visit them regularly.

34NCA9EJHyLC4YYZ_H9GNw.text: Yummy dim sum every time. Love the dim sum carts instead of ordering each dish. Note - dim sum is limited hours (for lunch only).

3tN6rJZr8_1IyDLHk2nnVg.text: I live in New York .and  don't usually do Chinese in Vegas . A friend told to try ping pang pong. I must say this authentic Chinese food the Quality are good and the service was awesome

bCursd8muLW30tboSD2cbA.text: Great Cantonese food! Open late for all the night owls and the food is above par for the price. They renovated the place and looks substantially better. I recommend for sure!

UuADuQoA6k7vgDt5peZ7Ow.text: Love coming here!  Food is always good, Mongolian beef, Kung pow chicken and fried rice are our go to dishes, consistently good.  Service was good as well.

EqHiIbsFJBzEyrHSYWzauQ.text: Ping Pang Pong is an authentic dim sum restaurant, located right off the strip. I recommend coming here as early as you can, it opens at 10am and the line starts to get crazy around lunchtime.  Everything is delicious and our favorites are the flat rice noodles and the BBQ pork buns. There's also these triangle shaped dim sum filled with beef which are amazing! It is so convenient because these carts come around to each table, filled with all the dim sum and as you select each plate, they add a stamp to your table's sheet. Definitely a must for every time we are in vegas!

ueh3P9pcl4goowMcDVOB4g.text: Very bad service !one of the cashier wear the glasses she is too rude,and so mean too my son(my son only 7years old)

M3Wku9okT3blgFptv4mSoA.text: Unbelievable for a cai-lang dish for $10. We will never come back to this restaurant.

kMqROC7Pj7rEWuR3GeUanQ.text: My favorite place to come and sit down for some delicious dim sum!  Best dim sum in LAS VEGAS!!!

yFT6WTe9QpabpUt0VYMWeQ.text: Located inside the casino.  We came on a Sunday and didn't have much of a wait (maybe 15 minutes).  We were approached immediately and offered water and a pot of hot tea.  The carts then started coming by and we were thrilled by the options.  They have several types of rice noodle including flat rice noodle with shrimp, beef, or Chinese donut.  We enjoyed everything we sampled but our absolute favorite were the desserts they had pineapple bun, sesame balls with red bean, and egg tarts.

I9vc0XPL8I0jPV5s7CvF5w.text: Food was bland, nothing to write home about. We were expecting better because it is Las Vegas! Not many dimsum choice too. I will go somewhere else for my next trip.

7aRYW5yZXOJMYtespjgUpA.text: Avoid this place...do yourself a favor....run to another establishment...now...seriously...7/11/17, Tuesday afternoon, waiting on the to go line for at least 11minutes.    Then, a team member states she will notify the front that I'm waiting to place my order.  Well, honestly, I don't think that happened because I took the initiative to go to the front team members and indicate that I'd like to place a to go order.  She gives me a menu that indicates dim sum associated with letters.  Then, I ask what do these letters indicate?  After, she hands me another menu with pictures and numbers.  I ask her how does this work?  Then, I asked the other lady at the front how do I know how much the dim sum with the numbers cost?  She indicates that the menu with the dim sum and letters are invalid.  So, the menu with the pics and numbers, how do I know how much the items cost?  She mentions oh just ask me.    What?  In other words, you could rip me off with no basis?    Total wait time + ordering + verifying the menu, prices, etc. = ~45min.    With that said, I highly recommend a revised dim sum menu with correct prices displayed for the customers' and establishments' maximum efficiency, time, ease, respect, and ethics in food service management.    Plus, I recommend more staff training accommodating those waiting to dine in, to go, and pay their bill because after observing this establishment while waiting for to go service, it seemed like there was a lack of communication between team members that was very obvious, no team work, and lack of organization.    In conclusion, I highly recommend the general manager, staff, and anyone involved in running this establishment to review training in customer service, food service management 101, and menu development.

gvGomwe6Yp3vezWYjogALQ.text: This place is small so often times it requires a wait.  This is the 2nd dim sum place i've tried in vegas and was not disappointed at all.  Between the two of us, we ordered a bunch of traditional dim sum dishes including chickens feet =).  It came out to be about 15 a person I believe and we were both stuffed!  My favorite dish is probably the pork and preserved egg congee.  I was surprised at how good it was!  Could have eaten that whole bowl myself.  The Siu Mai (pork dumpling)  and Ha Gow (shrimp dumpling) satisfies my dim sum craving.  The banana leaf wrapped rice was good.  The tofu skin roll and spare ribs also tasted delicious.  I think I Iiked everything except for the tofu pudding I got at the end.  You can definitely tell they made it from some processed powder in a box.  Was not freshly made.  Service is good.  Since the place is small they only have so many carts pushing around.  Some servers were nicer than others but overall I would definitely come back.  This is better than Orchid Garden in chinatown.   Although it has a terrible terrible name, its my favorite place in vegas so far.  Its located inside gold coast so just walk around the casino and look for it.  Wait times can be long during weekend brunch but I think its quite worth it.  If you've been to many high quality dim sum places...it won't compare.  I definitely think SF and LA has way better spots but I live in Vegas now so beggars can't be choosers.

Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

MXuZye6oAjudzUM-SZgk6w.text: Favorite dim sum spot hands down. Fresh (if you get there when it opens), non-greasy dim sum, and quick service! I love their shrimp dumplings, deep friend flounder, and watermelon juice.

iq_IlEZTde-NitT6YAGHwg.text: Wow excelent chinese food, the better food I've tested, the service is super good and fast... 100% recommended.

U1OjmFy6Y_rSWkfhwB0-6A.text: If you live in Vegas or just here for a quick trip,  add Ping Pang Pong to your bucket list. The food is exceptional and the staff is extremely accommodating.   A couple of my favorites include the fried shrimp rice and cashew prawns.

CMI588K2G6O-9fBZrLNuhg.text: Honestly the best dim sum I've ever had. I went late night so I could only order off of the regular menu and not the full dim sum but still!!! The shu mai and shrimp and green onion were the best I've ever had!! I'll most definitely be back to try the full extensive dim sum because by the look of all the pictures, it looks incredible.

ND_XxQanzYsl9p_vY2YbKw.text: "the bomb . com" is how my friend described this place when she took me; she was right! Their dim sum is phenomenal -pork buns glazed with honey, shrimp in practically any form imaginable, and fantastic mango pudding for desert. My fav though were the pork spare ribs (my mouth is watering just thinking about them). Just be sure to come early since they get busy pretty early.

7k7_3Frtdgbs_YzheW1huw.text: There's a line to get into the restaurant. All guests in your party must be present before your party may be seated. It's important to let the hostess know how many people there is in your party. For drinks, they provide complimentary tap water. However, there's a flat fee per person for a pot of Chinese Restaurant Tea. The dim sum was delicious. However, I didn't like how the windows on the dim sum cart weren't very visible. I felt that the dim sum could have been more presentable!  We got the following:  1. A bowl of steamed rice topped with chinese mushroom, diced chicken in bone, and ginger. It was served in a tall wooden bamboo looking container. It came with soy sauce on the side. I felt that the rice was a bit bland. I didn't like how the chicken had small little bones.  2. Eggplant topped with shrimp in black bean sauce. It came in 3. It was tasty but on the oily side.  3. Pan Fried Sticky Rice Cake filled with Red Bean Paste on a round banana leaf. It came in 3. It was crispy on the top, sweet and savory.  4. Steamed Beancurd Wrapped Tofu Ball topped with English Peas, Corn, and Chinese Mushroom.  5. Steamed Crystal Shrimp Dumpling. It came in 4. I liked how there were big pieces of shrimp and no fillers in the dumpling.  6. Steamed Fish Paste Ball, which came in 3, consisted of fish paste, coriander, diced Chinese sausage, topped with a gojiberry, and over a bed of enoki mushroom.  7. Steamed Roast Pork Buns, which came in 3 and were fresh from the oven.  8. Chinese style Crepe filled with crispy dough and shrimp and topped with soy sauce and scallion.  9. Steamed Beef Ball, which came in 3, consisted of beef and parsley, served over a bed of beancurd, and drizzled with A1 sauce.  10. Steamed Sticky Rice with sausage, scallion, egg, and dried shrimp. I was surprised there wasn't any Chinese mushroom.  11. Egg Custard Tart. I liked how the crust was slightly burnt!

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Steamed Sticky Rice
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Steamed Beef-Watercress Ball
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crepe with Fried Dough and Shrimp

PowRfMpR_bU2CTGNSTGvKg.text: This place is amazing! We went on a whim for dinner and we were blown away everything we ordered had so much flavor! The next day we're thinking about going again and it's open late.

5uEqOCXix2J7hSMQdD4SGQ.text: very friendly service.Food is good.Price is fair. I do   recommend this place.I will choose this restaurant again next time.

oB0iYqyahSi7n5pG-SZskg.text: This is an updated review of Ping Pang Pong. I try to visit whenever I am in LV. PPP used to be a hidden gem tucked in a corner of the Gold Coast casino. Now, it is literally the centerpiece piece of the casino. I was told that it moved to the new location around May 2017. The new digs are a far cry from the old school, Chinese kitchen that gave it so much character. The new restaurant feels like a corporate sell-out, but I'll keep an open mind.  I dined with three work colleagues who were less familiar with dim sum. They are adventurous eaters, and seemed to enjoy the experience. We tried all the traditional dishes, and I thought everything was very good. Two dishes that really stood out to me were the sticky rice and the shrimp chow fun. I thought these were some of the best EVER.

JW6ll9qoQTREVnATZaKTxQ.text: Probably the best Chinese food I've had here in Vegas. Although, it is quite expensive. We got the Chilean Seabass which was my most favorite dish. Secondly, the salt and pepper pork chops is the best tasting chops I've had in a while. Third, the seafood noodles is always a classic and was very delicious. Last, the Chinese broccoli had a very strong ginger seasoning, but was good nonetheless. The only con I have is that all of this cost about $75 dollars for the 4 dishes. I most likely won't be eating here too often, but I consider it one of the best Chinese spots in the desert.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Seafood noodles, Chilean seabass, Chinese broccoli &amp; salt and pepper pork chops.

S3KYVPWohI1li9yVbnOa9A.text: This is an okay place for a typical Dimsum.  The price is rather cheap and they give large portion.

YBnwObvQqXagR8hjAWatiA.text: I normally don't post any reviews.. but I want to save you your money and time! Don't eat here!! This place is terrible! Service and food terrible! Not authentic dim sum.. we ordered duck and it was served cold. They took and said they will heat it?? They brought it back it was dry! We asked for hot mustard, and they only have one type.. honey mustard??? Who eats dim sum with honey mustard??  All the dim sum we got did not taste fresh! We also ordered won ton mein... it was very bland and the wonton tasted sour ewww, cup of noodle taste better than that! Staff were every rude. Didn't get a refill on drinks and prices were outrageous for the quality! I wish I read the reviews.

zA1z5oHxvNrnPmcn239WQg.text: My parents and I went there for lunch on a Monday. The dim sum that they serve is quite tasty. The variety, however, leaves quite a bit to be desired.   Mom enjoyed the chicken feet, dad the baked pork buns (I thought it was a bit too sweet). We also had har gow, pork ribs (yum!), red bean gelatin dessert (this was good), red bean buns (my dad was desperate for food by this time). Service was good - prompt removal of plates, refilling of tea pot.   It's super noisy there. Near impossible to have a conversation across the table. This is most likely a Las Vegas casino complaint (?), but the entire restaurant smelled like an ashtray. I'm sensitive to smoke, so this was a less-than ideal eating situation.   The bill, for three people (two elderly people in their 80s and one female) was $60. That is stratospherically high for people who don't eat much. And the smell. It was awful. Will not be visiting again.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken feet. Mom chowed down on these. Picture taken after mom had a few feet.
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Rice noodle something or another. Good. Nothing out of the ordinary.
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Red bean gelatin dessert. It was yum.

-ArpCWgaz1KpkTO8PuFRAA.text: A mixed bag, I recall that it was much better pre-renovation and they raised their prices.  Good news is that you can use your Bconnected (Boyd) points.  The roast duck had the right amount of seasoning and was decently tender.  However, the biggest flaw was the skin was soggy and not crispy at all.  My dad made roast duck at the now closed Mini-Garden on Hotel Street in Honolulu Chinatown so I know that this a big no no.  Amazingly, if you are looking for a good roast duck, the Caesar's buffet is where you will find it.  The won ton noodles soup broth was spot on, without the usual massive amounts of msg and was infused with the a perfect amount of white pepper.  Won ton was ok, but the noodles was either overcooked or poor quality (not enough egg used), as it was too soft and not enough hardness like the ones you get at Louie's Noodle Shop (you can buy their uncooked noodles nearby on Reno Ave).  The san pan tiger prawns was a big disaster.  Description was it was in shell with "aged soy sauce with garlic and shallots".  Not even close, looks like they used the leftover shrimp from their hau gau and stir fried it.  The only saving grace from being a two star review is the enoki mushroom fried tofu with pickled cabbage.  This is an excellent dish, the tofu has a nice fried exterior with a soft inside.  The enoki mushrooms and the pickled cabbage provides other complimentary flavors to the dish.  Perhaps trying only their dim sum is a better option.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Enoki mushrooms tofu with pickled cabbage.
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Roast duck

ShNtHMgg_-ZcOJNgKIQEwg.text: This is only a dim sum review. Seems like other Yelpers have noted dinner options aren't as great. As far as dim sum goes though, PPP is solid. Nice restaurant and ambiance and I like that they do dim sum old-school but with new touches (i.e. rolling carts that are well-lit and encased in clear 'showcases'). The dim sum dishes are really good. Some favorites: char siu bun, stewed beef offal (pair this with rice porridge with a thousand year egg for maximal enjoyment), and their take on the youtiao ("fried oil stick")/cheungfun combo, using prawn/shrimp paste as a filler, surrounded by a youtaio-like covering and then the cheung fun wrap mixed with cilantro... that's a killer and my personal favorite. Some solid sweet dim sum options but my favorite will always be the classic tofu fa, which they do serve here.  Worth walking through an otherwise underwhelming, cigarette-smoke-smelling, old-fashioned off-strip casino.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

K9aC2yqFFI4fVEct-th4Ig.text: The only thing that made this place a 2 star versus a zero star is that the food was delicious. We went in for an after graduation celebratory dinner late Friday night and were so excited because it was completely empty and we had a party of 17. Soon we would find out why it was empty. They put two round tables together. The food came out promptly after being ordered, but then we never saw our servers again. We had to go look for her when we needed drink refills or to order something additional. We even had to find them to get our check. I realize with a group of our size gratuity is automatic but I definitely felt cheated because it was not earned. All staff were very short and seemed bothered by our presence. I did not speak to a manager at the time because it was our daughter's special night but I have no intention of going back and definitely will not be recommending this place to anyone. It's to bad because we enjoyed the food.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

CR48trT0-osYEKQnSABpQw.text: I don't come here for the dim sum (although it is delicious), I come for the mao po tofu. This place seems to be the only Chinese restaurant that makes it authentically with szechuan pepper corns. Perfect for a rainy day.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Best mao po tofu in vegas. They use szechuan pepper corns for an authentic taste. Also  their pork shumai is legit!

b-m29gJVxs_ki3UDBgNzwA.text: #5 of today's "OMG, HOW HAVEN'T I MADE IT HERE SOONER" day of reviews.   Being the crotchety impatient hangry monster that I am and usually only having time for dim sum on weekends, I've mostly avoided Ping Pang Pong so as to not have to go out to the almost-strip and wait in an impossibly long line.   Fortunately, I was able to try PPP for a quick snack between the 1pm and 3pm bingo sessions. As it was almost time for the kitchen to close, we were seated immediately and swarmed just as quickly with carts of food.  The swarming froze of my girlfriends into a sense of panic, but that eventually faded when the food was ordered and the dim sum-slangin ladies directed their attention elsewhere.   I was a bit concerned about the quality of the food since we arrived right at about closing time. However, all of the food was delicious. We focused on seafood and vegetarian/vegan items to accommodate a few dietary needs at the table. As I've said time and time again, Asian food is kind to the diet-restricted.   The egg tarts were outstanding. I haven't had a good one in a while and appreciated how warm and buttery PPP's were.   This meal was the perfect snack for a group that hadn't eaten lunch who also fully intended to have another round of drinks at the 3pm bingo session.   Can't beat dim sum for a quick, cheap, but satisfying meal.

sDLlDj6MvxwJOvAe38JXhg.text: First of all note that portions are family size style not individual portions. So it looks expensive but it is not so expensive unless you are by yourself and have to eat 1 full portion.  Very quick friendly service. Clean place with nice ambiance. Extensive menu. My spring rolls were very good and I made a mistake with my butter scallops entree  I wasn't thrilled. I saw many other good plates at other tables. :( totally my fault.   In the end I enjoyed the experience and would go back knowing better what entree I would like to eat.

QDzZk3zTWqUQ3AOQNhcMkQ.text: Decided to write up a review after eaten here about a dozen times!  Food here is as authentic Chinese as you can get!  Located in the Gold Coast Hotel/Casino,  just blocks away from "Little Chinatown", this place has some of the best wonton noodle soup around!!  Wontons are a good size with an awesome flavorful pork mixture.    If there's one dish that I can eat for lunch and dinner, it's the crispy roasted chicken... 1/2 chicken roasted so the skin is just a little crispy and the meat is just infused with this braised sweet chili soy sauce.  Pair this over steamed rice and I'll salivate over this every time!  Every restaurant has their take on orange peel chicken... and this dish is done well here.  Chicken is lightly battered, deep fried and lightly coated with a fragrant sweet orange sauce.  You won't find a pool of orange goopy sauce on the bottom of the plate!  If you're going to make a trip to a chinese restaurant near Spring Mountain Road, Ping Pong Pang is just a couple blocks away and is definitely worth going to!

ibLHet8vaRqIX3s-snK1eg.text: Wow! I have walked past this restaurant probably at least 200 times. I've heard that it was one of the best but really took no interest.  I came to Vegas on this trip with my best friend and her hubby. They wanted to eat here and now wished I had come sooner.  We ordered three dishes, the combo fried rice, orange chicken and Kong Pao Chicken.  All where served family style and was plenty for the four of us who ate.  The orange chicken was excellent. It didn't have to much orange sauce and tons of batter. It was perfectly cooked and I loved the taste.  I will be coming here again and trying a few of their other dishes I eyed.

The seafood clay pot and walnut shrimps are excellent and on point...

4d9PriB3QUuvGbQYja0U0Q.text: Been here for the first time in 2013 after they were named by Travel + Leisure magazine as "One of the Best Chinese Restaurants in the US  2013".    We thought not. Best Asian Restaurant in Vegas 6 times.  Yes, 6 times.  6 TIMES!    Seriously, though? (SMH)

rROyA04Ack7xR-KxWy-9cQ.text: Dimsum was not bad, but some items like porridge were not served hot. It was lukewarm. Curry fishball dish was excellent!! Overall we spent $100 for 4 pax. Pretty decent meal!

iObUihsls0KEk7zVhMMGcw.text: I be coming to this place even before it was renovated and always enjoyed the food. Customer service has never been on point but I feel is more of a cultural thing. I came here again on 7.20.18 and I have to say that the quality of the food has decreased. I never minded the poor customer service but since the quality of the food has changed I decided to write this review. I will come here again whenever I come to Vegas but either that will be the last one or I might have to adjust this review. I sincerely hope they step up their food quality game as I gave up on the customer service a long time ago.

Ih6-nbtNRcaN7kLW7otnPA.text: This review is for 3.5 stars.  I came here on a week night at about 6pm looking for some good Chinese food.  Ping Pang Pong is located in the Gold Coast so I expected the price to be a bit higher than normal but was actually pleased as it was very consistent with other sit-down Chinese restaurants in town.    The portions are very big here and very fresh.  They are known for their dim sum so I had to at least try some of their dinner dim sum to give a True review.  I had the pork buns dim sum, lettuce cups, and BBQ pork ribs.  Add in a few drinks and the bill came out to $44 after tax.  The pork bun was just eh.  I usually like the steamed bun but this came with a dessert-type of crust which caught me off guard.  Tasty innards, but not much going on in the way of a dish.  The lettuce cups were quite tasty and I actually recommend them as a nice appetizer.  Finally, the BBQ ribs were average - still can't find an authentic Chinese BBQ char siu in town.  The meat was good but not much flavor.  And the bone was so large that there wasn't much meat on each cutlet (though there were many ribs on the plate).  The dish came with some boiled peanuts which were a nice addition to the meal.    Service was all over the place.  I'm not sure if it was busy or what but the waitress would disappear and then show up and take 6 orders before returning to the kitchen.  So your order wouldn't be placed immediately, rather you have to wait until her rounds were up.  Very weird way of doing business but the food came out quickly and we were in and out quickly after just waiting a long time to place the order.  Ping Pang Pong is good Chinese food.  I prefer local when trying Asian cuisine in this town so I won't be back, but if you are staying at Gold Coast or nearby and don't have a car, and are craving non-American Chinese, then give this location a try.

hlz9turG9O5Zy97iYmXzDg.text: Having a family member who gambles through the night til the sunrise means comps and free food. We frequent here because other dining place in Gold Coast Hotel sucks so bad and Ping Pang Pong is the only decent place besides Noodle Exchange (their beef combination noodle is yummers!  but that's besides the point).   SERVICE Service is terrible. Servers here are slower than a turtle. However, I do want to talk about their cleaning guys (two brothers). They clean dirty dishes and wipe tables like there's no tomorrow. Holy moly. They could easily win 1st place at table cleaning contest if there's such thing. It's worth watching them while your servers takes her sweet time getting your orders.  FOOD Some of my favorites that I get every time:  Sea Bass Hot Pot ($19.95)- it's one of their secret menu. Mainly tofu and fried sea bass with lots of garlic. Little bit pricey but worth it. Yum yum.  Walnut Prawns ($13.95)- fried shrimp with sesame mayonnaise and honey-glazed walnuts. It's the ultimate fatty dish with lots of cholesterol but it's so dang good.   Tea Smoked Duck ($16.95)- roasted duck in a wrap with boison sauce on the side. I can eat this everyday!  Chicken with Black Bean Sauce ($9.95)- goes well with a bowl of white rice   Shanghai Noodles ($7.95)- stir-fried Napa cabbage, mushrooms, spinach and pork  Singapore Rice Noodles ($9.95)- noodles with light curry flavor.   Garlic Bok Choy- Always ask for extra garlic!  Last but most definitely not least, thier mango pudding. Comes with creamer on the side. They make fresh mango pudding here and it is the most flavorful and refreshing dessert. My family of 3 always order about 10 of these LOL   *dim sum here is alright. Much rather go to other places.   CONCLUSION Their service sucks but delicious food makes up for it.

QeJIYyEWlzgLamSln9dbzg.text: Poorest excuse to call this Dim Sum. Yelp rates this the highest in Vegas. Selection is sad, we have more variety in Utah with a much less Chinese population. Panda Express is more authentic.   Service was horrible, food was over cooked as it tasted like it was steamed many hours from yesterday's leftovers.  They kept pushing around the same 3 carts over and over with less and less of a selection. This is as authentic as Mexican food is to Taco Bell. I feel sorry for the people waiting in a long line to get in, normally with a big wait you would expect awesome food. I think most of the customers were from group tours or were offered free food for staying in the run down hotel/casino, as I can't picture anyone from Asia wanting to try this place.

D7Y7G6ldAxfJl4zUXG4EsA.text: This rating is strictly for service.  Very poor service, sat at our table for at least 10 to 15 min and no servers come to take our drink or tea.  We have to keep waving our hands to get their attention before one finally come.    We came during breakfast at 11:30 am.  If they can't hire more servers to service the table, they shouldn't be in the casino.

nlOydE4RiX8PUlU2usSuHA.text: One of the BEST fishes I have ever tasted. The Chilean sea bass 10oz is soooo good. A+ not even joking.

4IutLRig1J6vKIzaZdDiQA.text: First time and I very much enjoyed the food. Service was great. Very fast. Loved the dim sum although pot sticker appetizers were a bit undercooked - the dough was. Must try shu mai and the amazing guava green tea!  The server was very helpful and she explained what each dim sum plate was like. Will return!

gVOAxz67MQC7AJzwWwuDYg.text: First of all, great name. Not a big fan of the old and smelly casino it was in. But they do have dim sum carts. Mostly Chinese who do not speak English had a hard time asking if pork was in certain dim sum or not. I thought the shrimp noodle was the best thing I tried. Something was odd about the fact they didn't have our favorite, har gow. It was interesting that they had boba and Thai tea but I'm sure some people would like that. Not fancy not extra nice nothing compared to more authentic style dim sum found in chinatowns around the world. There was a mix up on our order and they brought us the wrong dish which we didn't get charged for. Management was helpful. Everyone who ate there right after started complaining of stomach pains and side effects of too much msg in the food too... hmm..

EMiG5V6RFVpbaYXiLJgq6w.text: Ping Pang Pong's name sounds almost like a racist joke... But besides that, I just don't really like this restaurant, and especially not for dim sum.   The wait to get in (especially during peak dim sum day which is Sunday) was about an hour for us but I'm sure it varies on the day. We sat at a table where we could see the line -- it was continually long up until we left at around 2pm. With all the waiting and the lines, you would think this place is really off the chain.   No! It wasn't. Food was mediocre and the actual restaurant is quite small. It seemed like the carts were scarce and we were constantly stopping the same carts over and over again. Price was decent but not worth the money for the so-so food.   I wanted to like Ping Pang Pong... Everyone, even locals, have told me this place is good but I didn't like it. I've heard people say Las Vegas lacks authentic and delicious dim sum places and PPP is not the place to find it.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Somehow the line was always long lol

C9oFxACt1C9KfSwAFzX37A.text: According to the locals in Vegas that we know, this is the best dim sum in town, and I'd say it's pretty decent. The roast pork (which I'd never had before), shrimp dumplings, and the green vegetable sides were my favorite dishes, and everything was at least decent. While we did not have a problem getting a seat at 11:30AM on a Saturday, our local friend told us that long waits are not unusual here so be prepared. The service is typical of dim sum places (kinda rushed), but generally acceptable. Prices were in line with dim sum in Los Angeles (i.e. less than the overpriced Strip restaurants). Overall, worth the drive to Gold Coast if you're in town and hankering for dim sum. And, still plenty of free parking...

KTcg9j6XeEH2itIQa-8Xcg.text: Ping Pang Pong, who would have thought that this would be one of the best locations for dim sum.  Hostess was not very welcoming and kept scolding us to stand inside the stanchion and to stay behind the line!  Not the greatest start, but luckily once I started eating, the experience took a 180 turnaround.  Located in the Gold Coast, this little Chinese restaurant serves up some mean dim sum.  So elegantly presented, each simple dim sum item takes Chinese dining to another level.  Delectable roast pork, cooked with a nice crispy layer of skin, thinly sliced and served with shelled boiled peanuts...what?  Who would've thought of that?  Then there was this super light custard made from egg whites served in a bowl and covered with a light pastry puff.  Who said dessert at the end?  We had to start with this popular dish before they ran out!  I kept saying I can't eat another bite and then another cart would come by with another beautiful dish.  They are so smart.  Even if you say no, they always unveil, just to make sure you know what you are saying no to.  Before you know it, one more dish added to our table!  Overall great experience and definitely recommend if you love dim sum.  I'm so glad I stood within the stanchion and behind the line.  Totally worth the scoldings!

Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Thinly sliced roast pork with boiled peanuts
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chewy Jin dui

2DTdzDR04EZd0YrSO75eSg.text: This is probably the most below average, mediocre dim sum place I've ever been with my (Chinese American) family.  The shu mai tasted like the frozen stuff you buy at a Chinese supermarket.  The white radish cakes (Lo Bak Gau) was cold and tasteless.  The egg rolls were cold and not crispy.    Also, the service is slow, and the prices are high.  Frankly, with so many other restaurant options, wish I had eaten somewhere else.  I would not go here again.

SgbM5F1X9v-l_wZCW6hRsQ.text: Pretty legit dim sum in LV.  Not sure why so many Yelp reviewers offered little useful info beyond, "Oh the food is really great here".     Here are all the facts and nothing but the facts --  * Dim sum in push carts till 3:00pm daily * Dim sum from menu 5:00pm until sold out. * Dim sum prices from $2.88 (siu mai, har gao, etc.), $5.99 (specialty items), to $8.95 (chinese broccoli).   * Free parking  You're all welcome!

3fms11_w_eMZz721rtaFRA.text: Good prices, large portions, darn good food. Best if you are not in a hurry and have 2 or more hungry people. It is located inside the Gold Coast Casino, off Flamingo not far from the strip.   I believe the whole restaurant closes for about an hour around 3pm. I would call to make sure it's open if close to 3pm. Gold Coast number is 702-367-7111  I took a star off for service. I've came here about 100 times over the last decade so clearly I like this place but the service should be better in my opinion. Sometimes the service is okay but other times it takes awhile just to get seated and you gotta wave them down to get refills. To give them credit many of the staff members are very kind and work hard.  Give them a try for sure, enjoy.

z3_tUbrb1hxb12qghp9P0Q.text: ***YELP 100 CHALLENGE 43/100***  In the many years we lived in Vegas, we never got the chance to visit this place even when we used to live in the apartments close by many moons ago. Last night we finally tried their dim sum and boy do I regret not coming sooner.  My mom got a $40 complementary voucher to any of their restaurants, and I thought what better time than now to try it. Nestled inside the Gold Coast casino sits this hidden gem. They have a separate line for to go orders which was really convenient and dinner rush hasn't started yet so it wasn't as crazy as expected, though there were a lot of people dining in already.   Their dim sum list isn't quite as large as some of the others in town so we tried all of them, some double orders. Each order was $3.88 if I recall correctly. Everything that we tried I liked, a lot! Their shumai and  Har gow shrimp dumpling was delicious, so was the shrimp with chives. The pork bun was one of the best I've had in town. They also had this bun that had lap cheong (Chinese sausage) inside which was very savory and mouth watering. For dessert we got sesame balls, coconut buns and mango pudding, all 3 were great. Their fried rice had great flavors but I didn't like the use of jasmine rice. I can't give 5 stars as I have not experienced dining there and tried most of their menu, but return visits are already in the works.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. $51 worth of dimsum

AMw4WPilXHxxaEdvOxYBSQ.text: Best dim sum!!  Wait is long but worth the wait.  Clearly this place is the best because all the Chinese go here.

cy8CDMsopdELkNiN73cWLg.text: It is a basic dim sum house. The food is good and there is usually something new to try. This time around the carts were moving kind of slow.We had to ask the manger where the sliced roasted pork was, he had it sent over as soon as it was done.   They are not really much on service. The food is good. Its great for groups and a sunday brunch. You can eat like royalty for 20 $ a person.   Will demo go back.

4KQmLkcXQcrCFq_70sbqzg.text: I was craving dim sum and it did seem like this was the highest rated place to go in Las Vegas. Unfortunately it was quite disappointing.  If you know of any better places for dim sum, please message me.  We arrived around 12pm and there was a bit of a long line. Luckily, it is a longer wait for smaller tables. We had a large group, so we were taken in immediately. Since they had more larger tables that were open.  There are two separate rooms on each side of the front counter.  There were plenty of carts going around, and service was good.  Although it was annoying that the cart ladies kept stopping only on one side of the table, alienating everyone else.  But they did have a lot of options to choose from, and had all our favorite dishes. But also unfortunately all the dishes that we assumed would be hard to mess up, were not great at all. Below standards for our taste. Probably a fast food dim sum place would taste better than what they were serving.  Quality was not amazing. Very mediocre.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Ylgn1mvObJt9vGEI4jCJjQ.text: The food was awesome. I went there during the lunch time. The ladies pushed the food carts were all pretty nice.

4U69wYE1-2a_rboc3k2Yqg.text: Dim sum close to the strip!  Prices are reasonable and it's open late.

v22lxLKlw-hxOQt_pyJVxQ.text: Needed a quick bite after drinking--these guys are open until 3am!  We ordered the salt and pepper calamari which was great--wished they were a bit more crispy but still satisfied my craving.  Also had the pan fried combination noodles with hefty amounts of meat and shrimp.  Reminded me of the noodles we get in SoCal.  Will definitely return.

SKb-3GRtUmqq7bHCFzbXDA.text: Chinese broccoli... $12???  The portions here at ping pang pong are very miniscule.  Typical dim sum really.  However, the service is lackluster.  Not the worst, but far from acceptable.  The multiple times I've come here on occasion I've noticed how most of the employees look like they HATE their job and the customers.  I've had the dishes flung upon the table a few times.  Relax lady XD. There are better places to eat, plus I dislike the line here.  They are pretty terrible at seating, many a time was there open tables and no one being seated.  Sigh... 2 stars because a 3 would be somewhere I'd come back to.

z-EdGlx3s1wYDYcHQ04WJQ.text: This place was rated the best Chinese in the country, not sure I would go that far, but i like the food nevertheless. I want to give this guys 10 stars so bad, but their service is just AWFUL, TERRIBLE (Like most of Chinese restaurants in town). Couldn't care less how busy they are, add more personnel dang it, customers should be your UTMOST focus.  11/6/17: Service is much appreciated now. Food is still great.

eW9Y0rAJ0KG5w-WgQ05iFA.text: Not great.  Not terrible.  We all presumed that a Chinese restaurant catering to what appeared on this night to be 95% Asian community would have hit all the right notes.  San Pan Tiger Prawns were very good.  Head, legs, and tail on.  Spiced just right.  Fried enough that legs crunched to powder and head held together and juicy.  Ma Po Tofu with Pork was edible.  Not good.  There were flavors missing.  The heat was right with Szechuan pepper.  Its just that no other flavors seemed present.  Lots of tofu not enough pork. Bland.  Noodles were completely tasteless.  Mo Shoo Pork was excellent.  No question.  It came as an appetizer.  Two large pre-filled rices pancakes.  At first bite i realized it needed Hoisin sauce. The next bite made me realize I needn't ask for it as it was already in there.  Wood ear mushrooms even.  Plenty of pork and veggies.  The price for all this was under $60.  Myself and two Partners-in-Dine would have been happier if the food tasted as good as those few dishes did.  When we were ready to pay our check there were no servers on the floor. We realized an entire table of six or seven eating dinner one table over from ours were the entirety of floor STAFF having dinner together.  We had to get up and pay at the register waiting in line behind several other diners waiting to pay their bills.  I think under normal circumstances we would have paid our server.  What happened tonight I am not sure.  I don't believe any of us were so in love or even like with our food that we would go out of our way to return.

U24HM5zULiY-pTKcSkIw3w.text: The best dim sum in the United States. I take all my business men there to impress clients. Each bite has a unique ingredient. Each bite has a rare taste. The shrimp dishes are all the best in Las Vegas, plus the dishes are reasonable. If I worked nearby I would eat at your restaurant four days a week

quW_dtK2bZ1wQX3W2qbKuA.text: Since my previous review, I've had several great experiences at PPP. The food is very good and cheap.   One of the best off-the-strip restaurants in Vegas.

QfETYmnWohlwulKd_G9qnw.text: Some of the best Dim Sum in Las Vegas.  They have a better than average selection.  It's fresh and tastes good. The ambiance is a little off - you have to walk through an especially smoky casino to get there, but it's worth it.  It's also kind of loud when it is busy.  Service is not bad, but what appeals to me is that usually I can get in and out within 30 minutes.

JqpzmXAsWoMhpO2LVKCjFg.text: Nothing special - this place is located in the corner of a smoky casino. The food was average - nothing really stood out to me as being particularly memorable.

C4bqKw6mVLcWTxSSoRQzuw.text: The best chinese dim sum restaurant in Las Vegas located inside the gold coast casino right off the main strip...highly recommend anyone visiting sin city and looking for good chinese style brunch to make a stop here...easy free parking but be sure to come early as it gets packed especially on the weekends...

6y0D_9wD84iwU8gzqtIrPg.text: I would say the best Dim sum in town. When they get busy sometimes food suffer. if you want to go for dimsum you should go early as there is a line.

obr0MaiKc_bKuF-MSbe17A.text: Our second day of $25 food credit, we decided to try the Dim Sum again here.    Our visit this time seemed better.  I liked the food and the service.  You can't compare this with all the Dim Sum restaurants in So Cal, but Ping Pang Pong gets the job done with some of the classic dishes; Ha Gaw (Shrimp Dumpling), BBQ Pork Buns (both baked and steamed), Sticky Rice Wrap, Salty Sticky Rice Dumpling, Sesame Balls, Porridge, Egg Tarts, Chiese Broccoli, Fried Shrimp Balls, and so on and so on.  It seemed like they had more varieties this time than I remembered.  It could be because we were there earlier than last time, too.    Do get there earlier than later or there will be a wait (and also they don't run out of your favorites)  since the place isn't very big.  The prices are fairly reasonable.  Most dishes are around $2.88 (for B dishes).   We tried to order enough to use up our $25 food credit and ended up packing some left over to go (ate it for breakfast the next day).   I've tried going to Dim Sum at the restaurants on Spring Mountain Road and it was almost impossible due to the wait time.  I'd much rather come here.  If you're in the mood for Dim Sum, give this place a try.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Coconut Buns, Butter Buns, Salty Sticky Rice Dumpling, Baked BBQ Pork Buns, Sesame Balls with Red Bean Paste
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pearl Rice Shrimp Balls, Shrimp Dumplings, BBQ Pork Buns, Porriage

8iye3kGWSbKLgSxZcLMHOw.text: Want good food BUT bad service? Yes?! Well this is the place for you then lol.   I have been coming here for years and I have to say I am pretty crazy for doing so. When visiting you have to expect to be ignored. I mean once you order and get your food all is good. If you'd like to order more or get a refill expect to wait. Why do I keep coming back?! Well I am completely in love with their Hong Kong style crispy noodles. & just as of yesterday I have fallen for their dim sum! I mean I ordered about 6-7 dishes during dim sum and it was only 10 bucks! If that was harbor palace at Chinatown that would have been a quick $20-30. Like I said though DO NOT have high expectations on service when coming in!!!

Y3eJ61EW1WELe0s-EW9M9A.text: This place was good, the wait was a bit long though. Food was amazing and came in large quantities. Although more items to select from might have made this review a 5 star, it was a great time. Nothing is really wrong with the restaurant, but I do not think it deserves the right to be 5 star.

QDrqXqYoSVg1jnVyOPuXqQ.text: I honestly love the food here. It's really loud inside and it's quite hustle and bustle but it reminds me of Hong Kong. The pork belly is the bomb

LTFw96engNME4G_5ABkAZQ.text: We've been here both for Dim Sum in the daytime and tried a few of their items at dinner...The food has been pretty solid. I prefer the quality of food here than other places we' ve tried(Cathay House, Orchids Garden)....Give them a try and see what you think....ALOHA!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Soft Shell Crab Rice Paper Rolls
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pan Toasted Noodles with Mixed Seafood
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tea Smoked Duck

k54GMMa6TIXcB_e_LgG8nQ.text: This place isn't the best dim sum place but its pretty good for the area. This place is rated #1 best dim sum by all the white people and asians seem to like it too. We went for dim sum Sunday at 11am. We got the last table before the long line began!   Service was really good. Shrimp har-gow was hot, fresh, and tasty. The shrimp noodle was delicious! The steamed pork buns and the glazed pork buns were good. The pork dumplings were tasty, although came with sweet and sour sauce (odd?). For the four of us, it was about $30. The hostess and cashier were very nice and attentive. The cooks were all old chinese men which was a plus. It looked pretty legit.  I will definitely come back when I'm in Vegas and craving dim sum. Food was good, prices were good, service was excellent! The place is pretty small and there aren't a ton of carts. I wasn't expecting much since its Vegas and there aren't as many chinese people here than in Cali. Since I came with no expectations, it was nice to leave full and satisfied. Tip: Go with another Chinese speaking person so you get exactly what you want. lol.

1RbJuRrKR-tvWsWuLCw2Ig.text: Customer service was blah. But food was good. Too bad the servers don't really know much about what they are serving. I enjoyed the food though. It does get very busy & the wait can be long. My best advice is too call ahead & see if there is a wait. Cool thing about this place is they do have dim sum to go!!!!!

LlBemcdzfkpHEaFipIP29A.text: I am very surprised that the dim sum here is good here!  I thought it would be bad because of the location.

aIR4AUy7H6je5fRZElN-FA.text: The food was good but as with most Asian restaurants service was horrible.  I had to get up twice to ask for the carts to go over to our side of the restaurant.  Seems like the cart pushers have now rhyme or reason to where they push their carts.  They kept circling around the other side where everyone had food already.

dWCRTZsybxQ9mTEdzxWXCA.text: Excellent food overall. Not nearly as good as Chinese places in LA. But more than enough to beat the smattering of places in Vegas Chinatown. We came here twice in our weeklong Vegas trip and nearly skipped Chinatown altogether. Dimsum is v good, but dinner dishes are ok, not great.

V96JcOcheNplTOTH6Ec5yQ.text: One of the better Chinese restaurants in Vegas. Ordered roasted lamb, duck, and noodles. Pretty authentic flavor, but nothing terribly spectacular.

ksHrCj1J5E6EGSHhJndk3w.text: Dim sum was good and fresh. Service was good. I thought it was on the pricey side 21 dollars for one person just seemed high.

rw8CpgxIskWUWIgDkGTiDA.text: not the best Dim Sum i ever had, if you have enough points at Gold Coast it might be worth it.

LIQcBQsxphscWDlU4_KMaA.text: Hands down the best dim sum in LV.  We used to go to what is now Orchid's Garden when it was still named Chau's then moved on to Chang's, and dabbled with Cathay House.  All of these restaurants would hover around 3 stars and dipped as low as being inedible depending on change of chefs and perhaps even ownership.  Then along came the idea of trying Ping Pang Pong inside the Gold Coast casino.  The litmus test for dim sum for me are the cheong fun, the har gow, the oven baked char siu bao, chicken feet, and anything with shrimp.  While the sauce of the cheong fun was very light, the noodles were soft and the shrimp were fresh. The har gow skin was soft and the shrimp again fresh.  The char siu bao was the right combination of sweet and salty.  Chicken feet were not too soft and not too hard.  Did I mention the shrimp were fresh?!  Yes, it's considerably pricier than all the other dim sum restaurants I mentioned but it's worth it.  And yes, it's also frigid cold like another reviewer said because that's how casinos keep you awake but it's nothing hot tea and a sweater can't fix.  And yes, it can get very crowded since it's actually a fairly small dining room for a dim sum restaurant, not to mention a dim sum restaurant in a casino known for its Asian clientel, but go before 11:30 am and you'll be fine since most are either at the gambling tables or are sleeping in from being at the gambling tables all night.

q_L0pmRXbLPvQir959EJVA.text: Not bad for the Gold Coast and I would come again.  Below average if comparing to So Cal.  Limited variety.  Decent taste, nothing offending.  Average prices.  Less quantity per order on some items - check the uploaded images.

d84kmJOMvMRcPe4fDehUYA.text: Went to Ping Pang Pong for lunch and had dim sum.  The food tasted fine, but the selection was not that great.  It is a small place, so the carts come around ofter.  The prices seemed pretty good.  Seems a bit cheap to charge for tea, but at least they have loose leaf tea.  Places that use tea bags and claim to be Chinese restaurants piss me off.  :)

UTXIy-ENcln-ZAeUqienDw.text: The best authentic Chinese food ever!!!!! This place is all quality, they even have authentic Mandarin chefs. I ate Kung Pow Chicken, Beef Flat Rice Noodles, Orange Chicken/Beef, & Fried Rice which were all superb. But I got to rate it down a little for the bad service from the waiters, you'll be lucky if they give you your check before you have to go to the counter & ask for it, they don't always give the complementary tea, & they charge for a small bowl of white rice. But other than the waiters the food is worth the hassle.

xj83uBgA8jyqjJXy5Nsahw.text: Food was o.k.  We went here at 130pm so food wasn't as fresh as we wanted ( as they serve dim sum up until 3pm.)    Temperture of food could have been hotter, but the flavor was there.  Not the best ,but not the worst, just ok.

QxyGw7dcQLNYSZH5-EjEfA.text: Not many selections, and the ladies pushing the cart doesn't understand English very well. First time trying a dim sum place in Vegas and I'm sure there are better ones near by.

XOjZJMEoeAM_2KgfYQcCXA.text: PUKE!!!!!!! Go hit Chia Town aka Spring Mountain Rd from "The Strip up to Decatur" and you are garunteed to have better food. Not to mention the waiter charged me twice for my melee which I discovered two days later looking at a bank statement. Went in to talk to the manager, he was nice. but was unable to help me. DONT EAT HERE

5DHewTKZsOuTHREKd4Ro3g.text: Food is pretty good but service is horrible. Got sat quickly and it took them about 15 minutes to ask what we wanted to drink, at the same we said we were ready to order and the person just walks away and another 15 - 20 minute wait on just order. So the order is put in for roast duck, fried rice and walnut shrimp. We start eating and drinking our sodas and no one comes by with refills so at this point I just want to eat and leave but nope. They just walk by and don't acknowledge us at all. So I had to get up and pay for the meal at the front desk and tell them straight up I'm not tipping them. The girl at the counter just looks and me and doesn't say anything at all. I will not be dining there at all in the future until they know how to treat their customers. I wasn't the only unhappy person either another table was pissed they couldn't order either. I hope they don't expect people to go back just because of the food. Order to go or something if you really want to eat there.

x8pVBDyj3z-5WhWCVEqOVw.text: This place is great. When we got there 1pm on a Saturday afternoon during a holiday long weekend it was busy. I am not sure if this was usual, but we waited for about 15 min which was fine. Its located inside the casino so there is plenty of scenery to look at while you wait. Doesn't matter if your really hungry, because the moment you hit your table hundreds of Delicious hot dim sum dishes are coming around your table to choose and ask what is what. All of the food looks so different and tasty so be careful when picking because its easy to overload your table with these dishes. lol All the food was incredible. The service was quick and efficient. We will definalty be back!  Oh and if you want to work some calories off after lunch or dinner, there is a bowling ally just upstairs from the restaurant! it was only 12 bucks for my hubby and I to play a game with show rentals!  Thanks Ping Pang Pong

EBmQSb3ZB5v17zkQuUm7Mg.text: OMG WORST SERVICE EVER. took a cab out from the strip bc of the great reviews.. should have just ate the noodle bar in caesars.   ordered a tremendous amount from the menu...i expected more dim sum for dinner but they only had a few selections and the ones we chose were out...  had chicken feet... i didnt eat but heard it was amazing. fried rice was dry. the dimsum we did have was good though.. chinese broccoli..i personally dont like so i cant really review it.. IMO, dont waste your time unless youre already tehre

BhaY8maDcBadtonbl2m6gQ.text: I've eaten dim sum around the world and Ping Pang Pong is right up there with the best of them.  The service was perfect and the food was delicious! We shall return!

inJSzqrGey5yr--8cF9F1A.text: Food is great.  Definitely must get the black pepper beef medallions.  Service is hit or miss.  Ironically enough, their actual servers, and especially bussers, give great service.  When they are busy or understaffed, and the managers step in to help, it goes down the drain.  They are slow, unattentive, and rude.  Eating by myself at Ping Pang Pong, a male manager waited on me one night.  After finishing my meal, I sat for 27 minutes (yes, I kept track) without receiving the check.  When I went to the front, where he was laughing with an employee, and asked for my check, he just rolled his eyes at me, and did not even apologize for the wait.

HTuUOnXxTxLkSNDcbvNwsg.text: I never ever thought that a Chinese restaurant is located inside the casino. I came here yesterday with a friend of mine to have dinner, We ordered walnut shrimps, beef medallion and Cantonese sausage fried rice,we had to wait quite long for the service, the food tastes good, I love the texture of fried rice, and definitely recommended.   the price is a little bit expensive compared to other in town, I heard that dim sum here is the best in Las Vegas, next time I will try then

gBBxMDtoJS8TETq5Ezohvw.text: Came again, although a little later than opening time.  Food still is authentic and really good.  We had a few unique dishes this time.  Kids love the place even though we actually don't do anything else at the Gold Coast.

O9trMAe2PySiLuCtZcVamA.text: I was pleasantly surprised wth the food and service at this place. It was definitely a place fill up and get your dim sum fix. Good price and fairly great selection of dim sum. Stop by here if you don't want to  dig deep in your wallet...especially if you've already lost most of it on the Strip.

UZq39rov3fBkXhr42XMgsw.text: Wow wow how come I didn't stumbled on this diamond in Vegas ?! The place is located in the Gold Coast hotel casino. We where just strolling along the blvd. and came in the casino. The place is very inviting and the service is top. We had some great dishes and I must say. Very impressed. Would recommend this experience to anyone. Will come back in a heartbeat. Keep it up Ping Pang Pong you must put your name out in the Vegas strip. The Alex was great keep it up man. 5 stars all the way.
