Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Great food

rN9FOuR69uS9LzQvWxFSRw.text: Long wait, on a Wednesday at noon. The food was lukewarm and mostly just okay. The duck was tough and rubbery.  Chang's Hong Kong is better, by far. I could try it again but I'm not optimistic.

rWOJGlyiaJwK1YKdfBVQbg.text: They FINALLY fixed this place up! Service was SOOOO much better and everything was tidy.  The food is always good here but I never went because the service was terrible.  Well, they upped their game! I'm so happy to continue going to this place again. It won "best of Las Vegas" every year, and they're living up to the standards. It's well appreciated and I'm so happy to once again get "the best" dim sum in town!

myZ5Lje6fkeCiVddx-77pA.text: Maybe because I am in Vegas and are fed up with resort-type pseudo Chinese food that cost a fortune so whenever I encounter a dim sum restaurant that's half-way decent, I don't mind giving it a higher rating.  Ping Pang Pong - let's just called it PPP - is also located within a Casino, namely the Gold Coast. The one big differentiation about this restaurant as opposed to others is that it's located far off the strip so the patrons are not visitors that just happen to walk by here. Most of the customers appear to be locals who drove here for the food.  For the most part the dishes are pretty tasty and fresh with high turnover rate. The roast duck was succulent, the salt and pepper smelt and the baked BBQ pork puff were delicious. We ordered a plate of stir-fried pea sprout greens and it was cooked just right.   One of the desserts was recommended by the restaurant and they are these red bean filled circular donut-like pastries dusted with granulated sugar. I find them to be overrated as the crust was dry and the filling was overly sweet.  Other than that PPP is a good place to go in Vegas for dim sum.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. An assortment of dim sum
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Donut-like pastries with sweet red bean paste filling

eFwm021Yb-VecUy9JDK-PQ.text: Came here with family and enjoyed a good Chinese meal. Egg Drop Soup, Manila Clams with Black Bean Sauce, Salt & Pepper Pork Chops, Mongolian Beef, Beef with Flat Noodle, Walnut Shrimp, Roast Duck and Chinese Broccoli was everything we ordered. Food was served in a timely manner and service was decent. We like the larger renovated space than where they used to be in the casino.

_0pz40D7dc-SgvFDTae0wA.text: Best Chinese food in Vegas so far that I've come across on.  Night market fried rice is pretty bomb! Salt and pepper pork chops legit also. Located at the Gold coast casino off the strip next to the Rio

ZtlDUvpvosunuk9K0-ulqQ.text: This really is one of the best Chinese restaurants in the country. They just moved to a better spot inside the Gold Coast Casino so they now have even more room. This place is a must, an absolute must!

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black Pepper Frog legs

idZXKhWNIqdwyUOLGX3JPA.text: Sooo they moved to a different location in the Gold Coast hotel. Really nice looking and the food was great. We had salt and pepper pork chops, young chow fried rice and chicken chow mein. Food was awesome I expected that but the service was awful. Oh my god. Usually the service is the greatest at Chinese restaurants but this place was awful. Nobody took our order even though it wasn't busy. Our server ignored us multiple times through out the night even though she saw us. That really dropped this rating down to 3. Food is really good though. Maybe it was just our server but I highly doubt it. It didn't look like management really knew what they were doing since there were what looked like 3 or 4 managers.

Q2Ha3b49WjGeIFEHfImfNg.text: Hands down the best Chinese for the price. Never had it  fresh and hot since I always get take out. A must try for locals.

RB30Z145IiikOKmR0r8xBg.text: The food was good and let our small Maltese in a carriage to be under our table.  But they mess up our credit card, so it took more than half an hour to fix it.  The second we went we make sure they don't mix up our credit card. I felt the first time we went, the dim sum was much better. Will try again if I visit LV.

k4oQLkTVA8HqUAqCIp9Igg.text: My bf bowls at the Gold Coast once a week and we were looking for something different to eat from the bowling alley snack bar.  We had the Honey Walnut Prawns, Orange Chicken, and Curry Pineapple Seafood Fried Rice.  The prawns and the fried rice were delicious, but the orange chicken was tough and difficult to chew.  The food was pretty expensive (+$50) for what we got, but it may have been different if we had actually eaten at the restaurant and not ordered takeout.  The girls at the register were not very friendly and seemed uninterested and robotic.  I asked a coupe of questions about items on the menu and the girl seemed inconvenienced by having to answer. I was told it would be 30 minutes for my food to be ready, but it took almost an hour!  Overall, some of the food tasted great, but the service was terrible!

B2T06PKAaP4a-wRDQa7SxA.text: First let me start by saying the food was great at this establishment piping hot and fresh crisp and succulent thats why i am giving a a ok rating .... my daughter was confirmed yesterday and we wanted chinese from a premier place here in sin city.... what i was not happy with and find quite concerning was the haphazard way the male staff brought out the food and passing over empty plates causing jamming on our lazy susans ... one young man put our plate of egg fried rice right in the middle of our lazy susan thus defeating the purpose of having it on our table.... while i noticed the tables with Asian clientele had plates taken off promptly and water was never lacking to be refilled.... I will go again but if i notice that amateurish behavior again i will recommend my non asian friends to go elsewhere

UK8Ms5lcMDKVk5Vq98greQ.text: I went in June based on a friend's recommendation-it was ok. Been to better dim sum places but it will do.  It was located in an old casino with low ceilings so prepare yourself if you dont like smoke while walking thru the casino.  The restaurant itself was bright n high ceiling with nice asian decore.  My husband n I arrived after 1 so our wait was not long but heard it normally is a long wait to get in.  I will go again next time to show my parents if we are close around but not a place i would go out of my way for.  Nothing on the dim sum menu stood out for me so i cant make any recommendations.

_bW6PwqlF_sri8zqJadcBw.text: This a great dim sum and Chinese restaurant. I like there lunch better than dinner time. The food is very good. I will definitely be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Garlic Shrimp
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sesame seed shrimp roll

T6MzGIgiWNGSwQ1hjnG85A.text: Pretty good place. I know it's been famous in Vegas for a while but I just never made it here. It looks nice new and clean after the renovations and remodel.   The staff was helpful, the food was pretty good and the price was decent.

tm40clxCzAhiaAYUI3Z57w.text: Went there a week ago. The best thing about it is the name.   Was ignored by the hostess, until she finally sat us. There was nobody else at the door.   We ordered the crispy chicken and an orange chicken dish. We asked for rice and they charged .75 per little bowl for what everyone else includes.   The chicken was what was left on the bone after they chopped off the meat to put into other dishes. It was just cooked chicken. The same taste as you could get at Costco, but without the meat.   The orange chicken was really tough. The worst I have ever had.   Do not waste your time going here. You would get better food at a take out place!

h8AwBF_y0OqKt9f1VJdj4A.text: This is one of the best Chinese food  I ever had . They give u big portion for reasonable price .

z9yRXtAKY_jM2w6K9TyKxQ.text: Inside the Golden Coast casino, we came here at 2pm after 15 minuets we got seats.Very good business ,we ordered a lot of dishes I love dim sum it's very yummy.I love this place full of strong Chinese style!

5WvymGkrabAqhX5L36ekVw.text: Yummy food but the service is very poor. I love the fried calamari it's very crispy and light batter. Great Dim Sum the pork buns are very good. Price is affordable.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

-BvrrHjwEdnnjY5sYOPTCw.text: Went here on July 4th with family for dim sum.  This is the first time we've been to the new location inside the Gold Coast.  We arrived a little after 11:00 am and waited over an hour before being seated.  I just wish the wait would have been worth it-at least the service part.  For the most part the food was above average (4 stars), but the service was horrendous (1 star).    Food We had the following:  steamed chicken feet (good), baked bbq pork bun (very good), shrimp hargow (very good), fried sesame ball (very good), steamed pork spareribs (most of the pieces had too much fat), eggrolls (2 plates half had holes and were burnt, but good), baked egg tart (very good-only 2 on plate but they were big), sticky rice in lotus leaf (only 1 on plate and pretty bad-way toooooo much soy sauce or whatever sauce is part of it), rice noodle roll with shrimp (very good), and bean curd skin (horrible-way too much meat-it didn't taste normal-almost dumpling like, no bamboo shoots).  Service For 3/4 of the plates we had, we had to flag people down get the food.  Once we asked for them to calculate our bill, it took about 10 minutes.  NEVER had to wait this long at any dim sum place to get bill.  Once I received the bill, I went to the front to pay.  There were two people up front handling the bills and payments.  No one was in line to pay but they were finishing ringing up the bill for another table.  I thought I would be next since I was just standing there waiting.  No.  One lady just started doing some other stuff, while I patiently waited.  This lady then went behind the screen and was given another bill and they processed this one before me-I'm just still standing there so I turned my back on them and looked out at the casino for about 2-3 minutes.  Finally, they said excuse me so I turned around and I thought that I can now finally pay my bill.  The other lady thought they were processing my bill, but the first lady said that it wasn't mine, so I had to wait another 30 seconds before they finally took my bill.  I don't expect very good service at Chinese restaurants, but the experience I had regarding the bill calculation and paying the bill takes my Chinese restaurant experience to a brand new low.

8g9N4lgBbSGg4E5R8nD5Gg.text: This is my absolute favourite Chinese restaurant EVER!  I like it so much I used the British way of spelling favorite. Imagine that! A 'u' right in the centre of the word!  I always get the Singapore noodles whilst restraunting (it's a verb, too) this place. My flavourite (coined a new word) dish is the walnut prawns.

14wVne7UCJUHj7Q1LYMrIA.text: Not a band place to try, been here several times.....  1.  Parking - A bit of a hike as you have to go to the Gold Coast Casino parking and then walk to the restaurant. So it is what it is. Not to bad, not too close.  2.  Ambiance - I knock off a star for it being or having a very odd feeling. It is kinda open to the casino floor, and it seems to be that the restaurant was stuck here, rather than designed to be here.  You have to walk through the smokey casino to get to the restaurant and then there is always a lingering amount of smoke from the people smoking outside the restaurant.  3.  Note - You have to go to use the casino bathrooms, which while they are not far at all, you still have to go through the casino. Not an issue if you are a casino lover.  4.  Food - Not bad.  The carts of dim sum did not seem to weave an order that I could detect.  You have to flag them down. The food itself is good, yet when you have to search out the cart , wait and wait it dampers the experience a bit.  For this I knock off 1/2 a star.  5.  Service - Not bad, but kinda like "we are busy" and "you should be happy to wait for a table" type attitude.  This type of attitude does not bother me greatly, however, it also does not endear loyalty and a pleasant experience. With so many great restaurants opening up that serve dim sum, they need to up their game.  What happened?  They used to be highly rated and I find them to be pretty good, yet not highly rated.  Worth a try for sure.

-0XI8OsoR-5pGADYQf8gGg.text: I was so adverse to coming to this place cuz of the stupid name for the restaurant until actual locals told me this place was one of the better casino restaurants for Chinese. Pretty damn good stuff.  I usually use my poker player points to pay for dinner here (side note..you want poker games with loads of reckless action..this is it!).    Never made it for dim sum here..only dinner but it sure is good.  We probably come here once every 2 months or so which is actually a lot considering all the choices Vegas offers.

TaWQBj5spU4vdHP3eZKUOA.text: I'm very disappointed by the dinner I had last night. We had to fall in line to get a table and once we were seated we were giving water and ordered the soup of the day and three dishes. The soup of the day was barely lukewarm, had no flavor, and was just meat, potatoes, and carrots. The salt and pepper pork chops had tiny bones that almost chipped my teeth variety of times and was also lacking salt.  The fried noodles lacked sauce and was very bland in flavor.   I also was restless the whole night and had diarrhea the following morning which is from the MSG that you put. I am not happy about the food you serve even if the remodeling makes it appear nice

x-Awy6EsRQ0ILIW0zblJjg.text: 3.5 STARS  Yay! It's hella Chinesey up in here!  Normally you can judge how good an Asian restaurant is by the amount of native diners. Vegas is no exception.  Ping Pang Pong came as a recommendation from my friend who lives in Vegas but he did warn me it's not nearly as good as the dim sum in SF..   On Sunday, 9.11.11, my friends and I came to PPP at 1 PM. It was about a 15 minute wait for a party of 7. The FIRST thing I noticed was the overwhelming amount of Mandarin and Cantonese speaking patrons; seemed promising.  FOOD Ladies push around dim sum carts and call out the dishes in Cantonese. They are more than happy to show you what's inside the steamers if you don't understand Cantonese.  We ordered the following (some in doubles): *Hai Gow (Steamed Shrimp Dumplings) *Siu Mai (Steamed Pork Dumplings) *Hai and Char Siu Cheung Fun (Steamed Shrimp and BBQ Pork Noodle Rolls) *Fung Zhao (Steamed Chicken Feet) *Ngau Yuk Mai (Steamed Beef Balls) *Jiaozi (Potstickers) *Deep Fried Shrimp Balls *Paai Gwaat (Steamed Spare Ribs) *Ngau Toa (Steamed Tripe) *Fu Pei Guen (Steamed Tofu Skin Roll) *Lo Mai Gai (Steamed Glutinous Rice w/ Chicken in Lotus Leaf Wrap) *Jin Deui (Fried Sesame Balls) *Char Siu Chow Fan (BBQ Pork Fried Rice)  The only standout dishes was the steamed tripe which was melt-in-your-mouth soft and the fried rice which was al-dente which bits of rich fatty pieces of pork (albeit a bit greasy).  The rest of the dishes were mediocre; they either lacked quality ingredients, were tiny (dumplings) compared to the norm and/or on the dry side. But when you're starving and there's a lack of good dim sum options, it sufficed just fine.  S E R V I C E Perhaps, I'm so use to rude service at Asian restaurants that I didn't find the service at PPP even the slight bit rude. Our waiter brought things quickly when we asked for it and refilled our waters promptly. This in itself is already a rarity in most Chinese restaurants.   A M B I A N C E / D E C O R With a name like Ping Pang Pong, it's no wonder that it excudes the typical stereotypical decor of Chinese village roof shingles, red paper lanterns and waitstaff in mandarin collared outfits. Most importantly, It was CLEAN!  With a plethora of dim sum restaurants in San Francisco, PPP would probably rank a 2.5-3 STARS in SF. However, considering Vegas has a scant amount of decent Asian restaurants and we left stuffed for only $15/person (including tip) they do deserve a better than average rating.

FYckYAPGRQtHJ0q6e5MxNw.text: We recently dined here for dim sum at 10am so we didn't have to wait for a table.  They serve traditional dim sum on a cart.  The place was quite small, which meant that carts went around to all the tables.   Overall, the dim sum was quite tasty.  The dishes we enjoyed the most were the assorted sweet and savory buns as well as the Shrimp Cheong Fun with plump shrimps.  The Sui Miu was tasty with the right amount of meat as was the tofu wrap.  There were a few misses.  The shrimp dumpling (har gow) was bland tasting shrimp with mushy, thick wrap. The Rice w/ Lotus Leaf (Lo Mai Gai) was mostly rice with minimal amount of meat and other ingredients.  The fried chicken wings were the worse with an odd mix of spices and too much grease.  We also ordered an item with rice and small spareribs. It was tasty but some of the ribs were fatty.  The dim sum dishes were inexpensive with dishes around $3 with generally tasty dishes and generous meat stuffing.

GDHACMqE7vwhi8jYPXF7dg.text: avoid this place as much as you can. we waited for almost 45min to an hour for our food and when we got it it's pretty much cold .. and i'm so mad to eat so i just end up just looking at the food and being disappointed .

Lrw0qVxs5HZdi79WYhNvXw.text: The wait is pretty long even when they opened at 10. I went at around 10:30 and the place is packed and a line. The dim sum here is good, but they don't have a big selection. Service is average for a Chinese place. Use your hand to flag the waiter if I want anything.

lJseBqnoOYeAqnuTv-h9_w.text: This is the place to go for authentic chinese food in Vegas. I dine here every time I visit Vegas, because the price is good and quality is good. Open late night, perfect for a night after clubbing.   MAKE SURE you order the lamb stew pot, comes with vegetable to add on after tasting the savory soup. The thing I like the most is the open kitchen configuration, you can hear the sound of wok, the breath of dragon chinese called. "rawrrrrr" that my friend  is fire stream out at a high temperature would sound. Like a big torch would sound. Mix with the ping ping sound of wok, the food come alive. Just something excites me. Authentic Cantonese cuisine demand good "wok haye" and able to hear it, it is just awesome.   Don't order the clam, menu said "Big", but it is really small clams. not worth 20 bucks. The rest can't go wrong.

QzMS8XYxAjxGe9dSRLc-3g.text: *Looks into restaurant and sees a butt load of Chinese people* Aw hell yeah, this place CAN'T be bad!!  A butt load of Chinese people in an Asian restaurant + a wait line = this can't be too bad!!  Okay so this place wasn't bad at all, even with the ridiculous name BUT it just doesn't compare to what I get in SF. =X BUT the food here was still fairly decent for a dim sum place in a funny smelling casino!   DIM SUM IS WHAT'S FOR LUNCH Like most dim sum places you have women pushing around carts full of food asking if you want any of this or any of that, what they serve here is exactly what any other dim sum restaurant in SF would have. The food was okay and for sure did not and could not compare to the dim sum I get in SF but the BBQ pork fried rice was the best thing we had that afternoon. I'm going to go out on a limb here and say it was better than most BBQ pork fried rice dishes I've tried in SF. =X  SERVICE Our waiter was quick, he took drink orders down (he memorized the drink orders) and a couple minutes later he was back with all the drinks! DAMN! Then we asked for BBQ pork fried rice, a couple minutes if not a minute later he comes back with it!   CONCLUSION I definitely wouldn't mind coming back here and who knows, maybe during my next Vegas trip I'll make a return. =)

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

eORNQepkGTmgPbnZhc3vew.text: I feel like dim sum is easy to do well. I have only had it a handful of times, and all of them seemed to have been equally as tasty and enjoyable. But I do not think that means it should be marked down. PPP has a pleasant enough atmosphere (especially for being tucked away in the Gold Coast), the service is spot on (by nature this almost has to be True with dim sum), and the food is tasty. Plus, there is just a fun element to the way dim sum is presented. There are no big surprises here, just dim sum done right.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Porridge. I thought only peasants in the Industrial Revolution in England ate porridge. Turns out PPP makes a killer porridge.

rzZdLYZa0mg9sJbirvfsgQ.text: This is an interesting name for a chinese restaurant. We had dim sum here for lunch and simply put : it was good. Better than some food we had at Chinatown in San Francisco.   The place is always bustling with activity while waitress with push carts go around to show you what's available. Just order from them directly :)  A few items to recommend : the Prawn Chee Cheong Fun , the Bolo Bao, cereal butter prawns, carrot cake, egg tarts.  Things to skip : stir fried bee hoon, Siew mai, har gao .  Please be aware that the restaurant is near the slots so be prepared to smell cigarette smoke spilling over into the area.  I recommend that you order chrysanthemum tea to go with your meal as it really helps to wash down well. Once you're done with 3/4 your pot, get someone to top it up to make sure it doesn't get too "thick".  Great place

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. There&#39;s always a long queue for dim sum brunch!
Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States. We ordered a feast!

_x3VHtp5Ho9_1Wgpcg3dlA.text: Driving down Hwy 15 towards Vegas, there are just so many billboards advertising Ping Pang Pong's dim sum lunch. We were getting hungry and after about the 7th billboard, we decided that dim sum it is. We headed straight for the Gold Coast Hotel and luckily we still had about 50 mins before the dim sum ended at 3pm.  Ping Pang Pong might be a catchy name to entice Mid-Westerners into the establishment, but in Chinese, this place is actually called "Golden Ingot" -- a form of ancient Chinese currency. It is 'jin yuan bao" in Mandarin or "gum yuen bo" in Cantonese.  We had to wait about 10 minutes for a table. After we were seated, the tea and water was promptly brought to the table. However, when it came time for the dim sum trolleys to come around, it took forever. We were starving. Surprisingly, when they did roll around, the quality of the dim sum was pretty good!! Much better than what we can get in Irvine. The chicken's feet was tasty, so were the har gow. In fact, the har gow were so good we got 2 orders.   Service sucks shit and after I handed in our ticket to pay, the bill never got to us. After a while I got sick of waiting and walked up to the counter to pay. If service was good they would've gotten a full 5-stars because to find such great quality of dim sum in a hotel like this, is absolutely incredible.

Photo of Ping Pang Pong - Las Vegas, NV, United States

fuFl2G6znLsEPVNtjCpgdA.text: Black chicken with black dates soup is friggin special. Also I like that they don't bring me forks. That's super offensive if they bring forks. Why? Because even Japanese restaurant know better they don't bring you a fork to eat sushi.   ***WARNING Don't pay attention about yelpers complaining about service. This is not PF CHANGS, or Applebee's.***  The entry level dim sum is good (KJ Kitchen at the RIO makes the simple stuff better currently--- their LO Bak Go is so er mah gawd!). Reading other reviews on here is so funny because of complaints about service. Want to be seated? Wave some one down, ask loud, better yell it in Cantonese. Don't expect them to ask if you want water or soda. Expect tea and only tea, unless you wave someone down and ask loud for cold water, same with refills. (Although they do bring you large water glasses and it tastes good. As a kid growing up Chinese, I used to think they scoop the water out of the fish tanks because it did taste a bit fish. That must be because they keep the ice machine behind the fish tanks. No fish tanks at PING PANG PONG hahahaha.)   Bring someone Chinese with you if you are scared. Want more tea, shit you know what you have to do with the lid. Want to pay your check? Lift it in the air  "Maaihdaan!!!!" or go up to the Cashier and start picking your teeth with the tooth picks.  If there is old food lingering on your new plates... I wipe that shit off with hot tea and napkin.  What kind of service do people need?   If I read one more review about Orange Beef.... If you go in there ordering General Tso's expect bad service. Tea, take dirty dishes away, bring my food. It's all good in the Chinese hood. If you're scared go to Elephant bar, Jose or Sean Jean will make you something nice there. I'm not racist I eat black chicken.   Seriously about the service, you can have a good ole' dim sum time without making at the least bit eye contact. Oh and lastly, I think I read a review about hot mustard... do they have hot mustard? Hahahahahahahahahahahahahahaha. I'm not going to answer that expect a hahahahaha if you ask.   No seriously eating dim sum is not that hard. I'm just making fun. I gotta go piss off Japanese people by rubbing my wooden chopsticks together down the street while I contemplate what's so delicious about Teriyaki.   Ho Sek Ah!

l_BrzTcMtsD4dw5SjnDV7w.text: Food is decent, but the service is absolutely the worst. I have never eaten somewhere where 100% of the staff is SO rude.

V9nk3g1AHm3mm5qYZpMXWA.text: Not a very good place for dimsum. A bit overprice. One dish of Chinese broccoli is $10.

9uECTs0Wyh_snhzVoS_SKg.text: This place sucks ass! I probably would never recommend this place to anyone and would never come back. The service is horrible! This place isn't that big so you would guess the servers would make more frequent trips with their cart; but nope. And when asking for certain items and being told there's no more, you would also think they would place an order for you or something; once again nope. NEVER AGAIN!!!

3ibNqepxjepnbJN4FOGfhw.text: My fave chinese spot in vegas (coming from OC) Everything is fresh & full of flavor. (Don't mind the service) Dim Sum is always worth the long wait in line

q9Ys1K88RCi9qalwOk5kAA.text: Everything tasted bland . Veggie in garlic sauce had only broccoli N bok Choy . Noodles had no sauce n chicken fried rice had some weird tasting chicken . Only good part is it is open till 3 am . That's it . Not sure what to order if I have to visit again

ZmS-Xz5GR3QtBHk-sKAJPg.text: Dim sum should be non stop coming since its only until 3 pm. By the time it pass to our table, selection is not that much. We need to asked 3 waitress for water refill. Food taste good.SERVICE IS SUCKS!
